title: Oxford to install three-way stop on Tilghman Street - Town considering traffic study to address speeding concerns
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Oxford to install three-way stop on Tilghman Street - Town considering traffic study to address speeding concerns

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 545
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD - The Town of Oxford is taking steps to address traffic concerns on Tilghman Street.Resident Will Cawley brought his concerns to the Commissioners of Oxford at a town meeting Tuesday evening. Cawley spoke about the safety issue of cars driving too fast down Tilghman Street.To address these concerns, the town will be putting in stop signs at the intersection ofTilghman Street and Bank Street. On Thursday, Town Manager Cheryl Lewis said in a text that the stop signs will be installed in the next few weeks."I think the first step really is to put up a stop sign at Tilghman and Bank," Commission President Tom Costigan said at the meeting on Tuesday. "A three-way stop. Let's see if that works."Cawley came to the commissioners with speed data collected over a 13-day period in August as well as a proposal for a speed study from Traffic Concepts Inc. He said that in doing research, he found that the first step in getting the speed lowered from 25 miles per hour on Til-ghman Street would be to have a speed study done."Once the speed study is done, then we can reevaluate what the recommendations are and see if we can make some changes to get the speed lowered," he said.Cawley asked that, in the meantime, the town get speed feedback signs installed on the street.According to the speed data collected by the Oxford Police Department in August, of the 3,225 total vehicles counted, there were 73 speed violations. The max speed recorded was 36 miles per hour.During the meeting, Cawley pointed out that Tilghman Street is 17-feet wide without any shoulders or a continuous sidewalk.Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner said that sidewalks would be a benefit, considering all the pedestrians walking down Tilghman street in the summer."People walk up and down that road, tourists and locals alike," he said. "Sidewalks would be a great thing to look at. But I also know that putting in sidewalks is not as easy as saying, 'We want a sidewalk.'"The speed study proposed by Traffic Concepts Inc. would cost the town $3,100. From it, the town would receive the speed study results, the engineering firm's observations and a report "that details the steps and reasoning used to establish the recommended speed limits."Costigan and Cawley agreed that if town opts to do the speed study, it should be done in the summer, when traffic is at its peak.Costigan said that while he didn't disagree with doing a speed study, putting up stop signs is a good first step."It's not an easy process," Costigan said about getting the speed lowered. "But it's one we can certainly look into and try."Kellner said that once the stop signs are up, there will be a "period of education" for people to get used to the change before they begin ticketing people for failing to stop.Costigan said getting the stop signs installed now, rather than in June or July, is better because it will give drivers time to get used to the stop before the busy summer months."And who knows," he said. "They may even like it." 
 
 Caption: MAGGlE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Oxford resident Will Cawley speaks about his concerns with people driving too fast down Tilghman Street at a Commissioners of Oxford meeting Nov. 14.

title: September declared National Preparedness Month
content:
September declared National Preparedness Month

 August 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A5 | Section: News 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Brian LeCates, director of Emergency Services and Geneva Schaffle, division chief, Emergency Management, accepted a proclamation from the Talbot County Council Aug. 22 recognizing September as National Preparedness Month. The proclamation encourages Americans to prepare for emergencies in their homes, businesses, and schools, and aims to increase public awareness concerning the importance of preparing for emergencies."We are approaching hurricane season, and this week has been very active, so we thought it was a great time to remind the community the importance of preparedness," Schaffle said."Our county works really hard with all of our stakeholders to prepare all year long but there are a couple of things people can do to be prepared." The Department of Emergency Services reminds citizens to visit ready.gov for a list of resources related to manmade and natural hazards, to sign up for weather and other local emergency alerts at talbotalerts.com, and to check out the DES website for preparedness materials.In addition, Planning and Zoning maintains the Community Rating System, which provides residents discount premium insurance rates on flood insurance. "This is also the time to pull out your insurance policies, know what is in your insurance policy and make sure you are prepared for our storm season as we come to a peak here in September," Schaffle said.DES will also host a seven-week Community Disaster Response Course. Community Emergency Response Training provides basic emergency response training, preparedness education, and strategies to help you and your community become more resilient in the event of a disaster. Schaffle noted that there are three spots left in the upcoming course."An informed community is a strong community," County Manager Clay Stamp said. "The key is to connect with Emergency Services today, on a sunny day, so that when the storm clouds come in, you are connected and get timely information and we can respond to help." 
 
 Caption: TALBOT GOVERNMENT
 
Brian LeCates, director of Emergency Services, and Geneva Schaffle, division chief, Emergency Management, accept a proclamation from Council President Chuck Callahan recognizing September as National Preparedness Month. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Toddlers drown in incident in Greensboro on Sunday
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Toddlers drown in incident in Greensboro on Sunday

 June 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 209
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Two toddlers drowned in Greensboro on Sunday, according to the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.On June 29 at approximately 7:30 p.m., deputies from the Caroline County Sheriff's Office responded to the 12000 block of Greensboro Road for a report of a possible drowning, police said in a press release.
Upon arrival, deputies located two pediatric victims, a 2-year-old male and a 3-year-old male, being provided medical treatment from the Caroline County Department of Emergency Services and the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Department. Both children were transported to Shore Regional Health in Easton for further medical treatment. Despite all efforts, both children tragically succumbed to their injuries.
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigation Division is actively investigating this incident and could not provide further details at this time.
"The Caroline County Sheriff's Office extends its deepest condolences to the family and all those affected by this heartbreaking tragedy," the press release said.
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office was assisted by the Maryland State Police, Caroline County States Attorney's Office, Caroline County Department of Emergency Services, The Greensboro Volunteer Fire Department and the Caroline County Department of Social Services.
Anyone with information related to this incident is encouraged to contact the Caroline County Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigation Division at 410-479-2515.
This report will be updated.

title: Cambridge man handed two life sentences without parole
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man handed two life sentences without parole

 March 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 648
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Tramelle Williams, 23, of Cambridge was handed two consecutive life sentences without the possibility of parole for the December 2022 murders of 24-year-old Taijay Daniels and 69-year-old Lory Fields.Before handing over the sentence on Monday, Dorchester County Administrative Judge William Jones called surveillance footage of Daniels' death "possibly in the top five, if not No. 2 most difficult thing I've had to see."
Williams also was handed a consecutive 20-year sentence for robbery charges and two additional consecutive 20-year sentences with mandatory minimums of five years for firearms charges.
Williams was tried separately for the murders of Daniels and Fields. He was found guilty on all counts — which included first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, robbery and firearms charges — in both trials.
A motion for a new trial for the death of Fields, filed by Williams' defense in late January, was denied at the sentencing hearing Monday.
According to court documents, Williams' defense argued there was insufficient evidence to support that a robbery had occurred and that Williams had intended to kill or harm Fields. His defense included in the motion that evidence related to Daniels' death was "unintentionally admitted and sent back" to the jury in the trial for the death of Fields.
According to court documents, in response, the state said the motion for a new trial should be denied because the evidence "clearly supported a conviction on all counts," and said none of the jurors had knowledge of the Daniels case.
"'Taijay Daniels' would be nothing more than a 'John Doe' to the seated jurors," the state's response to the motion says.
At the sentencing hearing, Jones denied the request for a new trial. He said there was sufficient evidence to prove that Williams was responsible for the death of Fields.
Jones said there was an extensive voir dire to make sure no jurors in the Fields trial knew anything about the Daniels case. He said that when the document related to Daniels' death was given to the jury on the Fields case, the jury was told to disregard it.
"And they did," he said.
Before the sentencing was handed over on Monday, Williams was given the opportunity to speak. He said he was sorry to the families of Daniels and Fields, and maintained his innocence. Williams said he thought he could benefit from going to a psychiatric hospital.
The events that resulted in the deaths of Daniels and Fields took place on Dec. 8, 2022. That day, the Cambridge Police Department responded to two shootings in the span of a few hours.
During the trial for Daniels' death, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said Daniels was found dead from multiple gunshot wounds on Pleasant Street, one of which was fired at close range.
Surveillance footage shown in court showed Daniels' last minutes walking past a corner market, followed by Williams shortly after. A video from an apartment complex on Pleasant Street showed a man identified as Williams approaching Daniels with a gun. Daniels dropped his phone as Williams extended his arm, shooting him in the back.
Then, Williams shot again, striking Daniels in the head twice before taking his belongings and leaving.
During the trial for Fields' death, Leonard said Cambridge police had found Fields lying in his front yard. He had been shot once in the head at close range and robbed of the keys to his Chrysler 300, she said.
Police testified that Fields' car keys and Daniels' phone were recovered from Williams the night he was arrested.
At the sentencing hearing, members of both Daniels' and Fields' families spoke.
Daniels' mother, Barbara Gabbin called her son a giver, adding that he was "full of love."
"Taijay was my world," she said.
Fields' daughter Lauren Davis wrote a letter to her deceased father, which she read at the sentencing.
"I have been so lost without you," she said, later adding that she would give anything for just one more day, one more second with him. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnapping in connection to missing woman
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Cambridge man charged with kidnapping in connection to missing woman

 February 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 1018
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man was arrested Monday in the alleged kidnapping of a 31-year-old woman who was reported missing over a week ago. The woman has yet to be located.Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 41, is charged with kidnapping, assault and related charges in connection to Tiyavauna Britt's disappearance.
An arrest warrant indicated Bradley was arrested in Anne Arundel County on Monday, Feb. 19. He was ordered held without bond during a bail review in Glen Burnie District Court that day, according to court records.
Britt, who was first reported missing to the Easton Police Department on Tuesday, Feb. 13, remains "critically missing," according to charging documents authored by a Maryland State Police sergeant.
According to charging documents, Britt's mother told police she had attempted to contact her daughter several times between Jan. 31 and Feb. 13, but had not been able to reach her. Several other family members were unable to make contact with Britt, her mother told police.
Britt's mother also told police that the car typically driven by Britt was found unoccupied in the Dollar Tree parking lot in Easton.
The car was found unlocked with Britt's belongings inside, including her phone and wallet.
Britt's mother said she found a note in the driver's side door of the car that appeared to be "a list of couple goals," according to charging documents. Police wrote that the end of the letter said "No phones, no kids, just us."
It was not clear who authored the note.
According to charging documents, Britt's mother believed her daughter was with her ex-boyfriend, identified as Bradley. The mother feared for her daughter's safety, citing previous domestic violence history between the two.
Bradley is currently on probation for a previous assault conviction related to Britt in Talbot County.
In early September 2021, police responded to an alleyway in Easton, where they found Britt crying. According to charging documents in that case, Britt told police Bradley was chasing her in his truck after the two got into an argument.
Britt told police that Bradley pulled her hair, grabbed her by the throat and choked her. He also reportedly held a pillow over her face and mouth, threatening to kill her, and told her not to leave.
Britt was found to have abrasions on her neck consistent with being choked, along with abrasions on her wrist and redness to the back of her neck at her hairline, police wrote.
While that case was still pending, police were called to an apartment in Hurlock in April 2022 for another altercation between Bradley and Britt, though that case was later placed on the stet, or inactive, docket.
Bradley was convicted of second-degree assault in Talbot County Circuit Court in June 2022 and was sentenced to 10 years, with all but time already served suspended.
He was placed on three years of supervised probation and ordered to complete an abusers' intervention program, though a violation of probation report filed on Feb. 16 indicated he had not provided verification of completing the course.
In further investigating Britt's disappearance, police spoke with three other people who knew her, all of whom said they had last heard from or seen Britt on Wednesday, Feb. 7.
Britt's employer told police she was seen leaving work in Delaware around 3 p.m. Surveillance footage from her employer showed Britt wearing a black coat and black sweatpants, police said.
A woman who identified herself as Britt's cousin told police she was with Britt that afternoon and heard her and Bradley having a verbal argument on the phone before the couple planned to go to dinner at Portside in Cambridge.
The cousin told police Britt dropped her off in Hurlock around 6 p.m., according to charging documents. The two spoke on the phone for several minutes afterward.
Police said a man who identified himself as an acquaintance of Britt said he received a phone call from her shortly after 7:30 p.m. The man told police he briefly spoke with Britt before hearing a male voice, adding that he believed the man with her "started to assault" her before the call suddenly ended.
Detectives obtained cell tower records for Britt's phone, giving police a timeline of events leading to the last time her phone was active, according to charging documents. Police wrote that Britt was in downtown Cambridge and Great Marsh Park that evening.
The last known cell tower location placed Britt's phone at Great Marsh Park shortly before 8:30 p.m. Feb. 7, police wrote.
Police also obtained cell tower data for Bradley's phone number, which placed him in the same area and locations as Britt during that time frame.
Officers from the Cambridge Police Department reviewed surveillance footage between Portside and Great Marsh Park, which showed a dark-colored Chevrolet Suburban pulling into the park shortly before 7:30 p.m.
According to charging documents, a Black male was seen exiting the vehicle with a woman who appeared to have her hands bound. The man walked the woman to the rear of the vehicle, opening and closing the hatch, and walked her to the front of the vehicle — out of view of the camera, police noted.
Further review of the camera footage revealed audio of male and female voices. Police wrote that "sounds of loud thuds" also were heard, which "appear to be consistent with forceful strikes."
Police interviewed a man connected to Britt on Feb. 16, who identified the voices as Britt and Bradley.
Charging documents said a "dark object" was seen lying on the ground in front of the vehicle as it drove away shortly before 8 p.m. The same vehicle was seen returning about 25 minutes later.
Police wrote that the footage showed a male driver leaving the vehicle and walking toward the object. Within minutes, the man was seen "carrying and dragging" what appeared to be a "small statured, light skinned female" consistent with the woman observed in the videos.
The man later carried the woman's "limp body" to the rear cargo area of the vehicle, placing other unknown items there before leaving at 8:30 p.m.
Police have not shared further information on Britt. Anyone with knowledge of her whereabouts is asked to contact Maryland State Police.
Bradley is set to appear for a preliminary hearing in Dorchester County District Court on March 12. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop
author: Contributed
content:
Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 523
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Easton Police Department, the Oxford Police Department and the Talbot County Sheriff 's Office came together Saturday, Dec. 9, for the Talbot Optimist Club's Shop with a Cop event.The event sees police officers pairing with local youths to assist them on a shopping spree to provide holiday gifts for the youths and their families.
Debbie Henckel, event organizer and member of the Talbot Optimist Club, has been working the event for over a decade.
"It's all about the kids, the smiles on their faces, and them being able to have something to give to their families," Henckel said.
The children participating came to the Elks Lodge off Dutchmans Lane, where they were greeted and paired with their chaperoning officers.
After they were welcomed by the officers, the children ventured out to the squad cars to head over to the Easton Walmart.
The squad cars left the Elks Lodge in an impressive fashion, lined up and utilizing lights and sirens similar to a parade procession.
Once they were at Walmart, officers helped the children use their budget and shopping lists to acquire presents for their families. Many of the children involved utilized their entire budget to purchase gifts for their families instead of themselves.
Fortunately, their kindness did not go unnoticed and was rewarded. The chaperoning officers found it in their hearts to give them a little extra so everyone left with a gift of their own.
In addition to the officers chipping in, there were a few shoppers passing by who also donated their own funds to the cause.
"This is a good place we live in," Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said. "I've seen these kids looking out for their families instead of themselves, our officers reaching into their own wallets to make sure no one is left out, and even just some local townspeople going out of their way to do the same. It is really moving, and I'm proud to see it all." After the shopping was completed, the group returned to the Elks Lodge to get wrapping.
Tape, wrapping paper, bags and scissors were all deployed simultaneously as the officers, and their companions took all the gifts and did their best to make everything look beautiful enough to go under the tree.
Once completed, the officers and children enjoyed pizza and snacks together, before wrapping up the day by playing a spirited soccer match on the lawn outside.
In all her years organizing the event, Henckel said she always sees familiar faces among the officers.
"You see a lot of returning officers and you know that's because they care. It's nice to see their eagerness to be here with the kids," she said in a news release. "They really make a difference to these kids, and around our community."
Henckel thanked the Elks Lodge for donating the space, the Easton Walmart for making the event possible and the three police departments for joining forces.
" To have their support over the years means more than you know," she said. 
 
 Caption: GREG MUELLER/TOWN OF EASTON

 Officer Cordero Proctor of the Easton Police Department does some holiday shopping alongside his partner at Walmart in Easton for the Talbot Optimist's Shop with a Cop event. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Accessible AED added in Downtown Easton
author: Contributed
content:
Accessible AED added in Downtown Easton

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first 24-hour publicly accessible automatic external defibrillator (AED) for downtown Easton is now operational, thanks to the collaboration of Talbot CARES and Bluepoint Hospitality.Talbot CARES, a program spearheaded by Talbot Paramedic Foundation, Team Trace and Talbot Emergency Services (DES), aims to provide publicly accessible defibrillators and additional emergency equipment around the county.Located on Washington Street adjacent to Doc's Downtown Grille, the newly placed station will ensure citizens have access to potentially life-saving equipment in case of an emergency, no matter what time it is.The station contains an AED device and other medical supplies, including a Stop the Bleed tourniquet kit and opioid overdose kits."We are incredibly proud of this station.It's the first time we've been able to place a station that is accessible 24 hours a day, outside of a public park or recreation area," said Rachael Cox, special programs paramedic for DES."By placing it in a prominent location downtown, we are hoping that this important resource will be utilized in emergencies by the surrounding community." Talbot Paramedic Foundation sponsored the AED. Bluepoint Hospitality sponsored the construction and installation of the cabinet and will ensure the station has access to constant power.Talbot Emergency Services will keep the station stocked and perform routine check-ups on the AED device."One of our priorities is for visitors and residents to feel safe downtown." said Michael Smith, head of security at Bluepoint Hospitality. "As part of this initiative, many Bluepoint staffers were certified in CPR, First Aid, AED and Stop the Bleed this year. We hope other downtown businesses join in on the efforts. The more staff that is certified, the better we can serve individuals with life-saving techniques before the professionals arrive." A nationally recognized model for placing public access AEDs, Talbot CARES has placed over 200 automatic external defibrillators (AEDs) in businesses, recreation facilities and parks, government buildings and more in Talbot County.To learn more about the program, contact Talbot Paramedic Foundation at talbotparamedic.org. Talbot County Emergency Services offers training sessions for local businesses and organizations, to learn more about available programming, reach out to Rachael Cox at rcox@talbotdes.org. 
 
 Caption: TALBOT COUNTY
 
Wayne Dyott, President of Talbot Paramedic Foundation discusses the AED system with Julia Foxwell, Director of Community Engagement at Bluepoint Hospitality. The Talbot CARE Station is located adjacent to Doc's Downtown Grille on Washington Street. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Plane crashes during landing at Bay Bridge Airport
author: Staff Writer
content:
Plane crashes during landing at Bay Bridge Airport

 April 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 113
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — This morning, a four-seat Cirrus aircraft crashed while landing at Bay Bridge Airport in Stevensville. Queen Anne's County officials said upon landing, the aircraft veered off the side of the runway into a marshy area, coming to rest partially in the water.Although the aircraft sustained significant damage, the sole occupant was not injured, according to Beth Malasky, public information manager for the county.
Shortly after noon, local fire departments and EMS had cleared the scene, and federal and state aviation authorities were en route to conduct a standard investigation into the incident.
Malasky said there is no damage to the runway; however, the airport will remain closed until the investigation is complete.

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week

 June 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here are the 10 stories that attracted the most page views on The Star Democrat's website this week. The stories are ranked in order of number of page views as of Wednesday evening.1. Easton High School graduate dies in car crash
The Easton community is mourning the death of recent high school graduate Darren Foxwell.
2. Body sits in Greensboro yard for hours due to traffic delay, town says
On June 22 at about 1:57 p.m., the Greensboro Police Department were dispatched to an apartment on Maple Avenue in Greensboro in reference to an unattended death. The body of the man who died sat in the yard for upwards of four hours after the medical examiner got stuck in Bay Bridge traffic.
3. Police investigating serious rollover crash outside Trappe
At around 4:30 a.m. June 17, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to an accident in the area of Chloras Point Road and Claylands Road, according to a press release.
The vehicle involved was 150 yards from the road and rolled over multiple times, police said. Authorities say a passenger was ejected from the vehicle and sustained life-threatening injuries.
4. Easton man killed in car crash in Anne Arundel County
An Easton man died in a car crash in Anne Arundel County last week, according to police.
5. Car flips on Route 16 in Cambridge
First responders arrived at the scene of a rollover crash on Route 16 near Egypt Road Park in Cambridge Tuesday evening. No one was injured in the incident.
6. Police arrest 3 in connection to Easton bank robbery
Police have arrested two Cambridge men and an Easton woman in connection to a bank robbery earlier this month.
7. Molly's Place opening second store in Easton
Molly's Place is expanding to Easton late this summer.
The sporting goods store has a location in Kennedyville, Maryland. Co-owners Nick and Chikki Shajwani credit the Waterfowl Festival as one of the main reasons they're coming to Easton.
8. The Blue Crab meets the Bagery: St. Michaels restaurant gets new owners
The beloved Blue Crab Coffee Shop in St. Michaels has reopened under new ownership, but they're not new to many on the Eastern Shore.
9. Man pleads guilty to attempted murder in Trappe gas station shooting
A man pleaded guilty this month to attempted first-degree murder for a Trappe shooting last year.
10. Easton's Keenan steps down as coach
The winningest coach in program history who led the Warriors to their only state championship in 2015, Keenan stepped down at the end of this past season, citing a desire to watch his two youngest sons play in the collegiate ranks.
To read these stories and more, visit stardem.com.

title: 2 charged with hindering drug investigation, reporting fake shooting in Easton
author: Konner Metz
content:
2 charged with hindering drug investigation, reporting fake shooting in Easton

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Police have arrested two people for hindering a drug investigation in April, alleging they made a fake report to 911 that there was a shooting at the Easton Walmart.Elon Black, 38, of Easton, and Lacira Wilson, 39, of Worton, are both facing charges in connection to a drug investigation on April 4.
They were arrested on Sept. 18 and 19 for intent to distribute drugs, obstructing and hindering, and making false statements to police officers.
According to a press release from the Easton Police Department, officers stopped Black's vehicle in the area of U.S. Route 50 and Cecil Drive on April 4. A K-9 search discovered "suspected heroin/fentanyl mix," crack cocaine and ecstasy, police wrote.
During the stop, police said Black was on his phone. Investigators eventually determined that Black called Wilson during that time. Black had Wilson make a call to 911 and report a fake shooting at the Easton Walmart, police said.
Officers went to the Walmart but found no evidence of shots fired.
According to online court records, Black and Wilson both posted $10,000 unsecured personal bond since their arrests, meaning they will only have to pay the full amount if they fail to appear for a court date or break other conditions imposed by the court.
Wilson has a trial scheduled for Nov. 5 in Talbot County District Court. She faces four total charges: obstructing and hindering, making a false statement to officers, and two counts of possession with the intent to distribute a controlled dangerous substance.
Black's trial is scheduled for Nov. 3 in District Court. He faces the same four counts as Wilson.
Black, in a separate case in Talbot County Circuit Court, is also facing two felony, six misdemeanor and 11 traffic counts in connection to the same April 4 traffic stop. A jury trial for those charges is scheduled for Dec. 8.
In that case, he's charged with two felony counts of possession with the intent to distribute narcotics. Black posted $10,000 unsecured bond for those charges back in July.

title: Automotive Group gives $300,000 to first responder training campus
author: Contributed
content:
Automotive Group gives $300,000 to first responder training campus

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 419
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department recently received a $300,000 gift from the Preston Automotive Group for its Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton."Preston Automotive Group is proud to support an amazing project that will benefit the first responders in our local counties firsthand," said David Wilson Jr., president of Preston Automotive Group."We are grateful to have so many brave men and women putting their lives on the line daily to make sure we are all safe. These men and women are the backbone of our community, the least we could do is contribute to a facility that will help train them and give them the resources they need to be as prepared as possible for situations that come their way while protecting us."Located at 9095 Mistletoe Drive, the training campus will serve Talbot County fire departments, emergency service personnel, law enforcement and paramedics for specialized education and certification. Currently, volunteer firefighters on the Mid-Shore have two options for training facilities - Princess Anne in Somerset County or Centreville in Queen Anne's County.Components of the project include a 3,500-square-foot public safety building for first responder training, a 3,600-square-foot classroom training and storage building, and a 1,500-square-foot concrete pad for car fire, extrica-tion/stabilization and traffic safety training.Training for fire departments will include firefighting skills, rescue and motor-vehicle fire/extraction. Law enforcement training will include hostage rescue, physical training/testing, traffic training, Homeland Security and K-9. Emergency Medical Services can use classroom facilities for training."We train together because we answer the call together," said Brett Whitehead, co-chairman of the Public Safety Capital Campaign, which benefits the new training facility, and president of the Friends of EVFD."The donation from the Preston Automotive Group is an essential first step toward ensuring training available for all emergency services in Talbot County, including our volunteer firefighters, our law enforcement and our emergency services personnel and paramedics. The demand for these services continues to grow on the Mid-Shore and this training campus will help meet this critical need."For further information or to donate to the Friends of the EVFD Public Safety Capital Campaign for its Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton, Maryland, contact Brett Whitehead at (302) 236-6249 or whitenj20@gmail.com.

title: 2-structure fire causes $850,000 in damage
author: Tom McCall
content:
2-structure fire causes $850,000 in damage

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 149
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — On Aug. 21, firefighters responded to a two-structure, two-alarm fire Stone Boundary Road. There were no deaths or injuries reported.One affected structure was a former butcher shop and storage building, and the other was a wooden-frame farm house next door. The combined loss of both buildings was estimated at $600,000. The contents within were valued at $250,000.
It took 75 firefighters three hours to control the fire, according to a release from the office of the State Fire Marshal. The Tanker Task Force was called in for additional water.
According to the fire marshal's report, "The fire originated inside the butcher shop shortly after the owner had been doing work inside. Embers from this fire landed on the cedar shingles of the vacant nearby 100+ year old home eventually spreading to the remainder of the house. Both structures are considered a total loss."
There were no smoke alarms present.

title: Human trafficking expert hired by For All Seasons
content:
Human trafficking expert hired by For All Seasons

 August 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A14 | Section: News 
 
 444
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - For All Seasons is part of the Governor's initiative, the Maryland Regional Navigator Program, serving human trafficking victims under the age of 24 in the Mid-Shore of Maryland.Although For All Seasons has been working with victims of human trafficking for years, this program connects its new human trafficking navigator, Susan Ahlstrom, with experts across the state to better support human trafficking victims on the Mid-Shore.Ahlstrom brings experience as a mental health and wellness counselor and is a certified EFT/tapping practitioner, most recently working as the T.A.M.A.R.(Trauma, Addiction, Mental Health, and Recovery) coordinator for female detainees at the Dorchester and Caroline county detention centers.She has over 25 years of experience working in nonprofit development, community building, education and youth advocacy.She holds a Master of Science in Counseling from the University of Hartford and a Bachelor of Arts in English from William Smith College in New York."I hope to help mitigate the upward trend in Human Trafficking by expanding For All Seasons Rape Crisis Center's outreach; and strengthening the medical, legal, social service, and mental health collaboration that has already been established to support survivors.I believe my counseling and education background, along with strong communication and networking skills will help facilitate the most effective trauma-informed response to serve victims and their families in the Mid-Shore region and beyond," Ahlstrom said.Human trafficking involves using force, fraud or threats to obtain some type of labor or commercial sex act against a person's will, often for little or no pay, or something of value such as food, shelter, clothes, or drugs. It is a crime whereby traffickers exploit and profit at the expense of adults or children. All persons under age 18 who exchange sex for something of value are human-trafficking victims regardless of the presence of force, lies or threats. A child cannot legally consent to commercial sex.The Eastern Shore is an attractive place for trafficking because of its geographic location in proximity to transportation routes by land, air and sea that offer opportunities for human traffickers to go undetected.Major highways like I-95, Routes 40, 50, 301, and 13 all make transporting victims and meeting buyers easy. In addition, three major international airports, inexpensive bus transportation, train service, and a high rate of seasonal work, make Maryland attractive to human traffickers.To learn about how to identify possible human trafficking victims, the industries where human trafficking most likely occurs, and ways to help, visit WeSupportSurvivors.org. If you would like more information or would like to request an anti-human trafficking presentation for your place of work or community, email Susan Ahlstrom at sahlstrom@forallseasonsinc.org. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED
 
Susan Ahlstrom is For All Seasons' new human trafficking navigator. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 3B | Section: News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO - While one Greensboro police officer was promoted Monday morning, Oct. 30, the chief announced his departure to join the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.But the focus was on Greensboro Police Chief George Paugh's promotion of Officer Lenox Trams to the rank of lieutenant, pinning his bars on his collar during an informal ceremony at the Town Meeting Hall on Main Street."Well, I'm very humbled," Trams said. "I was recruited here to make a difference and reinstate the love for law enforcement, so I've been trying to do that for seven months, and I'm going to continue to do that. It's a great little town." "I'm going to stay and watch this thing grow, and continue to give excellent service to the citizens and the town," Trams said."We're very proud to have you, and you're doing a fantastic job," Town manager Tammy Kelledes said.Several town employees attended the ceremony. Paugh thanked them and said, "I want to thank you guys for taking your time out of your busy Monday to join Lenox on his special day. It's been a long time coming." "Even though it's been a short period of time in Greensboro, you definitely made an impact in the community," he told Trams."I'm always stopped and told about how well you're doing and how you interact with the community, and that's huge. And that's who you are. You're Mr. Community Policeman," Paugh said."You've done some amazing things, and you're worthy of the rank." Trams joined the Greensboro Police Department with Paugh seven months ago.Most of their law enforcement careers were spent with the Easton Police Department.Trams, 48, was a police officer in Easton for 22 years, completing his career there as a school resource officer at Easton Middle School.Paugh, 50, a 26-year veteran of the Easton Police Department, is leaving soon to join the Caroline County Sheriff's Office as commander of criminal investigations and a lieutenant, the same rank he attained with the EPD.In only seven months, Paugh said, "We made a big impact." "We completely redid all the cars - the technology in them. Everything is up to date," he said. "We got a new CAD (computer-aided dispatch) system, new body cameras, new in-car cameras, all new computer systems" - all updates the department "very, very much" needed.

title: Mid-Shore sheriffs join in call for DJS secretary's resignation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore sheriffs join in call for DJS secretary's resignation

 October 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 693
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sheriffs across the state of Maryland are calling for Gov. Wes Moore (D) to "immediately demand the resignation" of Vincent Schiraldi, secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services.The Dorchester, Talbot and Caroline County sheriffs, along with all but five other Maryland sheriffs, voted Monday to have the Maryland Sheriffs' Association send the governor a letter to this effect.
"Since Schiraldi's appointment in 2022, his extreme policies and lack of leadership as the Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, have directly made communities less safe in Maryland," the letter reads.
"Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes," it later states, "only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes."
A statement from Moore's office noted that "over the past year," the governor has made a "concerted effort" to hold youth accountable and rehabilitate offenders. The statement highlighted a "26% decline in juvenile homicide arrests and 46% decline in non-fatal shootings of juveniles" statewide.
The statement did not directly respond to the Maryland Sheriffs' Association's request for Moore to call for Schiraldi's resignation.
"The governor is fully committed to working with local elected officials, law enforcement, the judiciary, and community leaders to improve public safety by holding youth accountable and rehabilitating them," it reads.
The Department of Juvenile Services did not immediately respond to a request for comment regarding the sheriffs' letter.
Schiraldi, who was officially appointed to the position by Moore in March 2023, has indicated in other media interviews that he has the governor's support and is planning to "stay in his job."
"Gov. Moore has been extremely supportive," Schiraldi told WBAL-TV on Friday afternoon. "He's gotten us additional funds this year — $17 million to make community safer by expanding programs — and I want those community members who are calling for my resignation to feel safe."
SHERIFFS WEIGH INThe Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot sheriffs said their votes to send the letter to Moore were prompted by negative impacts on local communities during Schiraldi's tenure as Department of Juvenile Services secretary.
Dorchester County Sheriff James Phillips said he "lost all respect" for Schiraldi following an in-person community meeting the secretary attended around a year ago.
"He had the audacity to tell us, … 'The data that I'm receiving doesn't support your claim of increased juvenile crime,'" Phillips recalled. "And our reply to that was, 'Well, obviously the numbers are going to go down because you're not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.'"
Phillips said in Dorchester County, "we're dealing with the same people, the same names, the same age kids."
"The law-abiding citizens are suffering because of their ignorance and stupidity in protecting these criminals," Phillips said. "And that's all they are. They might only be 15 or 16, but they're thugs."
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble says there's "no accountability," noting that his office was recently involved in a vehicle chase in which a juvenile had an ankle monitor with batteries that hadn't been replaced for two months.
Gamble said the Mid-Shore has "good" juvenile services workers, "but they're being hampered by the secretary." He pointed to Talbot Teen Court, a first-time program for juvenile offenders of misdemeanor crimes, as more successful in rehabilitating youth compared to the state's services.
"They're getting more community service and stuff out of Teen Court than they would ever get out of DJS," Gamble said. "It's just a failed system. And it's being led by what the Sheriffs' Association believes is a bad pick by the governor."
Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker said recent justice reform — particularly Maryland's Child Interrogation Protection Act — has decreased the ability of police to hold juveniles accountable.
That act, enacted in 2022, restricts police from questioning a child without first talking to the parent or guardian's attorney or the Office of the Public Defender. Baker said it's a "shame when parental rights are superseded by the legislature."
Baker, who serves on the state's juvenile justice reform commission, believes the General Assembly has a "role to play" in improving juvenile reform moving forward.
"Juvenile reform needs to be a high priority to help take the steps needed for them to have accountability for when they step into adulthood," Baker said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Representatives from For All Seasons say the problem of human trafficking in Talbot County is persisting, though they are seeing positive gains in awareness and detection.During a Talbot County Council meeting Tuesday, Lauren Weber, the nonprofit's vice president of strategy and development, provided an update to council members regarding human and labor trafficking.
"It is happening and it's happening here. That continues to be the case," Weber said. " … There's a complexity to human trafficking that it doesn't really know county boundaries."
Weber and Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communications, each said the organization has a special role given its wide reach. For All Seasons' presence in the five Mid-Shore counties — Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot — is critical to providing victims with essential services.
"We know that human trafficking knows no boundaries and that it affects people of different backgrounds, races, genders," Theeke said. "We have seen several cases come through our doors, and it comes from Talbot County. It comes from neighboring counties. We really aim to be the connector to get those people the help that they need."
Council Member Keasha Haythe asked if For All Seasons is seeing a decline in human trafficking numbers. Weber said it's a "double-edged sword."
"A year ago we sat in front of you and said, when we look at our rape crisis center data, a good fifth of what was coming in was having at least one indicator of human trafficking," Weber said. " … That persists."
The organization has noticed a shift in how many people are recognizing signs of human trafficking and making those reports, Weber says.
"The folks that are self-referring, we're seeing a decline," she said. "But we're seeing a real rapid incline in folks coming to us and saying, 'Hey, I know more and now I've seen something.'"
Weber said that since September, more than 120 people have taken For All Seasons' free, online anti-human trafficking course.
For All Seasons is an official regional navigator for the Mid-Shore area, Theeke said, meaning it works on task forces and serves youth and young adults that are victims of trafficking.
At the end of the discussion, council members thanked the For All Seasons representatives for their work and presented the organization with a proclamation Tuesday declaring January as National Human Trafficking Awareness Month.
"We know that even one victim is too many," council Vice President Pete Lesher said. "We appreciate all that you do both on prevention, but also to develop and take care of those who have been victims."

title: Suspect still at large following police pursuit
content:
Suspect still at large following police pursuit

 August 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: B5 | Section: News 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - A suspect was still at large Tuesday morning, Aug. 29, following a pursuit involving Delaware and Maryland police that began Friday, Aug. 25, near Marydel, Maryland.On Friday, officers from the Caroline County Sheriff's Office chased a wanted suspect through the northern part of the county before he escaped into a wooded area.The office's Criminal Investigation Division and several units were searching for Todd Randall Hockensmith, 36, of Felton Tuesday morning, according to Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker.According to a release from the sheriff's office, Caroline County sheriff's deputies, the Maryland State Police and the Delaware State Police went to a property Friday in Marydel, Maryland, looking for Hockensmith.At the property, Hockensmith was seen running to a car, which he used to flee the scene.Police pursued the vehicle through the northern portion of Caroline County until the suspect drove the car off the roadway in the 16000 block of Lentz Road in Henderson, Maryland.According to the police report, Hockensmith fled on foot and ran into a heavily wooded area. As other units arrived, a perimeter was set up and K-9 units were called to assist along with aviation units.After about three hours of law enforcement officers' searching the area, Hockensmith was unable to be located.Investigators learned the vehicle Hockensmith was operating had been reported stolen, according to the police report."The vehicle was reported stolen to the Denton Police Department by Hertrich Chevrolet (in Denton), and we actually located another vehicle on the property that was stolen from them that they didn't even know about," Baker said.On Monday, Aug. 21, Delaware State Police posted on its Facebook page a request for help from the public in locating Hockensmith, who "has three active felony warrants for his arrest for a host of offenses, including theft, burglary and a police pursuit." The Caroline County Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigation Division responded back to the Marydel property where the incident began. A second vehicle was located and recovered that also had been reported stolen through the Denton Police Department.As a result of the on-scene investigation, deputies arrested a female associate of Hockensmith identified as Danyeal L. Shahan. Shahan is being charged with motor vehicle theft and related charges. Shahan was wanted through the state of Delaware. She is being held on bond at the Caroline County Detention Center, according to Baker.The Caroline County Sheriff's Office has active warrants for Hockensmith "for the two motor vehicle deaths (of) two brand new cars from Hertrich Chevrolet here in Denton," Baker said.This is an active investigation and anyone with information is asked to contact the Caroline County Sheriff's Office at 410-479-2515. 
 
 Caption: TODD RANDALL HOCKENSMITH
 
DANYEAL SHAHAN

title: Icy roads, school closures continue into Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Icy roads, school closures continue into Thursday

 January 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Snow has covered the roads of the Eastern Shore since Monday. The counties of Eastern Shore believe they have a plan to get the roads clear by Thursday.Town of Easton crews are working to salt all back roads in town, according to town engineer Rick Van Emburgh.
Van Emburgh said Wednesday afternoon that emergency roads, such as those leading to the hospital, had been the priority. At that point, back roads had been plowed twice and now they focus is salting to prevent from freezing.
Mark Chandler, superintendent of public works for the town of Denton, said as of Wednesday afternoon all roads in town were passable, but he encourage residents to drive with caution.
SCHOOL CLOSURE UPDATES
With schools closed for at least three days this week, Mid-Shore residents have raised questions of whether student will be required to make up missed instructional time.
Talbot County Public Schools will remain closed on Thursday "due to the continued treacherous road conditions in some parts of the county," according to the district's website. TCPS has four days built into the 2024-25 calendar for inclement weather, according to district officials. This means the four days missed will not affect the end of school date for the school year.
Dorchester County Public Schools announced Wednesday evening that Thursday would be a virtual day of instruction for students. Students have been provided with electronic devices to allow them to access classroom instruction. According to the DCPS website, DCPS has three inclement weather days built into its calendar, meaning the three days missed earlier this week will not affect the end of school date for the year.
Caroline County Public School will also be closed Thursday, according to the district website. CCPS has four snow days built into the calendar for inclement weather, meaning the days missed will not affect the end of school date.

title: Residents displaced in 2-house fire
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Residents displaced in 2-house fire

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Of all the things in her home that Leona Demdy, 87, lost to a fire Saturday afternoon, she said her photographs are what she will miss the most.A lifelong resident of Easton, Demdy had collected photos of friends, family and neighbors. She said the snapshots were proudly displayed on her walls.
"I cried, cried, cried," Demdy said as she watched firefighters extinguish the last remaining embers at 17 South Locust Lane, many of her belongings strewn across the front yard of the early 20th century house. "I had everybody's picture on the wall. My walls were just full of pictures."
Demdy's home of 27 years was one of two houses that caught fire a little before 3 p.m. Saturday. It was the second house fire that Demdy had experienced in her life. Her home a few streets over had been lost to a fire three decades prior.
Firefighters were dispatched to the blaze at 3:07 p.m., by which time, neighbors said, flames were spreading quickly between the two structures.
Both Demby, who lived alone, and the family who lived next door were able to make it out of the houses, and emergency officials on the scene said that no serious injuries were reported.
It took firefighters a little more than two hours to control the blaze. Responding fire departments began to gather their equipment and leave the scene a little before 5:30 p.m.
Seven local fire departments responded to the fire — the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, the Cordova Volunteer Fire Company, the St. Michaels Fire Department, the Preston Volunteer Fire Company, the Oxford Fire Company, the Queen Anne-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company and the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, along with local EMS and law enforcement personnel.
The state fire marshal is conducting an investigation into the fire and its causes, the results of which will be available at a later date.
Though exact damages are yet to be determined by the fire marshal, both houses sustained significant damage, and all residents of the structures were displaced.
Demdy said she would be staying with a relative near Salisbury, and arrangements were made for her neighbors.

 Here are the 10 stories that attracted the most page views on The Star Democrat's website this week. The stories are ranked in order of number of page views as of Wednesday evening.1. Police ask for assistance identifying suspect in bank robbery
Police are asking for the community's assistance identifying a man suspected of robbing a bank in Easton Monday afternoon.

On May 20, while Cherrywood Solar workers were at Ronald Spearing Farm, human remains were found.

title: Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy
author: Konner Metz
content:
Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students in grades 10 through 12 graduated from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office inaugural citizens police academy Tuesday night.In a 10-week course that met every Tuesday, officers provided students an inside look at the law enforcement field, teaching topics such as crisis response, bleeding emergencies and traffic stops.
Saints Peter & Paul sophomore Carson Tyree said the academy changed his perspective of police work.
"What stood out is how these guys work. It's not all fun and games," Tyree said. " … When they go into a situation, there's a lot of thinking behind it because they can't violate procedure. If they violate procedure, they can't be a police officer."
Junior Canin Parks said he took the academy to learn more about law enforcement since he is considering entering the field. His favorite week was the virtual reality simulator, during which students were posed with the virtual task of helping people in distress.
Jules Stepp, a Saints Peter & Paul junior, most enjoyed learning about Talbot County's crisis response unit, or SWAT team. Students were shown the inside of a SWAT van and learned about the materials and techniques used in situations that call for crisis response.
"It was like we were there with them," Stepp said. "We got to live vicariously through them."
Stepp said she recommends the academy to anyone interested. The academy made it clear the extreme level of detail that policing requires, she said.
"I was surprised how much detail went into every little thing, and how one little thing can cause a problem so they had to backtrack and think about what the consequences could be," she said. "And how they have to go through so many processes to get grants, peace orders, protective orders and all that type of stuff."
Following Tuesday's 10th and final class, Maj. Steve Elliott thanked the students and called them a "great group" for the first ever citizens police academy. Lt. J.R Dobson said it was a fun 10 weeks.
"I think from day one — when (Sheriff Joe Gamble) was giving you guys a lesson on when the first sheriff of Talbot County was — until now, I've seen you all loosen up," Dobson said.
Gamble thanked Lori Stepp, the grants administrator for the Sheriff's Office, for procuring a grant to make the police academy possible.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is now fielding applications for its second citizens police academy. This round is open to county residents 18 and older. Classes are held every Tuesday for 10 weeks beginning April 8. Applications are open until March 31.
Graduates of the inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office citizens police academy:

title: Weekend storm threatens Shore with rain, wind
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Weekend storm threatens Shore with rain, wind

 October 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 237
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Eastern Shore is expected to see escalating coastal storms late Saturday into Monday.Zack Cooper, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service Office in Mount Holly, said while there is a low chance for thunderstorms or tornadoes, the storm will bring one to three inches of rain and 40 mph winds.
"So really starting late in the day Saturday we'll start to see an increase in cloud cover and shower activity, which will ramp up rapidly from there going into Sunday, which is when most of the heavy rainfall will occur, Sunday into Sunday night and going into Monday as well," Cooper said.
Due to the potential costal storm the Maryland Transportation Authority reminded residents and travelers to be prepared for wind warnings, restrictions and the potential for temporary traffic holds at MDTA bridges Sunday into Monday.
If wind exceeds 55 mph, the MDTA could make the decision to hold traffic or close bridges.
Cooper said minor costal flooding is possible.
While Cooper said this storm doesn't look like it will cause a big flooding event, there are some precautions that residents can take to make sure they stay safe.
"It all starts with just preparation and planning," Cooper said. "A lot of times if there's minor flooding or roadway flooding or things like that the best course of action is to just stay off the roadways."
The National Weather Service will continue to monitor the coastal storm throughout the weekend. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content:
'End of Watch'

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer | Section: End Of Watch 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE— As evening fell, the American flag proudly waved high up between ladder trucks welcoming the community to come, honor, and remember their fallen heroes.A date remembered and honored by many in Queen Anne's County for the last 22 years the Fallen Heroes Memorial continues to be observed Feb. 13. Hosted by Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 108, the event's location has varied through the years. It was held this year at the Centreville United Methodist Church.
The event began with the Pledge of Allegiance and a moment of silence led by Sheriff Gary Hoffman. Senior Pastor Rev. Karen Handy of Centreville Methodist Church welcomed and addressed families, friends and community members.
Chase Armington, past president of Lodge 108 and current Queen Anne's County deputy began, "Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes. It is our duty to never forget them, for they have paved the path forward with their lives. The path leading us here tonight was born from tragedy. Incredible losses. Unbearable pain for our families, friends, and the community. These honored in front of you served our community with pride, dignity, and honor. Knowing their lives could, at any moment be taken, so that we may live. So that we may continue on the path they have now paved."
Sue Nickerson, who lost her son, Centreville Police Officer Michael Nickerson, in 2001 explains, "The FOP from QAC started (this event) and they will always have it on February 13, the night that Michael (Nickerson) and Jason (Schwenz, Queen Anne's County deputy) were killed. But, it's to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne's County."
As a mother who lost her son, this event is near to her heart. Nickerson said, "It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters and our EMTs have done. It is very much appreciated."
First responders marched in for the Presentation of Colors, holding flags to honor those lost in the line of duty.
Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson spoke about stoicism and how it applies here. "The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us. We don't have any control over that. But what we do have control over is how we respond to it, how we react, how we pick up the pieces and go on. Stoicism also places an emphasis on appreciating the unity and precious gift of life."
During this powerful remembrance, family members came, first responder representatives saluted and all placed long-stemmed red roses by the framed photographs.
The names of the fallen heroes were read along with the date of their End of Watch.
Ten Queen Anne's County residents and fallen heroes' pictures filled the front table: Queen Anne's-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company's Daniel Lister, Sudlersville Volunteer Fire Company's "Buck" Clough, Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department's "Dougie" Thomas, United Community Volunteer Fire Department's David Brinkley, Centreville Police Department's Michael Nickerson, QA Sheriff's Deputy Jason Schwenz, DNR Warden Charles Rider, and Maryland State Police troopers Thomas Noyle, Philip Russ and Wallace Mowbray.
Radio transmission echoed for all to hear to mark the ultimate sacrifice given on that fateful Feb. 13, 2001, "Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland. May their dedication and sacrifice never be forgotten and may they rest in eternal peace." Bagpipes played 'Amazing Grace' from the balcony overhead. Silence filled every space of the church.
Handy closed, "Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others. Lord, mend those hearts that are broken in the loss of these loved ones. Lord, we pray that this memorial tonight has brought a bit of peace. Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons. We thank you and pray for those that they have left behind." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man gets 25 years after taking plea deal in murder trial
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Cambridge man gets 25 years after taking plea deal in murder trial

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 289
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge teen was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Sept. 6 in connection to the 2021 fatal shooting of Ja'Len Woolford.Daeveon Johnson, 19, faced a first-degree murder charge in the shooting that occurred on Nov. 18, 2021. Johnson entered an Alford plea for the charge in November 2022.
As part of the plea deal, Johnson will serve 25 years at the Patuxent Youthful Offenders Program. Once 50% of the sentence is served, Johnson will be eligible for parole.
Johnson's sentence will begin dating back to Jan. 4, 2022, the day he was arrested by Cambridge police. He will also serve five years probation.
The sentence orders Johnson to have no contact with Key'Marion Ennals. Ennals, 19, was found not guilty on 12 charges relation to the fatal shooting, including first-degree murder, at a trial this August.
Johnson's sentencing was delayed as part of his plea agreement, which included Johnson testifying during Ennals' trial last month.
In his initial interview with police, Johnson admitted to carrying a .40 caliber firearm. An autopsy revealed that Woolford died from a single gunshot wound from a .40 caliber firearm.
Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard provided a statement following the sentencing of Johnson.
"The State recommended a sentence of life imprisonment, suspending all but forty years of active incarceration," the statement read. "The Court heard heartfelt victim impact statements from three members of the victim's family, each expressing their choice to forgive Mr. Johnson, and each requesting the Court consider a lesser period of active incarceration for Mr. Johnson given his cooperation and remorse.
"The State continues to offer condolences to all family and loved ones impacted by the loss of Ja'Len Woolford, and thanks the Court for its mindful consideration of all circumstances at sentencing." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Crane accident at power substation leaves much of Caroline County without power Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Crane accident at power substation leaves much of Caroline County without power Thursday

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 436
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County residents, business and schools were without power Thursday morning after a commercial vehicle caught on fire at a Delmarva Power substation in Denton, causing mass outages.A third party contractor operating a crane working at the substation on Camp Road hit equipment in the substation, subsequently catching fire, Delmarva Power said in a statement about the event Thursday evening.
"This morning, a third-party contractor came in contact with our infrastructure which initially impacted more than 1,100 customers," the statement said. "Due to the extent of the repairs, we were able to restore 850 customers in just over two hours, with the remaining 300 customers restored two hours later, just before 1 p.m."
Shortly after 9:30 a.m., The Maryland Department of Emergency Management's online outage map showed between 15 and 25 % of Caroline County was without power.
The Caroline County Commissioners were immediately contacted by Delmarva executives discussing the situation.
"Delmarva Power's intergovernmental affairs liaison reached out to me," Caroline County Commissioners President Travis Breeding said. "She was very responsive, kept me up to date on the progress so that we knew what to plan for."
The power outages disrupted operations at many businesses, government agencies, public facilities and schools.
Caroline County Public Schools said Thursday morning that students at Greensboro Elementary School were relocated to the first floor of the building, where temperatures were warmer. The backup generator at the school offered limited heat, and the school stayed up due to the outages being widespread in the area.
Colonel Richardson Middle School and Colonel Richardson High School also lost power. Both schools stayed open with backup generators but gave student drivers the choice to go home. They also granted parents the opportunity to come pick up their kids.
Colonel Richardson High school canceled final exams on Thursday due to the outages.
"I know it. It caused some havoc in a few of our schools, Breeding said. "I think Colonel Richardson Middle, Colonel Richardson High, and Greensboro Elementary had to react and make some changes. But I think all in all we got through it okay."
Caroline County and the town of Denton offered warming shelters for those without power. Wharves of Choptank Visitor & Heritage Center and General James F. Fretterd Community Center staff both confirmed no residents arrived needing a warm place.
Delmarva Power company had the power back on in the Caroline County around 1 p.m. At 1:45 p.m., Choptank Electric, which services customers using Delmarva Power's substation, confirmed all their customers in the area had power restored.
"Delmarva power takes things very seriously, and I believe they did everything they could to restore power as quickly as possible." Breeding said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnap and murder of woman
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge man charged with kidnap and murder of woman

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man has been charged with murder, assault, kidnapping, false imprisonment and reckless endangerment for the kidnapping and murder of 31-year-old Tiyavauna Britt.According to a news release from the Maryland State Police, Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 40, was indicted on these charges on March 29. Bradley is being held without bail at the Dorchester County Detention Center.
Bradley was arrested in connection to Britt's disappearance Feb. 19 in Anne Arundel County, according to previous Star Democrat reporting.
Police said Britt's body has not yet been found. According to the police's preliminary investigation, Britt was last seen in Delaware at work on Feb. 7. Her vehicle was was found unoccupied in the Dollar Tree parking lot in Easton, according to previous Star Democrat reporting. The car was found unlocked with Britt's belongings inside, including her phone and wallet.
According to February charging documents, Britt's mother told police she had attempted to contact her daughter several times between Jan. 31 and Feb. 13, but had not been able to reach her. Several other family members were unable to make contact with Britt, her mother told police.
According to February charging documents, Britt's mother believed her daughter was with her ex-boyfriend, identified as Bradley. The mother feared for her daughter's safety, citing previous domestic violence history between the two.
The investigation, which is ongoing, is being led by the Maryland State Police Homicide Unit with assistance from the Easton and Cambridge police departments.
Maryland State Police asks that anyone with knowledge of Britt's whereabouts contact Maryland State Police Sergeant Scott Sears at 443-783-7230.

title: Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day

 September 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Fire crews initially dispatched for a fire alarm activation at Queen Anne's County High School discovered a small electrical fire around 7:13 p.m. Sept. 9.Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler said in a letter to the school community that the fire broke out in a special education room Tuesday evening. The sprinkler system activated, limiting fire damage to the room where it started.
According to the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal, the fire originated in a rear first-floor office. The preliminary cause was deemed accidental, the result of "an unspecified electrical event of a power surge protector."
The fire marshal estimated about $30,000 in structure and content damages. No injuries were reported.
A total of 36 firefighters responded, with Goodwill Volunteer Fire Company the primary agency in charge. The fire was brought under control in about 30 minutes, the fire marshal said.
The fire alarm company contacted 911, and the school custodian also discovered the fire after the alarm activation.
Water collected in a back hallway, one special education classroom, an office and a conference room as the sprinkler system ran for about 20 minutes, Kibler said.
Third-party contractors were brought in to evaluate and assist. Normal operations resumed Sept. 11, after the school was closed to students and non-essential personnel Wednesday to allow cleanup and assessment. Other Queen Anne's County Public Schools were not affected.
QACPS expressed gratitude to first responders, the Queen Anne's County Fire Marshal's Office, the Maryland State Deputy Fire Marshal, and its custodial and maintenance staff for their work in returning the building to use.
On its Facebook page, QACPS wrote: "We are thankful that there were no injuries, and our fire suppression system worked appropriately."
Questions should be directed to Principal Lou Sheppard, Kibler said.
