title: Federalsburg police chief resigns; sheriff's office takes over leadership
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Federalsburg police chief resigns; sheriff's office takes over leadership

 July 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Caroline 
 
 375
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — At the July 7 town meeting, Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner announced Police Chief Joseph Gasser resigned from his position on June 25."The mayor and council would like to announce the resignation of Chief Gasser from the Federalsburg Police Department effective June 25," Abner said. "We want to thank Chief Gasser for his service to the town and wish him well on his future endeavors."
Within the announcement, Abner said that the Caroline County Sheriff's Office would take over leadership of the Federalsburg Police Department to give the mayor and council time to figure out police department leadership.
"I was contacted by the mayor and council and asked to take over day-to-day operations and management oversight of the department," Sheriff Donald Baker said to the Star Democrat in an interview Tuesday. "I agree to do that on an interim basis for 30 to 60 days until the mayor and council decide what they are going to do moving forward and what that looks like for the Federalsburg Police Department."
The mayor also announced a public forum meeting for July 21 at 6 p.m. at the Federalsburg Town Hall to discuss their options moving forward with the police department, public safety and policing.
While the sheriff's office and the town of Federalsburg are in the early stages of conversation, Baker believes all options are on the table for the Federalsburg Police Department, including an memorandum of understanding with the sheriff's office that could discontinue the police department.
"I believe that everything is on the table to include signing an MOU somewhat like Ridgley's, directly with the sheriff's office of the county," Baker said. "Again, everything is on the table. and we are really early in this stage, but we absolutely could absorb any officers that were left."
Gasser was appointed to police chief position in January. He came into the position with a military background, and he had been serving the Town of Federalsburg for almost 30 years.
Ridgley has maintained a contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to have assigned officers covering the town since last year. In March 2024, the town suspended its police department amid a state investigation.
More recently, Ridgley has agreed to continue the memorandum of understanding with the sheriff's office for the next fiscal year.

title: Trams takes helm as Greensboro police chief
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Trams takes helm as Greensboro police chief

 January 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 326
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Mayor David Spencer administered the oath of office to new Greensboro Police Chief Lenox Trams shortly after 6 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 4, at the Greensboro Community Center and Fire Hall.Trams was named chief on Dec. 11. Also taking the oath of office was Greensboro Police Sgt. Jake Smith. The ceremony and meet and greet preceded the town's first meeting of 2024.
Trams, 48, has a 25-year career in law enforcement. He joined the GPD in March 2023. "(Chief Paugh) did a lot of work to get us up to standards," Trams told attendees, adding he would continue that trend.
Trams said he wants to fill out the department with three more officers. "We want the best officers who can do the job that the town deserves," he said.
Several of Trams' former colleagues from the Easton Police Department were on hand to applaud Trams' swearing-in, including Spencer, who was EPD police chief before retiring in Dec. 2022; Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner, Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker; and former Greensboro Police Chief Lt. George Paugh, who hired Trams to the GPD and moved on in November 2023 to become commander of the criminal investigation division in the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.
Several of Trams' family members attended, and Trams' law enforcement colleagues shared their thoughts.
Upon joining the EPD, Sgt. Al Orrison said Trams offered him his trademark strong handshake and "took me under his wing. My kids actually call him Uncle Lenox. I love this man."
Orrison said Trams had not become cynical after so many years in law enforcement.
"When you get to that 15-, 20-year mark, you become very cynical, and it's hard to have compassion all the time," he said. "But Lenox Trams always has compassion for everyone. He treats everybody fairly, and he's just an incredible human being."
EPD Sgt. David Trevino said Trams has "endless energy" and "never stops giving to people" through mentoring and volunteer work.
"The town of Greensboro is very fortunate," he said.

title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content:
Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law

 May 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 917
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In just a handful of months, K-9 Knox is making an impact at the Easton Police Department.The nearly 2-year-old black lab completed training in January. In 2025's first quarter alone, she was deployed 17 times, making six drug arrests alongside her handler, Pfc. Mark Schinault.
"She has that drive for her reward, her toy after she does a good scan," Schinault said. "That means the world to her, so she's very driven to work."
Knox is part of Easton's new guard of K-9s. Last year, three dogs trained in marijuana detection were forced into early retirement due to the legalization of recreational cannabis use legalization in Maryland, which took effect July 2023.
Easton is not the only agency looking to rebuild its K-9 team in the wake of the legislation. Across the state, law enforcement agencies are working to fund and fill their K-9 units, which serve crucial roles not only in deterring crime, but also in connecting with the community.
Police officers largely agree that dogs trained to sniff marijuana can't be used to detect drug offenses any longer, nor does the dogs' expertise hold up in court.
"I really didn't want to go down the road because I didn't want to be challenged in the courtroom," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
Knox joined K-9 Waylon in Easton, and soon two other young dogs not imprinted on marijuana will fill out the town's K-9 unit. Lt. Tim Larrimore said it has been a "complete rebuild" for the unit since the law passed.
Trained dogs can sometimes cost around $14,000, Larrimore said. Younger, untrained pups are significantly less, though they require major time commitments for training and certification.
Across the state, the work of K-9 dogs — depending on their training — often includes drug sniffing, tracking of suspects or missing subjects, and explosives detection. Knox is certified in drug detection and on her way to certification in tracking.
Schinault and Knox completed more than 60 hours of one-on-one training before she was certified in drug detection. Easton opted to go with untrained dogs to save costs and build rapport between K-9s and officers.
While Maryland K-9s are no longer sniffing for marijuana, Larrimore says their work is more important than ever in combating drug offenses.
"This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that's out," Larrimore said. "So now you need the ability to smell something that the human nose isn't necessarily good at detecting. It's the dog that gets you there."
PLAYING CATCH UP
Kent County Sgt. Scott Lockerman has a passion for not just his K-9 partner, Khari, but for all police dogs across the state. He is president of the Maryland Police K9 Foundation, a nonprofit that helps police agencies buy, train and protect their four-legged workers. The foundation paid for one of Easton's new dogs.
Lockerman said that after the legalization of cannabis, there was roughly a 60-40 split of agencies that could quickly get their K-9 units back on track versus those that were more affected by unexpected retirements. But he said progress is being made across all departments.
"Most of the agencies were able to replenish the dogs," Lockerman said.
At the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, one K-9 retired early after the cannabis law was passed, while multiple dogs retired shortly before. The agency worked ahead to bring in replacement dogs not trained to detect marijuana so the state legislation didn't present too many challenges.
"We saw it coming," Sheriff James Phillips said. "It was on the horizon."
Six K-9s currently work for the Dorchester Sheriff's Office. Three can assist in patrols and narcotic detection, two work in narcotics only, and one bloodhound specializes in tracking. Phillips said the office has adequate funding to fill its seventh and final spot for a K-9 trained in detecting explosives.
Funding often comes from grants, local donations, organizations such as the K9 Foundation and county councils. Phillips said it's "mind-boggling" how generous people have been in donating dogs to the Sheriff's Office.
In addition to purchasing the dogs, agencies pay for safety equipment (like bulletproof vests) and health payments. Departments are also on the hook for vet costs incurred by retired dogs, per state law. For a retired K-9, departments could pay up to as much as $2,500 a year, capped at $10,000 per dog.
Larrimore, the Easton lieutenant, says that hasn't yet presented a major funding challenge, though it could down the road.
"It hasn't hit us yet," he said. "These dogs are just retired last year. They're young, they're healthy."
COMMUNITY IMPACT
When the highly-skilled dogs aren't working a case, they're often out in the community showing more of their friendly side.
In Dorchester County, Sgt. Steve Twilley says the K-9 unit bridges the gap between the Sheriff's Office and the community. The dogs especially help police build trust with kids.
"Next thing you know, that kid's come to you for help instead of lashing out or doing something at school," Twilley said.
Schinault and Knox attended a recent Coffee with a Cop event this spring. Schinault said they're very involved with community policing efforts.
Phillips and Twilley say the same is true in Dorchester County. Whatever dollar amount is spent on police dogs, Phillips says, comes back to the Sheriff's Office "10 times over because of the relationships that we build with the kids and the people."
"I think an agency that's trying to do today's police work and doesn't have the K-9 ability out there, I don't think they're a full police agency," Phillips said. "I think it completes the police agency by having the K-9s." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Three arrested in connection with death of Centreville teen
author: Staff Writer
content:
Three arrested in connection with death of Centreville teen

 October 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office has arrested 19-year-old Kamryn Andrews, 20-year-old James Lawson and 27-year-old Travis Lissau in connection with the June 2025 shooting death of 19-year-old Christopher Parsley of Centreville.On June 1, at approximately 1:15 a.m., deputies from the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office, along with allied emergency services, responded to the 1500 block of Centreville Road in Queenstown for a report of shots fired involving multiple victims.
Responding units discovered Parsley, who had been attending a bonfire with friends, fatally shot. Life-saving measures were initiated; however, Parsley was pronounced dead at the scene.
In a statement issued by the Sheriff's Office Wednesday, Oct. 8, police said detectives from the Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigation Unit immediately launched an investigation, working closely with multiple federal, state and local partners. The investigation was conducted with the collaborative support of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Baltimore-Annapolis Field Office, the Chesapeake Bay Safe Streets Task Force, Homeland Security Investigations' Baltimore Eastern Shore Field Office, the Maryland State Police Centreville Barrack, Centreville Police Department, Delaware State Police, Delaware Information and Analysis Center, Delaware State Police Governor's Task Force, Delaware Probation and Parole, Seaford Police Department and the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office.
After an extensive investigation, the case was brought before a Queen Anne's County grand jury. The grand jury returned indictments, and on Oct. 6, arrest warrants were issued.
Andrews, of Seaford, Delaware, is charged with attempted second-degree murder (two counts), manslaughter, first-degree assault (four counts), second-degree assault (four counts), reckless endangerment (four counts), firearm used in the commission of a crime of violence (four counts), handgun on person (two counts), handgun in vehicle, loaded handgun in vehicle, and possession of a firearm as a minor.
Lawson, of Queenstown, is charged with attempted second-degree murder (four counts), manslaughter, first-degree assault (five counts), second-degree assault (five counts), reckless endangerment (five counts), firearm used in the commission of a crime of violence (five counts), conspiracy to alter physical evidence to avoid criminal prosecution, handgun on person (two counts), loaded handgun on person, possession of a firearm as a minor, and possession of a firearm without a serial number.
Lissau, of Centreville, is charged with attempted second-degree murder (four counts), manslaughter, first-degree assault (five counts), second-degree assault (five counts), reckless endangerment (five counts), firearm used in the commission of a crime of violence (five counts), conspiracy to alter physical evidence to avoid criminal prosecution, loaded handgun on person (two counts), and possession of a firearm without a serial number.
All three were taken into custody and held without bond.
Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, "This has been an incredibly difficult time for Chris' family and for our entire community. The effects of this tragedy have been deeply felt, and our thoughts remain with those who continue to grieve. This investigation reflects the strength of collaboration between our community and our law enforcement partners.
"As the investigation continues, every tip, video, and witness account remains vital to bringing closure for Chris's family and our community. We have zero tolerance for crime in Queen Anne's County and will always stand up for victims who no longer have a voice."
The investigation into the death of Parsley remains ongoing. Investigators continue to seek information from the public and encourage anyone who may have details related to this case to contact the Anonymous Tip Line at 410-758-6666 or email Sheriff-Info@qac.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton man charged with eight counts of child porn possession
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton man charged with eight counts of child porn possession

 June 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 185
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton man has been charged with possession of child pornography.Travis Schwaninger, 42, was arrested for eight counts of possession of child pornography following an investigation by the Criminal Investigations Division of the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.
According to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the Easton Police Department Criminal Investigations Unit received several tips in April about Schwaninger from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. After Easton police determined Shwaninger lived outside its jurisdiction, the department reached out to the Sheriff's Office about taking on the investigation.
On June 11, detectives executed a search warrant on Schwaninger's home and found additional evidence from Schwaninger's electronic devices, the Sheriff's Office said. Schwaninger was arrested on site and transported to the Talbot County Detention Center, police said. He was released on a $20,000 unsecured bond.
That Talbot County Sheriff's Office Patrol Division, Drug Task Force and Crisis Response Unit, as well as the Easton Police Department and Maryland State Police Computer Crimes Unit assisted in the investigation.
Anyone with information about the case can contact Cpl. Samuel Faggert at 410‐822‐1020 or sfaggert@talbotcountymd.gov.

title: Federalsburg workshops agreement with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Federalsburg workshops agreement with Caroline County Sheriff's Office

 September 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 395
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — On Monday, the Federalsburg Town Council held a special meeting to discuss the Memorandum of Understanding it is creating with the Caroline County Sheriffs Office.The MOU will establish policing duties for the town to be carried out by the Sheriff's Office, which will be replacing the town's police department.
While the MOU is not final and revisions could be made, the proposed agreement states that there would be four officers assigned to the Town of Federalsburg for a one-year contract.
According to the council, the four officers would be former Federalsburg Police Department Sgt. Brian McNeill, two cadets from the police academy and one current Sheriff's Office deputy.
At prior meetings, town officials expressed that Federalsburg was pursuing the agreement with the Sheriff's Office to save money on policing services as part of a plan to tackle the town's $5 million debt.
The agreement is set to last for a year, and council members said at prior meetings that regular check-ins will be held with the public.
"We felt as we wanted to give this MOU situation a try for a year, and throughout that year we want to have quarterly meetings with the public," Council Member Brandy James said at an Aug. 3 meeting.
According to the MOU, the cost of the Sheriff's Office coverage for one year would be about $863,000. The town currently pays $1.146 million for the Federalsburg Police Department annually.
The cost saving of $280,000 is slitting less than the projected savings made at a prior public forum. On July 21, Council Member Ian Furgerson said if the town were to sign an MOU with the Sheriff's Office, it would save the town between $300,000 and $500,000 per year.
According to town officials, during a meeting with Sheriff Donnie Baker, there were discussions of potentially utilizing half of the police department building as a space for the town and the other half to house the Sheriff's Office deputies.
Under the draft agreement, the town would provide its police vehicles for the station officers, with line items to be paid by the town for gas and maintenance. The town would pay a $15,000 line item for uniforms for officers.
The Sheriff's Office would manage press releases for criminal events, while the town would handle releases related to town events.
A motion was made to move forward the modified agreement after Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan makes some modifications for clarity. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants
content:
Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HANOVER - The Maryland Department of Transportation congratulated 17 counties and municipalities in Maryland for their selection to receive more than $28 million in Fiscal Year 2023 Safe Streets and Roads for All grants.Awarded by the U.S. Department of Transportation, these grants are an important step toward meeting Maryland's goal of Vision Zero - the elimination of all traffic fatalities and severe injuries on Maryland roadways by 2030.
"In order to create the transportation system that Marylanders deserve, we must work with our citizens, our local officials and our Congressional delegation with unity and focus to deliver safe, equitable access across the state for everyone, whether they drive, ride, or walk," Gov.
Wes Moore said. "These grants help us achieve that goal and help fulfill our mission to lift every community."
The grants will be used for implementation, planning and demonstration projects to improve safety and help prevent deaths and serious injuries on the region's roadways.
MDOT worked in collaboration with local municipalities to advocate for the grant funding.
"The Maryland Department of Transportation is proud to have worked closely with our federal delegation to support our local partners' efforts to receive more than $28 million in funding to boost safety for those who bike, walk and drive on our roads," Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld said. " The Maryland Department of Transportation looks forward to working with local leaders throughout the state to put this money to use to reduce roadway fatalities and ensure our streets are safer for all Marylanders."
The City of Mount Rainier is the largest implementation grant recipient in the state, receiving more than $9.7 million. Funds will be used for traffic calming measures, bicycle network improvements, sidewalk enhancements and pedestrian safety measures near Mount Rainier Elementary School.
The Town of Brentwood received $160,000 to develop a Vision Zero Action Plan.
"As a historically disadvantaged community, we're grateful for this federal investment and support of our county and state partners so that we can deliver safety for our residents, businesses and visitors," Brentwood Mayor Rocio Treminio-Lopez said. "While a small town, we have urban issues that need collaborative approaches to solve."
Baltimore County received $3.5 million to put toward developing a Vision Zero Action Plan.
"Investing in our roadways not only improves vital infrastructure, but prioritizes the safety and wellbeing of our residents and communities," Baltimore County Executive Johnny Olszewski said. "We are grateful to our federal and state partners for their help with the critical planning projects supported with this grant - and for helping to ensure Baltimore County's roads are safe for years to come."
Queen Anne's County received a grant of $280,000 to develop a comprehensive multimodal safety plan.
"This federal grant will help our local, state and federal partners combine knowledge and resources to create a comprehensive highway safety plan that will improve safety for our citizens and everyone traveling though Queen Anne's county," Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jim Moran said.
The City of Cambridge received a grant of $320,000 for research on ways to reorganize its streets to make them safer and more pedestrian-friendly.
"We have a number of streets and intersections that are really quite dangerous, especially to pedestrians," Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout said. "We're grateful for the funding. It's the kind of thing small communities need." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Train and tractor-trailer collide in Hurlock accident
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Train and tractor-trailer collide in Hurlock accident

 February 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 295
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HURLOCK — A collision between a tractor-trailer and train had streets in Hurlock closed down Friday. According to reports from local police, the accident is still under investigation.Onlookers from the scene said it looked as though the truck carrying a load of corn tried to cross in front of the oncoming train.
Ultimately the tractor-trailer made it successfully only half way across the tracks before being struck by the train. Nealson Street at Broad Street remained closed for hours while clean up was conducted. No injuries were reported.
Leon Guin works as a jockey driver at Amick Farms on Nealson Street near where the accident happened. He said he saw the accident just after it happened.
"Our security guards heard the accident," he said, "and two of our outside drivers saw and heard it also. They were bringing the chickens in at that time."
From Guin's point of view, he could see the truck cab and front portion of the trailer wrapped around the side of the train. The covered load had spilled alongside the train tracks and the truck cab twisted so it looked as though the truck was driving on the tracks.
President and General Counsel for Maryland and Delaware Railroad Company Cathrin Banks stated she had reason to believe the operators of the train did everything they were supposed to do approaching the crossing.
Police had to close access at the Nealson Street entrance of Amick, but operations continued via the Route 392 and Delaware Avenue entrance. Four hours later, Guin was leaving work and clean up operations were still continuing, he said.
At press time, Hurlock's Chief of Police Bruce Jones said he was not yet able to release further details of the accident, including the name of the truck driver and company they were hauling for.

title: Church outside Trappe struck by lightning; storms cause other minor damages
author: Konner Metz
content:
Church outside Trappe struck by lightning; storms cause other minor damages

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — As storms traveled through Maryland Tuesday, a church outside of Trappe caught fire after being struck by lightning, according to fire officials.Around 7:45 p.m. Tuesday, firefighters responded to the Faith Chapel United Methodist Church for a blaze caused by lightning. No injuries occurred, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.
The church, located east of Trappe in the village of Bruceville, suffered $25,000 in damages, the fire marshal reported.
The Rev. Gary Moore said the damage is "very, very significant" for the small church, which dates to the 1880s.
"I was there last night," Moore said in an interview Wednesday. "Assessing the building will be a difficult decision as we move into the future."
The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company was assisted by local fire departments in extinguishing the fire. It took around 20 minutes to control, the fire marshal's report stated.
Moore thanked fire crews for their quick response.
"It's what makes living in Talbot County a joy," he said.
Sunday morning services at the Bruceville church will be moved to Trappe United Methodist Church on Maple Avenue, Moore said.
OTHER DAMAGES
Elsewhere in Talbot County, around nine trees fell due to the storm, according to Talbot County Emergency Services Director Brian LeCates. There were also downed wires, some flooding and minor car accidents, he added.
"We had a total of 24 incidents that were storm-related," LeCates said. "Most of them are trees down with wires and then just flooding on streets down in Oxford and here in Easton."
Commerce Drive in Easton was temporarily closed due to flooding Tuesday night, according to the town's Facebook. It reopened shortly after closing.
The St. Michaels town office will be closed Thursday due to repairs to an electric pole lost in the storm, the town announced Wednesday. Repairs won't cause any other outages, the town said.
Jimmy Windsor, Dorchester County's emergency management planner, said there were no reports of major flooding or significant storm damages. He said there was tree damage in northern parts of the county, but no serious incidents.
In Caroline County, a few trees were downed but mostly cleared out of roadways by mid-Wednesday morning.
An Easton Utilities spokesperson said two customers experienced power outages Tuesday night. Easton Utilities President and CEO John Horner cited the organization's efforts to provide reliability.
"Every upgrade we make strengthens our system, reduces outages, and ensures we're prepared to meet growing demands," Horner wrote in a statement.
Thunderstorms in the area are expected to continue Wednesday. According to a briefing from the National Weather Service's Mount Holly/Philadelphia office, Caroline and Talbot counties are under a flood watch alert from 5 p.m. Wednesday to 2 a.m. Thursday.
LeCates stresses residents should avoid driving through flooded waters and take precautions even when home during thunderstorms.
"Prepare your homes for loose objects that will be blowing around," LeCates said. "Secure loose objects."

title: Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - A Preston man pleaded guilty Monday to attempted murder in connection to the February 2022 stabbing of a young woman.After waiving his right to a jury trial two weeks ago, Mark William Thompkins, 25, pleaded guilty to attempted second-degree murder during a hearing in Caroline County Circuit Court.The plea reached Monday comes over a year and a half after the stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.According to Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her. Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.A witness attempted to help the victim but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods, evading officers.After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, to diffuse the situation, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.Following his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022.He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August of this year, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.In court Monday, Franklin said he will recommend a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years of active incarceration suspended, followed by five years of supervised probation and special mental health conditions.State sentencing guidelines recommend five to 10 years, said Jesse Hicks, Thompkins' attorney. The plea is not binding, meaning a judge has the ability to impose a higher or lower sentence than what is recommended.Sentencing will be deferred until Feb. 1, 2024. 
 
 Caption: PHOTO BY MIKE DETMER
 
Police on scene in Preston for a reported stabbing Thursday, Feb. 17, 2022. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 670
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A Chestertown pediatrician has surrendered his license to practice in Maryland ahead of a civil case filed Tuesday morning in Kent County Circuit Court.Julio Ramirez, formerly head of his private practice at 6602 Church Hill Road in Chestertown, is being sued by a Kent County woman. The woman, who is not named in court filings, is seeking relief from the court for physical, psychological and emotional injuries she said she incurred while seeking treatment for her child in his office in 2023.
According to court documents, the woman was touched inappropriately and in a sexual manner while in the treatment room with Ramirez and her daughter. Following the encounter, which she said she tried to rebuff, the woman notified office staff and subsequently filed a report with the Chestertown Police Department.
In September 2023, the woman made a formal complaint to the Maryland State Board of Physicians.
Through the course of the board's investigation, four former employees "all testified to a pervasive environment of sexually abusive, unethical, and inappropriate behavior," according to the investigation report.
The investigation found Ramirez, on multiple occasions, sexually assaulted at least three female employees of his over the course of several years. The investigation further found that he sexually assaulted at least one other mother while in the course of treating her child.
Following the board's initial inquiry into the allegations in April, the board ordered a summary suspension of Ramirez's license, concluding "the public health, safety or welfare imperatively required emergency action in this case."
As a result of the board's investigation, Ramirez permanently surrendered his license to practice medicine, according to a letter Ramirez sent to the board.
As listed by the Maryland Board of Physicians, Ramirez, 65, graduated from Universidad de El Salvador Facultad de Medicina in 1988. He was first licensed in Maryland in 1998.
Ramirez opened his first office in Chestertown in 1999. According to information on his practice's website, he opened a second office in Centreville in 2004 to "better serve the Queen Anne's and neighboring communities." In February of 2015, he moved this office to the Shore Medical Pavilion in Queenstown. Hospital affiliations include the Anne Arundel Medical Center and Chester River Hospital Center.
The woman, named Jane Doe in the court filings, is represented by Schlachman, Belsky, Weiner & Davey of Baltimore. The complaint was filed by Michael J. Belsky and Catherine A. Dickinson.
In a statement released to the press, the law firm attorneys state Ramirez grabbed their client's breasts, vagina and buttocks in the course of examining her daughter. The attorneys state it is likely there are other victims.
"As alleged in the Complaint, Dr. Ramirez was a serial abuser of women. Our office is actively investigating these instances of abuse, especially against mothers who were assaulted while the doctor was treating their children. It goes without saying that this behavior is not acceptable, and we intend to hold the doctor accountable for his actions. We encourage anyone with information on these allegations to reach out to us," Belsky and Dickinson said in an interview with the Kent County News.
Ramirez's office is not taking phone calls. A message on his website states, "It is with a heavy heart that I announce my office has closed permanently. Due to unforeseen circumstances, and after careful deliberation, I have decided to retire and close my practice. I assure you that this decision was not made lightly, and I am deeply saddened that I will no longer be able to serve you and our community as a pediatrician."
He continues, "I would like to thank you for your time and the trust you have given me during our many years of operation in Chestertown. Taking care of your family was an honor and a privilege for me and my staff. My years here have been filled with countless rewarding experiences and the most remarkable patients. These shared moments will be remembered fondly, and will always be with me."
Contacted Tuesday morning, Kent County State's Attorney Brian DiGregroy was not able to immediately respond to inquires regarding any criminal charges. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: A 'crisis' on the shore — animal intake on the rise
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A 'crisis' on the shore — animal intake on the rise

 June 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Animal shelters across the Eastern Shore are facing higher levels of dog and cat intake than seen in years past.Patty Crankshaw-Quimby, executive director of Talbot Humane, said that just in the first six months of this calendar year, the shelter has seen a significant increase in the number of animals entering its care.
There has been a 35% increase in dog intake and a 25% increase in cat intake this year over 2023, she said. Crankshaw-Quimby noted that the shelter has yet to reach its busiest time of the year for kitten, which is in the later summer months and early fall.
"This is a trend we are seeing across the country," Crankshaw-Quimby said. "I am the president of Professional Animal Workers of Maryland, the state association of shelters and animal control agencies, and we are seeing crisis level intake in our larger municipalities."
A similar trend is being seen in Caroline County.
Karen Culotta, director of the Caroline County Humane Society, said the number of dogs at the animal shelter has increased significantly over the past four years.
The shelter is currently at 95% capacity. Though Culotta said they spend all their efforts caring for all the animals they can, the influx has overwhelmed the shelter.
Culotta acknowledged that it is difficult to determine the exact reason for the influx. She said it seems to go beyond issues of pets going without being spayed or neutered. She speculates that it could be economically driven.
"For some people, with the cost of vet care going up, with the cost of everything going up, or, since the pandemic, sometimes (people) can't afford to feed their animals or can't afford to get vaccinations, which is required of every cat and dog in the state of Maryland," Culotta said. "It's very challenging for everybody here."
Crankshaw-Quimby said that the Talbot County Shelter has embedded essential programs to help address the large number of animals the shelter is facing.
"We work very hard to keep animals out of the shelter with our robust assortment of programs; however, being an open admission shelter that turns no county resident in need of surrendering their pet away, as well as performing the role of animal control, one large animal control seizure or a wave of animal surrenders could put us over the top," Crankshaw-Quimby said. "This is why the foster, spay/neuter and intervention programs are so very important."
Culotta said she has contacted directors of other local shelters, and they have noted the "odd" rise in intake.
"It's definitely a crisis here on the Eastern Shore," Culotta said.
Culotta and Crankshaw-Quimby encouraged residents to partake in spray/neuter programs and to sign-up to take in foster animals, particularly dogs, at a local shelter. Participating in these programs can assist shelters as they go through high animal intake, they said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — From Queen Anne's County to Dorchester County many churches, libraries and senior centers assisted as various organizations hosted a point-in-time, a count of all experiencing unsheltered and sheltered homelessness.In Caroline County alone, approximately 142 people were reported to be in attendance on Wednesday. Jimmy Morris, continuum of care housing specialist for Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, said the count in Dorchester County recorded its highest ever number of people experiencing homelessness. Finalized numbers for the Mid-Shore will not be available for several weeks.
Morris said large efforts were made to reach this specific population, from media outreach to visiting encampments. He said this larger effort was made due to the growing population of homelessness on the Shore.
Over the last few years, the population of people experiencing homelessness has skyrocketed on the Eastern Shore, and organizations focused on assisting this population are working to have a proper count in order to better secure funds to provide resources.
Ashley Kessinger, continuum care manager at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, said this winter the organization's shelters were filled with people trying to stay warm.
"It's been a crisis," Kessinger said. "Our shelters are completely full, and they stay full all the time. They're all working off of waitlists. They're all trying to find other ways so that people that come to them, don't have to turn them away. But they're just full and we don't have enough."
According to Kessinger, the results of the data gathered by each jurisdiction will be submitted to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and can be used to secure grant funding.
Yvette Robinson, grant manager at Neighborhood Service Center, was distributing information at the Fredrick Douglas room of the Talbot County Free Library in Easton, one of the locations for the county Wednesday. Robinson said homelessness on the Eastern Shore looks different in comparison to homelessness in major cities. One of those contributing factors, she said, is resources.
"The numbers are growing, the resources are not," Robinson said. "We rely on community partners to try to collaborate so that we can see what's working, what may not be working …we're just trying to get the information out that there are variable resources."
According to Robinson, since Nov. 24, 2024, Neighborhood Service Center has given out 9,000 pounds of food and served over 600 families, a majority of which were homeless.
Kessinger said a contributing factor to the growing homeless population has been a lack of affordable housing on the shore. Many of the people served at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health either have no income or they receive funds from Social Security which can be about $900 a month.
A lack of affordable housing has made the issue worse but it is the mark of homelessness that will make it difficult to get landlords to consider working on affordable housing alternatives.
In her experience, there are some landlords that refuse to help customers that her organization works with because the customers have experienced homelessness. Kessinger said there is an assumption that the customers will be bad tenants or bad people in general.
For Kessinger, everyone deserves help and people shouldn't treat those experiencing homelessness differently because of their circumstance because it can happen to anyone at any time.
"People think homelessness looks a certain way and we have seen people from all walks of life and it does not look a certain way," Kessinger said. "There's a lot of stigma on the shore about homelessness and some people just don't want to see it. If they come across an encampment or something like that, they just want it to go away. …everyone deserves a chance to have a home." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school
author: Konner Metz
content:
Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Newsletters 
 
 187
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Local police and emergency medical professionals took part in a serious training of the utmost importance in Easton on Thursday.Active shooter situations in elementary and secondary schools caused 328 deaths from 2000 to 2022, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.
That's why before every school year, local first responders have made it a habit to complete active shooter trainings. This year's training brought Talbot and Caroline sheriff's deputies, Easton police, local EMTs and paramedics, and others to The Country School.
Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull led a drill Thursday afternoon, showing me just how critical it is that first responders from different counties to work together cohesively under stress.
And the results were enlightening: officers and EMTs didn't always make the correct decision every split-second, but they did confer with each other on what steps to take during the next drill, learning how to get better along the way.
To learn more about the training, read my story below. Also in today's newsletter: Talbot Mentors helps local students achieve their goals, a conservation easement will become a public park in Dorchester County and more.
Thanks for reading.
— Konner Metz

 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Youth issues were the overwhelming theme for the third Cambridge City Council meeting in a row.At the Sept. 12 meeting, residents and commissioners alike made comments about juvenile crime.Lance Cephas, who is the father of Commission President Lajan Cephas and Commissioner Sputty Cephas, said crime is affecting everyone, including the children and families who aren't part of the problem.He further noted the children who aren't contributing to juvenile crime are being punished for the actions of about 25 children, "25 kids should not take this whole city down," he said.Lance Cephas stressed the importance of educating the kids that are caught doing things they shouldn't be."Because if you send them back home to that same environment, ain't nothing going to happen," he said. "A lot of police officers, they'll pick them up, they'll let them go, and soon as they're around the corner, they've done something else to somebody else. So you've got to get them and educate them." He said he understood both his children's, Lajan and Sputty, and Mayor Stephen Rideout's points of view regarding the juvenile curfew but said the council shouldn't be "at each other's throats" and "controlled by 25 kids." "We've all got to come together," he said.In late August, Rideout vetoed a juvenile curfew ordinance which commissioners had passed Aug. 14.Before that, in July, Rideout had proposed an alternative curfew ordinance which had additions and changes from the original curfew ordinance. These included adding definitions and altering language on enforcement procedures and penalties.Since Rideout vetoed the original curfew ordinance, Sputty Cephas has made amendments to Rideout's alternative ordinance in an effort to compromise and "find middle ground." According to council meeting documents, Cephas plans to recommend these amendments Sept. 25 when Rideout's proposed ordinance will be read for a second time.During the meeting, Sputty Cephas talked about finding that middle ground."Commissioner Atkiss made a point to say that $100 is a lot of money for a struggling parent," he said."My day job is in banking, so I understand that struggle as well." Sputty Cephas said he would like to keep fines as part of the penalty for not following the curfew, but said he cut them in half in his amendment. Instead of a $100 fine, it would be $50.At the end of the meeting, Rideout suggested to Sputty Cephas that the two of them get together to talk about the proposed amendments to the alternative ordinance. Sputty Cephas agreed to meet.Two presentations were given during Monday's meeting, as well. One presentation was given by Pam Gregory, president and CEO of United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, and one by Lisa Molock, chief executive director at Let's Thrive Baltimore and an organizer for Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America.Molock talked about the work she has been doing in Baltimore, and Gregory talked about the economic issues that many Marylanders face. She shared data from a report that focused on asset limited, income constrained and employed (or ALICE) Marylanders and shared data on Dorchester County residents specifically. Gregory said that in Dorchester County, 45% of residents are below the ALICE threshold.During public comment, Theresa Stafford said poverty is a "lead driver" for many other issues in Cambridge."We need to get serious about fixing the problem of poverty," Stafford said."Bringing in industries or businesses that will pay good wages, and of course, supporting getting kids educated because that's the other key driver that keeps driving up the crime." 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Pam Gregory, CEO of United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, gives a presentation at a Cambridge City Council meeting on Sept. 11.

title: Firefighters handle major town house blaze in St. Michaels
author: Konner Metz
content:
Firefighters handle major town house blaze in St. Michaels

 June 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Firefighters across the Mid-Shore worked together to put out a large town house fire in St. Michaels on Saturday. No injuries were reported.Around 1:20 p.m. Saturday, the St. Michaels Fire Department responded to a fire at a six-unit town house complex on Martingham Circle. Assistant Chief Phil Jones said a second alarm was requested. Agencies from Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester and Queen Anne's counties assisted, with at least 70 people on the scene.
The fire was caused by an electrical failure with an HVAC system in the attic, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal.
Jones said two of the six units will be "displaced for some time." A third unit incurred small fire damage, a fourth unit sustained water damage and the other two units were unharmed, he said.
The fire marshal's office estimates $1 million in damages to the structure and contents.
First responders were able to extinguish most of the fire in the first hour of efforts. Jones said firefighters were on scene for over four hours Saturday to fully handle the blaze. They had to be mindful of the hot conditions.
"With the heat, it makes it twice as hard for us," Jones said. "Usually a firefighter can only work five to 15 minutes in the heat" without taking a break, he added.
All firefighters were required to receive a medical check on their vitals, Jones said. Crews went through over 20 cases of bottled waters.
Jones emphasized that the firefighters on scene were all volunteers. He expressed appreciation for the responding units from surrounding counties, as the additional manpower was necessary for such a hot day. Jones said there was good cooperation with the homeowners and between fire agencies.
"We all work together to complete everything," Jones said.

title: UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students and staff at Easton High School are evacuating after a bomb threat made Monday afternoon, according to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.At 2:57 p.m., the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said in a release posted to Facebook that deputies are on scene at the school. Students and staff were evacuated into the stadium and are safe, police say.
Police say students who are car riders are being picked up at the Easton Elks Lodge, students who are bus riders are riding buses and students who are walkers can walk home.
As of 3:01 p.m., "all buses (were) being loaded and released from EHS," according to police. All after-school activities are canceled.
Talbot County Public Schools sent EHS families a message at around 2:15 p.m. on Monday.
"Easton High has received a Bomb threat. At this time the school is on lockdown," the message stated. "We are waiting further direction from law enforcement."
"This is an ongoing investigation and Deputies will be on scene for several hours," Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated. "Please avoid the area and obey police detours. We will be sure to release additional information as soon as it becomes available."
Earlier on Monday, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said it was investigating a threat made on social media.
Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, was not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. It was not immediately shared by law enforcement if the Easton High lockdown resulted from this threat or from a separate threat.
On Monday morning, Gamble said all school resource officers in the district were aware of the threat, and extra deputies were patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
This report will be updated.

title: Easton man gets five years for narcotics charges
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton man gets five years for narcotics charges

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - An Easton man was sentenced Wednesday, Nov. 22, to five years in prison for possession with the intent to distribute narcotics.During a plea hearing, Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen Kehoe found Jaurice K. Henry, 27, guilty of two drug charges, handing down two 15-year sentences and suspending all but five years of each in a binding agreement. The two fiveyear terms will be served concurrently, according to court documents.Henry's release will be followed by three years of supervised probation.The charges against Henry stemmed from the Easton Police Department's investigation into a fatal overdose late last year.Police were dispatched to the Econo Lodge on Dec. 5, 2022, for an overdose victim.Officers began and continued resuscitation efforts until they were relieved by Talbot County paramedics.The victim was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, where he was later pronounced dead.Detectives with EPD's Criminal Investigations Division conducted the death investigation. After several months, Henry and Iyana Wilson, 27, were identified as the individuals who sold a cocaine and fentanyl mix to the victim, police said.Two cases involving alleged drug possession and distribution remain pending against Wilson.In September, Wilson entered an Alford plea to possession with intent to distribute narcotics in one case. She is set to be sentenced Dec. 15 in Talbot County Circuit Court.A second case charges Wilson with manufacturing narcotics, conspiring with Henry to manufacture drugs, possession of drug paraphernalia and obstructing justice.She is also alleged to have altered physical evidence relevant to a criminal proceeding and to have possessed contraband in a place of confinement by having narcotics inside her body while at the Easton Police Department, according to charging documents.The second case against Wilson is set for a status conference on Dec. 1. 
 
 Caption: The Talbot County Circuit Court is located at 11 North Washington St., Easton.

title: Chester man charged in murder of father
author: Staff Writer
content:
Chester man charged in murder of father

 July 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News

 Words

 CHESTER — A Chester man has been arrested in connection with the murder of his father. The Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff's Criminal Investigation Unit arrested Drew Bernard Meyer, 32, of Chester, charging him with first degree murder in the death of his father, Wayne Michael Meyer, 65, also of Chester.According to police reports, on May 17, deputies were dispatched to Auckland Way in Chester, for a report of a cardiac arrest. Upon arrival, deputies found Wayne Meyer deceased under "suspicious circumstances."
The Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff's Criminal Investigation Unit assumed the investigation and identified Drew Meyer as the primary suspect in the isolated event. A short time later he was apprehended by an allied police agency.
Meyer is being held without bond pending his preliminary hearing on Aug. 7.
In a statement released to the public, Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, "Our thoughts are with the Meyer family during this incredibly difficult time. We are committed to protecting the privacy of the family as they navigate this tragic event. This was an isolated domestic situation, and we appreciate the public's trust in our investigators to bring this case to a swift conclusion. We are grateful that Drew Meyer will now be processed through the criminal justice system, ensuring that justice is served."
Anyone with additional information about the case is asked to contact DFC Armington of the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff at 410-758-0770 ext. 1938 or carmington@qac.org. The Anonymous Tip Line can also be reached at 410-758-6666.

title: Time to remove delivery boxes

Time to remove delivery boxes

 December 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 As your editor reminds us frequently, the decision to stop hand delivery of the Star Democrat to our homes is perhaps economically necessary and practical to continue bringing local news to our community.However, no attention whatsoever has yet been directed toward removing the thousands of rusted, deteriorating, bright yellow Star Democrat boxes from our front yards and local roads.
We support your modernization, but now tell us how to unearth the boxes without buying tools, hiring someone or hurting ourselves. Those boxes do not get prettier with time and will continue to mar our beautiful highways until they are removed.
If we get them out of the ground, can someone collect them and dispose of them in a responsible way? Too rusty and dangerous for service groups or school kids to get service hours?
Let's come up with a happy resolution for keeping our scenery free of antiquated ugliness, OK?
SUZANNE HOOD
Royal Oak

title: Crime in Cambridge 'trending down,' police department says
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Crime in Cambridge 'trending down,' police department says

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 521
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The number of reported crimes, ShotSpotter alerts and shots fired calls is down in the first quarter of this year compared to last year in Cambridge, according to a quarterly report from the Cambridge Police Department.Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said he thinks this shows that crime in Cambridge is "trending down."
"A lot of credit goes to our officers that are out doing what we're asking of them to do as an administration," he said about these decreases. "And that's patrol with a purpose, be in our high-crime areas."
Todd also attributes the lowering of these stats to the department's work in getting guns off the street. He said that last year the department averaged getting one illegal firearm off the street per week in Cambridge alone.
"We know there's more out there, and we know there's still crime," Todd said. "But we're making progress."
According to the CPD report, in the first quarter of 2024, CPD submitted 200 crime incidents committed within its jurisdiction to the National Incident-Based Reporting System, a national reporting system for crimes used by police departments. That is compared to 247 incidents submitted in the first quarter of 2023.
This year, the majority of those incidents have been assaults.
The CPD report also states there was a 33.3% decrease in ShotSpotter alerts for the first quarter of 2024 compared to the first quarter of 2023. ShotSpotter is a gunshot detection system that has sensors that can detect and locate illegal gunfire incidents and alert law enforcement.
The CPD report states there was a 40.9% decrease in shots fire calls compared to the first quarter of 2023.
The first quarter of this year, there were 46 Shot Spotter alerts and 13 shots fired calls in Cambridge, according to the report. There was one shooting in that time.
Todd confirmed that shooting was on March 1 in the 800 block of Phillips Street. According to previous Dorchester Star reporting, police found several spent shell casings from multiple calibers of handguns on the scene. Isaiah David Foster, 23, of Cambridge was arrested on firearm possession charges, as well as resisting arrest and obstructing and hindering, following the incident.
According to the CPD report, calls for service increased 9.1% in the first quarter of 2024 compared to the first quarter of 2023. Todd said this is a good thing because it shows that officers are out in the community doing their jobs.
Compared to 171 adult arrests, there were eight juvenile arrests and 34 juvenile referrals in the first quarter of 2024.
Although Todd said he didn't have those numbers for this time last year, when it comes to juvenile crime, he thinks Cambridge is "stagnant."
"I think there's a lot of work to do with juvenile reform," he said. "We have to put more emphasis on figuring out why these kids are out committing these crimes and getting in touch with families by working through social services and Juvenile Services."
Todd said that the department will have a better understanding of the state of crime in Cambridge come summer.
"When the kids get out of school, that'll be a big factor of just how good we're doing crime-wise," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 2 arrested on gun charges in Days Inn incident
author: Konner Metz
content:
2 arrested on gun charges in Days Inn incident

 August 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Police arrested two people last week on firearm charges stemming from an incident at the Days Inn hotel in Easton.Ernest Young Jr., 40, of Federalsburg and Katherine Adkins, 29, of Queen Anne were both arrested on Aug. 12 after an incident that afternoon. Young is charged with first-degree assault, home invasion, reckless endangerment and four firearm charges.
Adkins faces two handgun charges, accessory after the fact to a felony, altering physical evidence and making a false statement to an officer.
Around 1:40 p.m. on Aug. 12, police were dispatched to a first-floor room in the hotel. According to court documents, 58-year-old James Terrell Jr. told police he and Adkins were in the room when Young knocked at the door.
A few minutes later, Young allegedly pointed a gun at his chest, Terrell told police. Terrell grabbed Adkins and left the room before "Young grabbed Adkins and took her back" into the room, per court records.
A woman in a room on the second floor later told police that Adkins "knocked on her door and handed her a handgun." Adkins allegedly told the woman, "'Take this 'cause I don't want to get in trouble,'" court records indicate.
An officer saw Adkins on the second floor and approached her. Adkins told officers "there was no gun" and soon after "doubled down" on that assertion, court records state.
Officers found a gun in the second-floor room, which was allegedly the same one hidden by Adkins and held by Young during the incident on the first floor.
Adkins was released on $25,000 unsecured personal bond on Aug. 14. A preliminary hearing is set for Sept. 2.
Young posted $1,000 cash bond on Aug. 3. His preliminary hearing is set for Sept. 3.

title: Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — J.R. Dobson grew up around the fire house, always knowing he wanted to be a firefighter.In his teenage years, Dobson joined the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company as a junior cadet, and by 16 he began riding the fire trucks. He fondly recalls the "everybody knew everybody" aspect of the tight-knit community.
Dobson eventually moved to Easton, beginning his journey with the Easton Volunteer Fire Department in 2003. Over time, he's served in a number of roles, including most recently, assistant chief.
Now he's taking on the department's top role for the first time. Dobson was elected the department's chief in December.
With a wife and two daughters, timing was everything for Dobson when considering the commitment to assume a role as demanding as Easton fire chief. The timing is right, he said, and he's looking forward to leading and making a difference.
"There's a lot of tradition here," Dobson said. "It's certainly the biggest department in the county. It's got probably the most going on out of all the departments in the county. I think just being here, seeing how this department operates versus a small department. It's a business. And we're all here for free, none of us get paid."
Dobson officially began as chief this month. Sonny Jones just wrapped up his third two-year term leading the department.
Dobson, who volunteers at the fire department as all the firefighters do, is a patrol and operations commander at the Talbot County Sheriff's Office. He believes his experience leading around 35 deputies across multiple divisions will translate to his duties in the fire house.
"I think that I bring a lot of management skills, leadership skills," Dobson said. "Just from my experience there, I think it helps you here."
Thus far, Dobson says the support he's received has been "overwhelming."
Past fire chiefs have reached out, and he hopes to pick up one thing from each of them to set himself up for success. For instance, Jones' ability as an incident commander is something Dobson admires.
"If there were ever a bad day anybody was having, he's who you would want there," Dobson said of Jones. "Just the way he kind of rolls through an incident scene. He's been there and done that kind of thing."
Similarly, Jones — who is remaining involved with the department — spoke highly of Dobson.
"I've known J.R. the entire time that I've been a member of the Easton fire department," Jones said. "J.R. is a first-rate guy. He's a terrific leader. He has many, many qualities which will bode well for him as the chief of the department."
Some of the ongoing projects the new fire chief has his eye on include purchasing a utility vehicle to use for Rails to Trails and woods fires, buying a new engine and updating box alarm assignments. He also wants to implement some new standard operating procedures.
Dobson said he hopes to nail down a handful of tasks for the year and keep circling back to see what progress is being made. At the top of his list is recruitment and retention of volunteers.
"I think it all starts with recruiting. I think it all starts with retention," Dobson said. "Those are things that we've done well in the past, although the last year or so we haven't gotten as many members as we would like. And sometimes we'll get members in and they don't realize the commitment."
While acknowledging the town's consistent support of the department over the years, Dobson believes Easton Fire can do better in attracting more volunteers amid struggles statewide and nationwide to fill volunteer fire departments.
"We got to get people in here," Dobson said. "We've got to get these trucks out. And I think that the way the town's growing, if we don't grow with it, then we're failing ourselves." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot, Queen Anne's counties included on Trump's list of 'sanctuary jurisdictions'
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot, Queen Anne's counties included on Trump's list of 'sanctuary jurisdictions'

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 636
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot and Queen Anne's counties have been listed as "sanctuary jurisdictions" by the Trump administration, a label disputed by officials from both counties.President Donald Trump issued an executive order last month instructing DHS Secretary Kristi Noem to track the jurisdictions the administration considers to be defying the president's immigration crackdown efforts.
On Thursday, the Department of Homeland Security published a list of more than 500 jurisdictions across the country, stating that those jurisdictions are "defying federal immigration law."
Queen Anne's and Talbot officials challenged the claim Friday. In a statement, Queen Anne's County called the sanctuary designation "wholly inaccurate."
"Queen Anne's County has never adopted or endorsed sanctuary policies, nor have we enacted any ordinances or resolutions that would shield individuals in violation of federal immigration law," the statement read.
Talbot County said it received no communication from the federal government that it wasn't complying with federal immigration laws in advance of the list being published.
"We have, and will continue to, follow all applicable federal laws and have not taken any deliberate actions to obstruct their enforcement," a statement from a Talbot County spokesperson read.
"We welcome further information and guidance from the federal government so we can address any pertinent issues," the statement added.
The DHS website states that jurisdictions were designated "sanctuary" based on the following factors: "compliance with federal law enforcement, information restrictions, and legal protections for illegal aliens."
Noem said in a DHS press release about the list of jurisdictions that the department is "exposing these sanctuary politicians who harbor criminal illegal aliens and defy federal law."
"These sanctuary city politicians are endangering Americans and our law enforcement in order to protect violent criminal illegal aliens," Noem said.
As part of Trump's effort to label "sanctuary jurisdictions," federal agencies are directed to identify federal grants and contracts for potential "suspension or termination, as appropriate," per the president's executive order.
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said in an interview Friday he's concerned for the status of a federal grant that goes to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office. This year, the agency received $40,000 to increase patrol efforts in Trappe, a town without its own police department.
The grant — which is administered annually — has led to a number of arrests and reduced crime, Gamble said.
"We hope that we can reapply and renew that grant," he said.
Talbot County's inclusion on the list was a "total shock" to Gamble, who says his office has always complied with immigration agents. "They haven't asked us to do anything," he said. "We haven't said no to anything."
Gamble said he's spoken with the former and current Maryland ICE directors, both of whom indicated they are unsure of why Talbot County is listed.
Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann expressed similar sentiments. He said Friday he's not aware of any actions by his office or the county government that could lead to the sanctuary designation.
"This is continued misinformation that's been perpetuated now," Hofmann said. "I've heard this for a couple years, so it's of no surprise."
Under Trump, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, has ramped up agreements with local law enforcement agencies, referred to as 287(g) agreements, to carry out immigration crackdown efforts. ICE has signed nearly 700 of these agreements nationwide and seven in Maryland.
Neither Talbot County nor Queen Anne's County are currently engaged in 287(g) agreements. Hofmann and Gamble said since the sheriff's offices aren't in charge of the counties' jails, they can't enter into jail enforcement agreements with ICE like other Maryland counties have.
Hofmann noted the Queen Anne's sheriff's office was eligible for ICE's Secure Communities program, a separate and now defunct effort where local agencies submitted fingerprints of those arrested to the federal government. Fingerprints were cross-checked with immigration databases.
Hofmann added that since it ended, his office "hasn't changed on how we deal with criminals," emphasizing a "zero tolerance" approach.
The Associated Press contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Longtime fire department volunteer remembered in fishing tournament
author: Contributed
content:
Longtime fire department volunteer remembered in fishing tournament

 October 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 4 | Section: News

 OXFORD - On Oct. 8, over $6,500 in proceeds from the third Big Al's Gone Fishin' Tournament and Auction were presented to the Oxford Volunteer Fire Company.The Tournament, held on June 3 at Doc's Sunset Grille in Oxford, was a fundraiser and tribute to the memory of the Alvin L. "Big Al" Ledford.Ledford was known for his love of fishing, dedication to service, and his welcoming spirit. He was a lifetime member of Oxford Fire Co. and served the department as a fireman and an EMT from 1976 until his death in January, 2020.As it has for the past two years, the 2023 Big Al's Gone Fishin' Tournament was a day to remember.· rganizers said the event symbolized the essence of Oxford's tight-knit community and the love and respect they held for Ledford.Participants gathered at Doc's Sunset Grille, a venue that held significance for the Oxford Fire Co. volunteer, and shared stories of their encounters with him."These generous contributions made this tournament successful and possible," said Mark Ledford, Alvin's son and the event's organizer."In particular, I'd like to acknowledge Doc's Sunset Grille, Campbell's Boat Yard, and Roto-Rooter of Delmarva." Tim Kearns, president of Oxford Fire Co., said that monies raised from this event will be used to buy new radios, lights and graphics for the fire boat. Funds will also be used to update worn equipment."It was busy and a great crowd this year, and we look forward to being part of the Tournament next time," said Chooch Oristian, the owner of Doc's.

On Friday, the two teens were referred to the Department of Juvenile Services and charged.
