title: Workshop encourages becoming an informed weather spotter
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Workshop encourages becoming an informed weather spotter

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For Warning Coordinator Meteorologist for the National Weather Service, Sarah Johnson, discussing weather's not just typical small talk.She deals in tornados, hail, high winds and severe storms all the time. As Marylanders escape winter weather, hopefully, there's a pause in the storm seasons.
June is considered the beginning of hurricane season and Johnson mentioned some things to stay alert to on the Eastern Shore.
At the Kent County Public Library on March 21, she introduced her audience to their program: SKYWARN.
She's looking for more and more people to become a spotter, who look out for the basics of thunderstorm development, storm structure and severe weather features, then report the information accurately.
"The main mission of the spotter is to be aware of the rapidly changing conditions of the weather," Johnson replied.
And it's sorely needed too.
Johnson said last year they reported the second most severe thunderstorms.
The third most for tornado warnings.
And the fourth most in flash flood warnings.
Unperturbed by the smaller audience in attendance, she was concise and enthusiastic while walking through the process of what to look out for.
For instance, people tend to be on high alert when they get something on their phone saying "tornado warning." Not so much when they get a "severe thunderstorm warning."
"That's a mistake to think one's worse than the other," Johnson commented.
Especially when water can be more harmful than wind in most cases, she said.
"When we look at the fatalities, 75% in the United States are due to water in some way; 50% of those are those are due to storm surge; 25% freshwater heavy rain flooding. Keep that in mind. Don't think, 'Oh, it's just a tropical storm.' No, you still need to pay attention and see what the hazards are."
Severe storms should not be treated much differently than a tornado.
She then pointed out the difference between a storm watch and a storm warning. A watch means to keep an eye on the weather pattern.
A warning means, don't just watch — get prepared.
A severe storm warning means, gather up some candles for light, or buy extra gas for the back-up generator and do things that will prepare your family and yourself for a potential hazard.
As hurricanes emerge from the North Atlantic ocean and the Gulf of Mexico, Johnson reminded her audience how to categorize them and what that exactly means.
Hurricanes, big or small, she indicated, can create problems, such as tornados.
The uninformed, she added, might hear about a category 1 hurricane and think it's not much of a problem. They'll see it as a little rain and wind. Very minimal damage.
The savvy spotter though, will see that even a category 1 hurricane can create big problems, such as a tornado. The spotter will know category 1, simply describes the wind of the hurricane. Nothing else. It does not highlight the possibility of it creating tornados or other adverse weather conditions.
And those who think tornados are only a threat in Kansas are in for a rude awakening.
Tornados hit everywhere, Johnson pointed out. Even in our backyard.
She said Hurricane Ida was a remnant tropical system that produced a lot of tornados in 2020.
Hurricane Isaias was a destructive Category 1 hurricane, producing the longest tracked tornado in Delaware history.
Tornados in Cecil County and Southern Delaware — resulted in fatalities last year.
"That's why we need you all," she said, encouraging her audience to report their observations to their nearest national weather station.
To become a spotter, adults are invited to complete the SKYWARN training.
Those who finish the course join a volunteer program with between 350,000 and 400,000 trained severe weather spotters.
Individuals affiliated with hospitals, schools, churches and nursing homes or who have a responsibility for protecting others are encouraged to become a spotter.
"There can be no finer reward than to know that your efforts have given your family and neighbors the precious gift of time—minutes that can help save lives," as stated by the NWS.
And as the movie "Twisters," the sequel to the original from 1996, comes out in theaters shortly, Johnson jokes that she's preparing to field a lot more questions about tornados.
She discouraged the crowd on becoming storm chasers like sensationalist Hollywood actors and actresses, but rather to become informed citizens who save lives. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Anton Black's family settles with state medical examiner
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Anton Black's family settles with state medical examiner

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 773
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - A $235,000 settlement approved by the Board of Public Works resolved all claims in a federal lawsuit brought against the state medical examiner by the family of 19-year-old Anton Black, who died in Greensboro in 2018 after being restrained by police.The settlement, which includes a $100,000 payment to Black's family and $135,000 toward attorneys' fees, was approved without discussion during Wednesday's Board of Public Works meeting.The settlement also "makes necessary changes to the Maryland Office of the Chief Medical Examiner's process for autopsies conducted on people killed in law enforcement custody and requires notification to families about the results and their rights to challenge the results," according to a news release from the American Civil Liberties Union.Reforms to the state medical examiner's office include the adoption of a policy addressing how medical examiners handle deaths in custody, which includes those involving law enforcement restraint, according to the ACLU.The policy also incorporates and models guidelines from the National Association of Medical Examiners for determining how such deaths are investigated and how examiners determine causation.The ACLU said the reforms will instill more transparency, impartiality and "independence from improper law enforcement influence." The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner must also provide families with information on their rights to seek correction of an autopsy report and the procedures to seek that correction.In a statement, Richard Potter, the founder of the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black, called the settlement an "excellent first step," adding that community members must stay vigilant to ensure it's effective and increases accountability from within."I hope that with this settlement agencies will begin to recognize their own wrongdoings, catch them and change them before they cause harm," he said in the statement. "What is needed is a sense of shared ownership that can only come through trust and mutual accountability, with police confronting their own biases about mental illness, committing to de-escalation, and truly serving a diverse community." Black died on his mother's front steps on Sept. 15, 2018, after being chased, tased and restrained by three white police officers and a white civilian.That day, Black and a 12-year-old family friend were walking around Greensboro together when Black began pulling and dragging the child, who was calling out for help, garnering attention from onlookers that led to a call to police.The chase ended outside Black's home, where Greensboro Police Officer Thomas Webster IV, offduty Ridgely Police Chief Gary Manos, Centreville Police Officer Dennis Lannon and a civilian attempted to restrain Black, pressing his body against a wooden handicap ramp for six minutes while attempting to handcuff and shackle him.Black later became unresponsive, but continued breathing and had a pulse.Officers rolled Black on his side, then shifted him to a sitting position.After no further response, officers removed the handcuffs and began CPR. Black was later transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton, where he was pronounced dead that evening.The medical examiner ruled that Black's death was an accident caused by a heart condition, with bipolar disorder as a contributing cause.Unanswered questions surrounding Black's death and excessive use of force spurred the litigation. The family filed a wrongful death lawsuit against multiple police officers, towns and the state medical examiner involved in the case in December 2020.No one was charged in connection to Black's death.In August 2022, the family and coalition reached a settlement that required police departments in Greensboro, Ridgely and Centreville to overhaul use of force policies and the enhancement of resources for police confronting mental health emergencies; officer training in de-escalation, intervention and implicit bias; hiring transparency; and public complaint reporting.The settlement also included a $5 million payment to Black's family from the police and municipal defendants.Black's death caused his family and the coalition to become deeply involved in Maryland's campaign for police reform and accountability.Efforts by the family and the Coalition led to the passage of Anton's Law in 2021, which makes police discipline records available to the community under Maryland's Public Information Act.Sonia Kumar, a senior staff attorney with the ACLU of Maryland, said the "hardfought" settlement is about ensuring the medical examiner is truthful about what happens when people, particularly Black people, are killed by police or corrections officials."We can't prevent such deaths if we aren't honest about what caused them, and this settlement is a crucial step towards that goal in future cases," she said in a statement. "We hope this settlement will make a real, positive impact, but it is truly just the beginning of the reckoning needed to address decades of misrepresentations so we can bring justice to families still waiting for the government to tell the truth." 
 
 Caption: ANTON BLACK 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline County leaning towards not going forward with Regional Detention Center
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County leaning towards not going forward with Regional Detention Center

 September 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 613
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At the Caroline County Commissioners' Sept. 2 meeting, County Administrator Kathleen Freeman told the commissioners about a recent conversation she had with Queen Anne's County about whether Caroline County was on board for a potential regional detention center.The commissioners stated that if no new information was made available on the operating budget, they would back out of a drafted agreement that outlines a joint effort on the new 388-bed facility that would house all Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent county prisoners.
"Unfortunately, because of their schedule and their pay scale, I don't think Caroline County is going to save any money by entering into the agreement," Commissioners President Travis Breeding said. "If we're not going to save any money, why relinquish the autonomy that we have right now to operate as our own facility and better suit the needs of the Caroline County as opposed to a three-county organization.
"I just don't see the the upside at this point," he said. "We did our due diligence, we looked into it, it's just not going to work."
The potential detention center would be located at the former Eastern Pre-Release Unit site at 700 Flat Iron Square Road near Church Hill.
The center aims to address the growing need for modern and efficient detention facilities in the region, where counties are struggling to finance renovations or replacements of their aging detention facilities.
"We appreciate the the time and and the effort that Kent, Queen Anne's and our staff have put into researching this, we did our due diligence, and we just don't feel that it's going to be advantageous for us to enter into the three-county agreement," Breeding said, adding the county spent a lot of time studying the proposal. "We went through the process, and in theory it looked like it should have been a good deal for Caroline County, but it just hasn't worked out that way."
In prior discussions of the detention center, the commissioners' concerns largely dealt with who would manage and staff the new facility, as well as how authority over the facility would be divided among the three participating counties.
The commissioners proposed a regional authority to manage the detention center, which was not mentioned in the original drafted agreement between the three counties.
The majority of the authority over the center would have been in Queen Anne's County hands, according to the draft. All decisions and disagreement must go through Queen Anne's County Commissioners, and if they may have a disagreement it will be mediated.
The Caroline County commissioners expressed concerns about the autonomy and authority of the the new facility's warden. According to the draft agreement, "The Board shall appoint a Warden to operate the Facility with the consent of the County Commissioners of Queen Anne's County."
The draft agreement also stated that "The Warden's contract shall not be terminated without the Board's consent"
The commissioners voiced that they believed under the draft that Queens Anne's county could decide after a certain amount of time to remove Caroline or Kent county from agreement, regardless of the amount of money that was put up. To remove one or both of the other counties from the agreement, according to the draft, Queen Anne's County must give the other county a two-year notice to take its prisoners and house them elsewhere.
The commissioners said they understood Queen Anne's County's decision to conduct the draft agreement this way, but they requested further negotiation and discussion to establish a partnering jurisdiction.
Last week, the commissioners made clear that while Caroline County has not completely abandoned the idea of a regional detention center, the commissioners are leaning toward not participating in the agreement and focusing on upgrades toward the facility within county limits. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Crime 
 
 406
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Videos showing the Tuesday assault at Easton High School have been circulating online. The incident involved three students and one staff member and ended with a student being transported to a hospital for non-life-threatening injuries.According to a press release released by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the assault happened on Tuesday afternoon. The videos paint a picture of the incident, though no further official statement has been released by law enforcement on the assault.
In the videos, a group of students are circling around the three students involved in the assault. Seconds into the video, one student in a black hoodie moves toward a student in a red hoodie and assaults him. The student in red falls to the floor. Immediately following, an additional student in a gray hoodie proceeds to join in the assault.
In the video, a male staff member in a white shirt attempts to protect the student that is being assaulted and physically puts his body on top of the student, seemingly to act as a barrier between the students.
The other two students seemingly continue to assault the student in red and begin to also assault the staff member. Soon after, other staff members intervene and separate the students and defuse the situation. The incident lasted around 30 seconds.
Deputies were able to identify two victims of the assault, one was an Easton High School staff member and the second was a student of the school. No identities have been released, and the incident is currently under investigation.
The assault resulted in one student being transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton via Talbot County Department of Emergency Services to be treated for non-life-threatening injuries, police said.
The two other students in the video were identified and arrested in relation to the assault.
According to a statement from Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools, the event is being evaluated and those involved will face appropriate disciplinary action.
"The safety of our students and staff is always our top priority. We are grateful for our partnership with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the presence of School Resource Officers in our schools," the statement said. "Deputy Horseman, along with several other Sheriff's deputies and members of the Easton High staff responded quickly to contain the incident. The students involved will face appropriate disciplinary action, and we are continuously evaluating safety measures to prevent or mitigate incidents of this nature."

title: Old mill to be demolished
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Old mill to be demolished

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 352
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following lengthy discussion and community considerations, the Centreville Town Council announced intentions to demolish the old mill building at 2647 Centreville Road.Presenting its findings of fact following a recent public hearing, the council on Aug. 7, identified the structure to be a dangerous building that poses a risk to public safety.
Presenting the demolition order, the council stated the property owner has 10 days from the Aug. 7 meeting to demolish the building and in the event of failing to do so, the town may cause the structure to be demolished.
It was also noted, in the first step to acquiring a search warrant for dangerous buildings, the council unanimously approved an ordinance to add a new related town code chapter.
State law requires a town code chapter be in place in order to get an administrative search warrant from a judge.
The town would then have to go to court and get a search warrant before entering the property. The intention is to allow inspectors onto property the town deems pose a public safety risk.
The now more permanent administrative search warrant ordinance is related to the emergency version issued earlier this year.
The ordinance's initial draft received considerable public outcry but no public comment was presented at the hearing.
"So that feels like a good sign," Council President Ashley Kaiser said.
The council has made significant progress in ordinance developments to make it more palatable but public education will be needed before initiating any type of robust enforcement, she said.
"I think it is a step in the right direction and puts us in line with a lot of towns around us," Kaiser said.
In other business, three applications have been received for the two chairs open in the council's upcoming October election.
The Ethics Board will review applications before considerations are brought to the Board of Supervisors of Elections.
Although currently on the ballot for re-election, Council Member Jim Beauchamp noted he intended to withdraw if both other candidates move forward.
Beauchamp has served off and on the council for 10 years, "It's been a good 10 years," he said.
The Centreville Town Council will next meet Sept. 4 at 7 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm
author: Natalie Jones
content:
After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm

 January 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 UPDATE 1:30 p.m. Tuesday: Impending heavy rains, gusty winds and flooding from the powerful storm system moving across the region have prompted local school districts to cancel after-school activities Tuesday, with delays and closures possible Wednesday.Dorchester County Public Schools are operating on a half-day dismissal schedule Tuesday, with all after-school activities canceled. All of the county's schools will be operating on a two-hour delay schedule Wednesday, Jan. 10, for evaluation of overnight flooding and storm damage, according to the school system.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools were also dismissed early Tuesday due to the storm. As of Tuesday afternoon, all of the county's schools are set to run on a 90-minute delayed opening Wednesday, with reevaluation and modifications possible in the morning.
Schools in Talbot and Caroline counties canceled all after-school activities Tuesday. Both districts are monitoring conditions to determine if delays or closures will be necessary Wednesday.
The Caroline County Board of Education meeting will be held as scheduled at 6 p.m. Tuesday.
Gov. Wes Moore enacted a State of Preparedness declaration Tuesday morning, directing the state's department of emergency management to coordinate responses to the storm's impacts.
Rainfall of 1 to 3 inches is possible across the region Tuesday, with the heaviest rain expected Tuesday night before tapering off Wednesday morning, according to the National Weather Service.
The main concern is the potential for coastal flooding in Talbot and Queen Anne's counties, said Mike Lee, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Philadelphia/Mount Holly office. Dorchester County is also expected to experience significant flooding.
A coastal flood warning is in effect from 7 p.m. Tuesday to 7 p.m. Wednesday for areas along the lower Chesapeake Bay, including Cambridge, which will see major impact from flooding early Wednesday morning, according to the Weather Service. Water is expected be two to three feet above ground level in some low-lying areas.
A coastal flood warning and a flood watch are in effect for Talbot, Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent counties from Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning.
Moderate coastal flooding is possible Tuesday with the high tide cycle. Water levels are expected to continue rising Tuesday night from strong southerly winds. The rising water levels could lead to potentially significant flooding.
The highest tides will be early Wednesday morning and again in the afternoon.
Widespread roadway flooding is expected across the region's bayside communities and along tidal waterways. Dorchester County could see road closures.
Strong, gusty winds are also expected to build across the region throughout the day Tuesday.
Dorchester County is under a high wind warning from 4 p.m. Tuesday to 4 a.m. Wednesday, with south to southeast winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 60 mph possible. Fallen trees, downed power lines and widespread power outages are expected.
Talbot, Caroline, Kent and Queen Anne's counties are under a wind advisory from 5 p.m. Tuesday to 3 a.m. Wednesday. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph are expected, with gusts up to 55 mph.
The already-saturated ground in the region has also made trees more vulnerable to becoming uprooted with strong winds.
The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services urged residents to make sure loose items are secured ahead of time and reminded residents to not drive through or stand in flooded roadways.
The region will dry out some on Thursday, but a second storm is likely to roll through the region again Friday night into Saturday, the Weather Service said.
This story has been updated to include information on school delays and closures. This story may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man arrested on 30 charges following vehicle pursuit
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Cambridge man arrested on 30 charges following vehicle pursuit

 July 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 266
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Cambridge man was arrested on 30 charges after fleeing a traffic stop and striking a house.Keizye Daijuon Collins, 27, was arrested on charges including first- and second-degree assault, driving on a suspended and revoked license, reckless driving and attempting to elude police by failing to stop.
According to a news release from the Cambridge Police Department, officers attempted to conduct a traffic stop on July 1 for a stop sign violation on Fairmount Avenue and High Street.
Police said that when the vehicle came to a stop in the area of High Street and Park Lane, Collins exited the vehicle. When an officer told Collins to return to the vehicle, Collins did so and fled the area "at a high rate of speed."
Police said that in the area of High Street, Collins "swerved" at a CPD patrol vehicle and the officer in the vehicle "had to make evasive maneuvers to avoid being struck."
Police said officers watched Collins turn down the 400 block of Charles Street and strike a house on Charles Street and Skinners Court while attempting to travel between houses. After that, police said Collins fled the scene on foot.
Collins was identified as the driver of the vehicle through investigation, according to the news release.
Police said Collins later contacted CPD, attempting to report his vehicle as stolen. When CPD requested that Collins come to the station and speak with officers, Collins refused and officers applied for charges on Collins.
On July 8, Collins was arrested on an arrest warrant. He was later turned over to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond.

title: Caroline Police Accountability Board reports progress
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Caroline Police Accountability Board reports progress

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 1030
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Police Accountability Board shared its second annual report with the County Commissioners at their Feb. 6 meeting.The bottom line: Of the thousands of contacts people had with county and town law enforcement officers, a handful of complaints were made, and a fraction of those resulted in disciplinary action.
Presenting the report were Police Accountability Board Chairman John Bartlett and Board Administrator Kimberly Raeder.
Bartlett said he wanted to make one "very important" point: The Caroline County Sheriff's Office had over 26,000 calls for service in 2023, which generated only six complaints, he said.
"Five of those six were exonerated, meaning unfounded, and one was a very minor infraction, which led to a written reprimand," he said. "I think that speaks volumes with law enforcement here in Caroline County."
A state mandate
Raeder explained the purpose and scope of the three police oversight boards mandated by the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, which became effective July 1, 2022.
The role of the county's Police Accountability Board "is to receive police complaints, recommend policy changes and identify any trends," Raeder said.
"The second board is the five-member Administrative Charging Committee, and their role is to look over and review completed complaint investigations and recommend discipline," she said. If the Charging Committee decides to administratively charge, they use the statewide police disciplinary matrix to "decide what kind of discipline would be necessary based on the complaint."
The five members of the Charging Committee were appointed and trained in April 2023 at the Fretterd Center by the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission.
The third board is the Trial Board comprised of retired Maryland Circuit Court Judge Owen Wise, a citizen and a police officer of the same rank, Raeder said. No complaints have been referred to this board.
"I'm proud to say that Caroline County is leading the way for other counties on the Eastern Shore who have reached out to us regarding using Judge Wise, if they need a judge for a trial board," she said.
Few complaints filed
Among the county's municipalities, 15 complaints were filed, including a pending complaint related to an April 7, 2023, incident in Denton that prompted millions of views on YouTube, Bartlett said.
A video of the incident shows Christopher Morgan threatening the residents and breaking the window of the storm door of a home while two Denton Police officers stand on the sidewalk watching.
The way the officers handled the call for service prompted Denton Police Chief George Bacorn to request the Talbot County Sheriff's Office to investigate the handling of the incident. Their findings were turned over to the Administrative Charging Committee.
There were no complaints from Ridgely or Greensboro. One was brought to the Police Accountability Board from Federalsburg, which was exonerated, Bartlett said.
The report breaks down the 15 complaints by percentages; numerically, four complaints are pending investigation, three were administratively charged, two were withdrawn by the complainant, four were exonerated and two were "not in the purview of the ACC (Administrative Charging Committee)."
The Accountability Board identified trends in the disciplinary process and didn't "recommend any changes at this time."
"A common identified trend, however, has been the lack of activation of body cameras when officers interact with the public," the report stated. "The ACC discovered this trend when reviewing completed complaint investigations which had no body camera footage for the ACC to review. The Board advised the municipal Police Departments and the Sheriff's Office to remind Officers to adhere to department policy and activate their cameras when encountering the public. The policy protects both the Officer and the Citizen if a complaint were to arise from the interaction."
Cost to the county
Bartlett thanked the commissioners for their "financial support of the committee for legal decisions when needed."
The boards' complying with the state mandates has incurred expenses for the county, although some have been covered by the Police Accountability, Community, and Transparency Grant program.
Of the $105,272 in grant funds received, the Accountability Board has spent $49,545, which includes the purchase of IAPro software for filing complaints, annual computer licensing for all board members, and pay for the Board's administrator.
The Police Accountability Board is asking the state to continue offering these grants, as well as other police-oriented grant programs for local police departments to be able to purchase "the required technology, resources, and tools to comply with the law," including software and a change in the vendor for body cameras, so that every law enforcement agency in the county has the same system.
Other costs included outside legal counsel, with expenses the County Commissioners agreed to fund to the tune of nearly $8,000.
Questions arose requiring legal clarification for both the Police Accountability Board and Administrative Charging Committee, and the county commissioners "agreed to bear the expense of hiring outside legal counsel" to represent both. "Legal Counsel attends each quarterly meeting and provides interpretation of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021 as needed," the report stated.
The legal expenses for the Police Accountability Board were $3,650, while those of the Administrative Charging Committee amounted to $4,300.
PAB recommendations
The Accountability Board recommends "changing ACC training from all in-person training to online meeting based or pre-recorded online training. With one member of our ACC board resigning this past July, we have firsthand knowledge of the burden imposed on the newly appointed volunteer Board member. As terms end or resignations occur, the pool of applicants will continue to shrink when advised that members must undergo uncompensated training prior to serving."
Another unanticipated result of the law has been the withdrawing of multiple complaints, which created a legal conundrum for the Accountability Board and is currently being resolved with the Office of the Attorney General.
The report also suggested amending the law by mandating only complaints of "matters of public concern," that is, "police misconduct, such as abuse of power, false arrest, police brutality, or criminal activity" be referred to the Charging Committee, thus alleviating pressure on municipal police departments. "Rude and discourteous" behavior towards a citizen would be handled at the department or agency level, as suggested by the Accountability Board.
To read the full report, which includes rosters of members of the PAB and ACC boards, visit carolinemd.org/DocumentCenter/View/8606/2023-Annual-Report-PAB?bidId=. The last page provides links to other documents and resources provided by the PAB. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: CASA of the Mid-Shore celebrates its volunteers
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
CASA of the Mid-Shore celebrates its volunteers

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 400
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Over appetizers, drinks and good conversation, CASA of the Mid-Shore thanked its volunteers Thursday with a special event at the Avalon Theatre in downtown Easton."The people who bring our mission to life are our CASA volunteers," Executive Director Robin Davenport said.
CASA of the Mid-Shore assigns volunteer court appointed special advocates in Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties to advocate for children who are considered to be at significant risk in their current homes and have been placed under court protection.
Advocates are tasked with identifying a child's needs and advocating for necessary services so those needs can be met.
During the celebration Thursday, Davenport shared a story of the impact volunteers can have on the children they advocate for. She said a retired volunteer, Sally, was at the doctor's office recently when she discovered her nurse was a child whose case she was appointed to a decade ago.
Davenport said Sally had never known if she had made a difference in the child's life. At the doctor's office that day, the now-nurse told Sally she got through high school and college because of what Sally said to her.
"And so we're here tonight because everyone in this room talks the talk and walks the walk," Davenport said. "And that is really important to us, but certainly to the future of the kids who we're working with."
Volunteer Geoff Searle said he got involved with CASA of the Mid-Shore in 2022 after retiring. He said social workers often have large caseloads, and CASA volunteers are able to focus solely on one child.
Larry Neviaser, who became a volunteer this year, said one of the things that drew him to the organization is its focus on finding the best outcome for every child.
"We don't represent anybody else except the child," he said.
Neviaser said he feels supported by CASA of the Mid-Shore's staff.
"They recognize the value of the volunteers, and (that) it really makes the organization," he said.
Along with being thanked and served up food and drink, CASA volunteers heard a presentation from author and speaker Frank Kros about making positive impacts on children that can last generations.
Weaving in stories about his own childhood, Kros talked about the mindset of children who have been through abuse and gave tips on how to encourage children.
"It's incredible what we can do when someone genuinely believes in us and provides us the support that we need," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: County says new paramedic station in Cordova will reduce wait times for residents
author: Konner Metz
content:
County says new paramedic station in Cordova will reduce wait times for residents

 October 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 347
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA — Talbot County officials and first responders broke ground Monday on a new EMS station intended to reduce ambulance wait times in the northern part of the county.The station, located in Cordova across from Chapel District Elementary School, is already taking shape. As site work begins and the station's main structure is erected, officials placed shovels in the dirt for a ceremonial groundbreaking.
Residents in Cordova and across northern Talbot County will reap the benefits of the station once it's completed, said Brian LeCates, director of the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services.
"We always try to make sure that we are to our calls within eight minutes, at least 95% of the time," LeCates said. "And this is an area that was underserved by that.
"The (Talbot County Council), they really took note of that. We gave them information. We gave them data."
Council members fully funded the $2.1 million project, which will be the county's sixth paramedic station. It will include space for a 24/7 paramedic and EMT unit.
Council President Chuck Callahan said the project comes at an important time as renovations are progressing at the elementary school across the street.
"It's kind of the perfect storm here when it comes to having safety, kids," Callahan said. "It makes the whole community feel a little bit safer."
Jimmy Eason, president of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association, said the station is welcomed "with open arms."
"Unfortunately for us in Cordova, we're facing almost a 100% failure to respond rate," Eason said. "But not to any fault of anybody's, it's just a sign of the times. So this station means so much more to this area than some people might believe."
Callahan thanked the Gannon family for giving a piece of their farmland up for the project. Siblings Greg and Celeste Gannon attended Monday's groundbreaking.
LeCates shouted out their mother, Sylvia Gannon, for her continued loyalty to Talbot County's EMS efforts. Gannon, a former County Council member, was a founding member of the Talbot Paramedic Foundation.
"Every step of the way, she always stepped up and tried to help us," LeCates said.

title: Be responsible on the water
author: Staff Writer
content:
Be responsible on the water

 May 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Summer is a great time to enjoy local waters. Whether you're a boater, angler or water sports enthusiast on the Eastern Shore, please remember to be responsible around the water. May 17-23 is National Safe Boating Week. The Safe Boating Campaign, led by the National Safe Boating Council, offers these tips for practicing social distancing and safety while boating:Wear a life jacket. No matter what activity you have planned on the water, always remember to wear a life jacket every time you are on the water. Accidents on the water can happen much too fast to reach and put on a stowed life jacket.Make sure your life jacket is U.S. Coast Guard approved, appropriate for your water activity and fits properly. A life jacket that is too large or too small can cause different situational problems.Know state boating laws. Rules and laws can differ from state to state and violations can result in ticketing, fines or jail time.Take a boating safety course.Learn valuable tips that can help save your life in unexpected situations.Make sure your boat is prepared. There are many items that need to be checked and rechecked on any boat. Schedule a vessel safety check with your local U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary or U.S. Power Squadrons before you hit the water. Every vessel safety check is conducted at no charge.Always file a float plan. File a float plan before you leave shore with someone you trust that includes details about the trip, boat, persons, towing or trailer vehicle, communication equipment, and emergency contacts.Check the weather, including the water temperature. Know the latest marine weather forecast prior to going out, and keep a regular check for changing conditions.Don't drink while you boat. Where the primary cause was known, alcohol was listed as a leading factor in boating-related deaths.Beware of carbon monoxide poisoning. Gasoline-powered engines on boats, including onboard generators, produce carbon monoxide (CO), a colorless and odorless gas that can poison or kill someone who breathes too much of it. Be sure to install and maintain a working CO detector, never block exhaust outlets, and always dock, beach or anchor at least 20 feet away from the nearest boat that is running a generator or engine.Keep in touch. Communication devices can be the most important piece of emergency equipment on board a vessel, especially in case of emergency. Be sure to have and know how to use at least two communication devices that work when wet, such as satellite phones, emergency position indicating radio beacons, VHF radios and personal locator beacons.
By following these tips, you can enjoy your boat, the water, sunshine and fresh air responsibly. For additional boating resources and tips, please visit SafeBoatingCampaign.com.
CAPT. BRETT M. SAUSE
USCG master licensed captain 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Telling the truth matters
author: Staff Writer
content:
Telling the truth matters

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 131
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Telling the truth matters. When people share accurate information, our community stays safe.The Dorchester County Republican Central Committee recently said protesters were being brought here on buses. That is not accurate. While some protesters come from other counties, most are local. They live here in Dorchester, mostly from Cambridge, which is a Democratic stronghold, or nearby places like Worcester and Talbot counties. They are Andy Harris's constituents, just like you.
Even more troubling are claims about threats of violence. No proof has been shown to support these claims. Sharing information that isn't true creates fear. This can hurt our community.
Everyone in Dorchester County deserves to feel safe. Democrats and Republicans alike have the right to peacefully speak and protest without fear. Telling the truth matters. It protects us all.
SYDNEY BRADNER-JACOBS
New Market

title: County buys mask testing system to keep firefighters safe
author: Staff Writer
content:
County buys mask testing system to keep firefighters safe

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 302
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Volunteer firefighters across Talbot County will soon benefit from new technology designed to keep them safer on the job.At a recent Fire Chiefs Committee meeting, fire chiefs gathered around their brand new AeroFit testing system, a device that delivers precise, OSHA-compliant fit tests for N95 respirators, elastomeric masks and other protective gear. The equipment, fully funded by the county, was purchased to reduce costs for local stations and increase safety for emergency responders.
Until now, fire companies had to pay for individual fit testing services, which added up in cost and required outside scheduling. With the new AeroFit system, once staff are trained, the tool can be used at any station, as well as other local emergency responders, to test firefighter masks, N95 respirators, gas masks and more.
This flexibility means the system will not only help volunteer fire departments but will strengthen readiness across all county emergency responders.
Properly fitted masks are essential for protecting firefighters and other emergency personnel from hazardous smoke, chemicals and airborne particulates. With AeroFit's advanced technology, firefighters will know their equipment is performing as intended before entering dangerous environments.
"Providing our firefighters with the right tools is critical," stated Jimmy Eason, President of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire & Rescue Association "With the county's support, this system ensures that every responder, whether volunteer, law enforcement, or emergency services staff, can be confident their protective equipment will keep them safe."
The purchase of the AeroFit system is part of Talbot County's ongoing investment in the safety of both residents and first responders. Each year, the county provides funding for the seven volunteer fire companies through its annual budget appropriation. Funding is distributed to each department by the Talbot County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association.
"This is about taking care of the people who take care of us," said council President Chuck Callahan. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Jury acquits man of all charges in fatal shooting
author: Carl Hamilton and Lilly Howard cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Jury acquits man of all charges in fatal shooting

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton and Lilly Howard cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 978
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Donald Raymond Snyder Jr. pulled a 9mm handgun from his waistband in the driveway of his Elkton-area residence at approximately 9:20 p.m. on June 17 and, from close range, he fired two shots into the upper torso of his friend, Christopher Cimorose, who was in the driver's seat of a red Nissan Versa.Snyder, 41, and his defense lawyers maintained during the two-day-long trial this week that he shot Cimorose — killing him — in self-defense because Cimorose, 55, had threatened, "I'm going to kill you, (expletive)," while a "metal pipe" was resting on his lap.
The prosecution, however, contended that Snyder gunned down Cimorose "in cold blood" because Snyder's 41-year-old girlfriend, Michelle McCarthy, was ending their relationship and that Cimorose — her former boyfriend — had come to Snyder's residence to pick her up at McCarthy's request.
On Thursday morning, the jury acquitted Snyder of first-degree murder, second-degree murder, voluntary manslaughter and the eight related charges after about four hours of deliberations.
As the forelady announced the not guilty verdicts, Snyder lowered his head and appeared emotional while standing beside his Timonium-based lawyer, Joshua Insley, at the defense table. Then they embraced for several seconds. Bruce Saller, who wasn't present, served as Insley's co-counsel at trial.
Snyder, who reiterated his self-defense account on the witness stand, was released from the Cecil County Detention Center on Thursday after his acquittal, court records indicate. Snyder had been incarcerated on no bond since his June 20 arrest.
Maryland State Police investigators elected not to charge Snyder after interviewing him in the hours after the shooting because they lacked probable cause and they let him go home.
But on June 20, after viewing security-camera footage of the incident in the drivefway of Snyder's Locust Point Road residence, south of Elkton, and re-interviewing the sole eyewitness, McCarthy, detectives charged him with murder and other offenses.
The pertinent part of that video was played for jurors.
"Thirteen seconds, in real time, you are going to see the intentional, premeditated killing of Mr. Cimorose," Cecil County State's Attorney James Dellmyer told jurors Wednesday during his closing argument. "This is evidence of first-degree murder. Chris (Cimorose) didn't stand a chance. That gun was on him before he got out of the car."
The footage starts with Snyder "briskly walking up" to the driver's side door and punching Cimorose in the face, according to Dellmyer, who prosecuted the case with Deputy State's Attorney Patricia Fitzgerald. State evidence included a photo of Snyder's right hand, which showed bruising on his knuckles, and a picture of an abrasion on Cimorose's forehead.
After the car lurches forward a few feet, Snyder pulls the handgun as he walks forward to the driver's side door, gets into a shooting stance and rapidly fires three shots at Cimorose, including one errant round, Dellmyer reviewed.
A person cannot be the aggressor and then claim self-defense, Dellmyer said. The video doesn't show Cimorose swinging the object or advancing, nor does it show Snyder retreating because of a perceived threat, he added.
"You cannot start a fistfight and then shoot someone to death," Dellmyer stressed, before asking, "Is it reasonable to use deadly force?"
McCarthy testified that Snyder hurled her cell phone, cracking the front, during a heated argument between the two shortly earlier that day and then alleged that Snyder, in anger, had broken five other cell phones of hers that year.
McCarthy told Snyder that she was leaving him during that dispute.
"I said, 'That's it. I'm done with you . . . I packed all my stuff in the car," McCarthy said.
But McCarthy could not legally drive her packed car because it lacked valid license plates — so she called Cimorose for a ride.
McCarthy testified that she was in the front passenger's seat of Cimorose's car when Snyder wordlessly sucker-punched Cimorose in the face and swiftly fired three shots. "I saw the punch. I saw everything," she said.
Insley, however, maintained that McCarthy wasn't a credible witness.
The defense lawyer proffered that the footage shows McCarthy outside Cimorose's car during the incident. Seconds earlier, McCarthy and Snyder had been inside her vehicle waiting for Cimorose to arrive.
Insley also reminded jurors that McCarthy admittedly never mentioned Snyder throwing a punch during her first interview with investigators. "I was covering a little bit for my boyfriend," McCarthy confessed on the witness stand.
Guilt prompted McCarthy to contact police on June 19 and set up a second interview, in which she told investigators that Snyder punched Cimorose without provocation before the shooting, she testified. McCarthy testified that she and Cimorose were no longer romantically involved.
When Insley asked McCarthy if she had asked the prosecution to dismiss two drug cases against her in exchange for her cooperation, she combatively responded, "Drugs has nothing to to do with this case."
Also during Insley's cross-examination, McCarthy confirmed that Cimorose was on probation in a criminal case for strangling her.
Insley reminded the jury during his closing argument Thursday that the autopsy report showed that Cimorose had methadone, cocaine and fentanyl and other drugs in his system at the time of his death.
"Ever smoke crack before," Ingsley rhetorically asked the jury, before remarking, "I heard it makes you pretty wacky."
The defense also took exception to the state's interpretation of what the shadowy footage showed. The state contended that Snyder lunged forward and punched Cimorose, but Insley insisted that a thrown punch is not visible in the video.
As for the object Cimorose purportedly possessed, Insley accused investigators of "sugar-coating" by using words like stick, pole and a table leg to describe it, so it wouldn't be associated with a weapon. Insley referred to the object as a club. It looked like a wooden cane with a section of metal where the handle should have been.
Snyder called 911; identified himself as the shooter; told the dispatcher he acted in self-defense and turned himself in after learning about the charges against him — all actions of an innocent man, according to Insley. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Kent Samaritan Group nears goal to open emergency shelter in December
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent Samaritan Group nears goal to open emergency shelter in December

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — On Sunday afternoon, the day of its fundraising rally at Presbyterian Church of Chestertown, the Samaritan Group of Kent County had $1,400 toward its goal of $14,000 needed to open the Emergency Winter Shelter, in operation since 2003.Because of Christ First United Methodist Church's $5,000 donation, along with other donations, at the end of the event that afternoon, the group had $12,000.
Shelter Director the Rev. James Diggs said they need donations and are optimistic to reach the goal, but they also need volunteers for the shelter: some cooks, but more importantly they need hosts and sleepers. The host, Diggs explained, meets and greets the guests, ensures they are comfortable and safe while the sleepers stay the whole night.
Diggs announced this year they are aiming to open the shelter in December, a first.
That is up to the amount of volunteers that sign up. Diggs said that they have to have 85% of December filled to accomplish this, with volunteers especially needed Christmas Eve, Christmas, New Year's Eve and New Year's.
"Let's make this month a recruiting month. Help us do it because I think we certainly can. We're excited to be able to add December and maybe next year, add another month."
As winter approaches, the need increases to care for Kent County's homeless population he stated.
As their mission describes, the Samaritan Group of Kent County work with local agencies, churches, businesses and organizations and individuals to keep them warm and also providing financial assistance.
During the rally with refreshments and ice cream served by Marcia Stoltzfus and family, Diggs listed the shelter's accomplishments and gave out certificates and awards to the hardworking, caring volunteers which make it possible each year, adding a fun family event along the fundraising.
In the early winter months of 2025, they served 21 clients, seven women, two children and 12 men, 661 bed nights total. In 2018 they served 21 people as well, 1,033 bed nights and that next year, 28 people and 921 bed nights.
"The number of people we serve is unpredictable. We just don't know from year to year. The point is to be ready and all of you volunteers make that possible."
He thanked some of the volunteers that helped get the shelter ready.
Receiving the Laverne and Shirley Award was dynamic duo Annie Woodall and Andrea Nieman. Top Chef, and also supplying that tasty soft serve ice cream was Marcia Stoltzfus and family. The Host with the Most was Allison Brieske and Volunteer of the Year, who dedicated time cooking/ inspiring her whole church to cook, and hosting, was Anne-Marie Walters.
Many other certificates given as well, some of whom were not in attendance.
"They may not be here, but they were when it counted," joked Diggs.
Giving her testimony about the rewards of volunteering was Melanie Keller, who was recruited by Woodall and Nieman years back and was the volunteer coordinator for a time.
Keller said that after her third child, part of what kept her volunteering was her two children who also volunteer. They play hide-and-seek with guests and see other people's experiences, their suffering and joys and practice reaching out with compassion.
"We are a community and I hope to see some of you as hosts," she told attendees.
Diggs said hosts have a very important role, stay from 5:30-10 p.m. and are in pairs. Diggs personally greets the hosts each night and briefs them on what they need to know, ensuring they are comfortable.
Sleepers stay into the night and see guests off in the morning.
Diggs encouraged the audience to not only sign up but to become recruits, sharing the joys of volunteering at the shelter where Mid-Shore Community Foundation, United Way of Kent County, the Good Neighbor Fund and Kent County Department of Social Services partner in this important mission.
"We need your help," Diggs said to the community. "With it we can open up in December...one month at a time."
To contact them go to: info@samaritangroupofkentcounty.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Queenstown man charged in Centreville shooting
author: Staff Writer
content:
Queenstown man charged in Centreville shooting

 January 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Crime 
 
 201
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Police have charged a 17-year-old male as an adult in connection with a weapons discharge incident Nov. 22 in the 100 block of Little Kidwell Avenue in Centreville.According to a statement released by the Centreville Police Department, a warrant was served on the young man at a Del Rhodes, Queenstown residence on Jan. 3 without incidence.
He was charged with attempted second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, possession of a regulated firearm under the age of 21, and use of a firearm during a felony or violent crime.
During a search of the residence, a handgun was seized as evidence.
Police Chief Robert Hobbs confirmed the suspect and victim were related. The victim, an adult male, sustained only superficial injuries from the incident. He was taken to the hospital and released the same evening, Hobbs said.
The man charged is being held pending trial. His name is not yet being released as investigation surrounding this incident continues.
Members of the Maryland State Police, Centreville Police Department, Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff, US Marshals Service, Queen Anne's County Narcotics Task Force, Maryland State Police Crime Lab as well as the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office are continuing the investigation.

title: Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A 17-year-old suspect has been charged in connection with a bomb threat that forced an evacuation at Easton High School Monday.In a social media post on Facebook, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office announced detectives located the residence of a 17-year-old female and charged her with "making a threat of mass violence." Police say she is not enrolled in the Talbot County Public Schools system.
Students and staff were evacuated out of EHS on Monday afternoon after the threat was made just after 2 p.m. Police say a caller contacted the front desk and "advised that there was a bomb inside of the school and hung up."
"The caller re-contacted the front desk staff a few minutes later and asked when dismissal was," the Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated.
Police stated EHS staff immediately notified the school resource officer of the threat, leading to a quick evacuation from the building. The sheriff's office said all students and staff were safely evacuated as of Monday afternoon.
Deputies responded to the school, and bomb-detecting K-9 teams searched the building and surrounding property. Once cleared, staff returned to the school building.
"I am so grateful for the outstanding work our Talbot Deputies, Easton Police Officers, and our Talbot County Department of Emergency Services Dispatchers performed today to identify the caller of the bomb threat," Sheriff Joe Gamble said in a release.
"Within two hours the suspect was identified, located and charged," he said. "The teachers and staff at Easton High worked tirelessly with law enforcement to make sure everyone was safe. We are so fortunate to have such dedicated professionals in our community who work very hard to keep our children safe."
Deputies are working with the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office and "will be seeking additional charges if applicable," the sheriff's office said.
At Monday's Easton Town Council meeting, Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello thanked staff and first responders who handled the situation on Monday.
"I want to offer my sincere thanks to the teachers and the staff, and the first responders who attended the bomb threat today at Easton High School," Abbatiello said. "You all were professional in caring for our children and put them first. In this day and age, you cannot be too careful."
Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020.
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Investigators looking into fatal crash in Easton
author: Staff Writer
content:
Investigators looking into fatal crash in Easton

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Crime 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General is investigating a fatal crash following an attempted traffic stop and pursuit that occurred in Easton Monday evening.The preliminary investigation revealed that just after 7 p.m., deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, in marked police cruisers, encountered a car in the area of westbound Route 50 and Dutchmans Lane, where they attempted to initiate a traffic stop.
The driver of the car did not stop and continued to drive on Route 50. The deputies pursued the vehicle for several minutes.
Officers from the Easton Police Department assisted during the pursuit, which ended several minutes later when the car being pursued crashed into a tree in the 8300 block of Black Dog Alley.
Four people were in the vehicle at the time of the crash, according to the investigation. Officers rendered aid to all occupants and EMS arrived on scene and began rendering medical aid.
The driver, a juvenile male, and the front seat passenger, an adult woman, were transported to a local hospital for treatment of serious injuries. The adult woman was later pronounced dead at the hospital, the attorney general's office said.
The two rear passengers, a juvenile male and an adult woman, were transported to an area hospital for treatment of serious injuries. The involved officers were equipped with body-worn cameras.
The Independent Investigations Division, with assistance from the Maryland State Police Crash Team, is investigating the circumstances leading up to the crash.
Anyone with information about this investigation is asked to contact 410-576-7070 or email at IID@oag.state.md.us. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline commissioners discuss plan for public safety after Ridgely police suspension
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Caroline commissioners discuss plan for public safety after Ridgely police suspension

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 216
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tuesday morning, the Commissioners of Caroline County shared its plan to maintain a safety system in Ridgely after the recent suspension of the Ridgely Police Department.According to a press release from the town, on March 13, the commissioners of Ridgely suspended the entire Ridgely police department with pay, effective immediately, pending an investigation by the Office of the Maryland State Prosecutor.
No reason for the investigation was immediately indicated.
According to the Ridgely Police Department website, six officers are employed by the department.
At their March 19 morning, the county commissioners shared their plan for a temporary agreement with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to provide public safety services for the citizens of Ridgely.
The commission explained that the Caroline County Sheriff's Office and the Maryland State Police would divide responsibilities for providing law enforcement to the town.
The sheriff's office will work one five-hour shift a day for seven days a week.
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office will lead half of 911 dispatch calls for the town, and every other call will go to the Maryland State Police.
The commissioners also agreed that Sheriff Donald Baker will secure warrants and firearms for the Ridgely police department. Baker will secure the front door of the Ridgely Police Department.
Caroline County's Police Accountability Board has a pending a case involving the Ridgely Police Department. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot County man charged for possessing, distributing child porn
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County man charged for possessing, distributing child porn

 March 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 181
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Talbot County man has been charged with the possession and distribution of child pornography.Jordan Cabrera, 20, was arrested March 2, according to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.
Cabrera, whose residence is listed under a Trappe address in court records, is charged with three separate child pornography counts: two counts of soliciting a minor to engage as a subject in child porn and one count of knowingly distributing child porn.
According to court records, the charges were filed by an ex-girlfriend of Cabrera's, who was underage at the time they dated from 2021 to 2023.
Cabrera allegedly obtained nude photos from the then-minor and distributed those photos on a messaging app called Telegram, court records state. The nude photos also surfaced on Instagram and Twitter, the ex-girlfriend alleged in charging documents.
She wrote they broke up in 2023, a month before she turned 18. She stated she was a minor in every nude photo and video, per court records.
Cabrera was initially held without bond before posting $1,500 bond March 3. A preliminary hearing is set for March 31.

title: Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In 2018, the state medical examiner ruled that Anton Black's death at the hands of police in Greensboro was an accident. An audit report released by the state attorney general's office Thursday says the cause of death should have been ruled a homicide.The recommendation, one of dozens, comes after a four-year review of cases from between 2003 and 2019, during which time former Medical Examiner Dr. David Fowler was in office. The audit ultimately evaluated 87 cases, reclassifying the cause of death from accidental, unknown or natural to homicide in 36 of them.
"The audit also validated concerns that bias may have affected death investigations in Maryland," Attorney General Anthony Brown said in a letter to Marylanders included with the report. "Addressing those concerns benefits everyone in our system of justice — including the vast majority of law enforcement professionals who perform their duties with integrity and deserve clear, consistent standards."
The audit, led by Towson University psychology professor Jeff Kukucka, began in 2021 after Fowler's testimony in the trial of Minneapolis Police Officer Derek Chauvin sparked outcry. Chauvin, who was convicted of murder for the 2020 death of George Floyd, knelt on Floyd's neck for up to nine minutes during an arrest.
During his testimony, Fowler, who was called as an expert witness, said Floyd's death could be attributed to causes other than police restraint, including "excited delirium," a term used to describe agitation and aggression related to mental health or substance abuse that has been disavowed by leading medical authorities. Over 450 medical experts co-signed a letter to former Maryland Attorney General Brian Frosh and others condemning Fowler's testimony.
"This audit marks the beginning of a long conversation — one that must be handled with honesty, delicacy, resolve, and deep consideration," Gov. Wes Moore said in a letter included in the Thursday report. Moore went on to highlight reforms in the medical examiner's office that have been underway for several years.
The 2023 settlement of a case brought by the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black and Black's family demanded changes including a policy addressing how medical examiners handle deaths in custody, including those involving law enforcement restraint, according to the ACLU of Maryland.
The policy incorporates and models guidelines from the National Association of Medical Examiners for determining how such deaths are investigated and how examiners determine causation.
On Sept. 15, 2018, Black, 19, and a 12-year-old family friend were walking around Greensboro when Black began pulling and dragging the child, who called out for help, garnering attention from onlookers that led to a 911 call.
A chase that ensued ended outside Black's home, where Greensboro Police Officer Thomas Webster IV, off-duty Ridgely Police Chief Gary Manos, Centreville Police Officer Dennis Lannon and a civilian pinned Black against a wooden handicap ramp for six minutes while handcuffing and shackling him.
Black, who had severe bipolar depression, stopped breathing and became unresponsive after being handcuffed and shackled. He was taken to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton, where he was pronounced dead that evening.
Fowler ruled Black's cause of death was a sudden cardiac event. A later examination by a Johns Hopkins University cardiologist determined asphyxiation was the cause. No one was charged in the incident.
For those who have advocated for change in the way in-custody deaths are handled by the state since Black's death, the report released Thursday marked a potential turning point.
"This 70-page independent report vindicates what family members and communities — mostly Black and Brown Marylanders — have been saying for decades: the truth. That the entire system has been complicit in making police-involved deaths seem inevitable," said ACLU of Maryland senior staff attorney Sonia Kumar, who led the team that litigated the 2023 settlement, in a statement Friday.
An executive order issued by Moore Thursday called for the attorney general and the state's attorney's office to examine whether any cases should be reopened for investigation as a result of the report's findings. The executive order also established a task force to examine the handling of in-custody deaths.
Star Democrat reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Counties and towns prepare for snow on the Mid-Shore this weekend
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Counties and towns prepare for snow on the Mid-Shore this weekend

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 531
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With snow in the forecast this Sunday and Monday, Mid-Shore towns and counties are making plans and readying their snow plows."Every storm is different and unique," Easton Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said. "But we feel that we're prepared and ready for the storm."
On Friday, the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services had a meeting with local towns to coordinate in preparation for the winter weather.
According to the National Weather Service forecast as of Friday afternoon, snow is likely to fall in Easton from Sunday night into Monday. The weather organization is expecting a "major winter storm" will bring snow and ice across the country, "from the Central Plains to the Mid-Atlantic" this weekend.
Sunday night, there is a 90% chance of precipitation in Easton with snow expected mainly after 1 a.m., according to the National Weather Service. On Monday, there is a 90% chance of precipitation in Easton with snow expected before 1 p.m. and then rain and snow likely. Monday night, there is a 50% chance of precipitation.
Talbot County Public Schools Communications Director Debbie Gardner said the district is monitoring the forecast to determine if closures will be necessary.
Dorchester County Emergency Management Division Director Jimmy Windsor said Dorchester County has warned all its departments of the predicted weather, including its Highway Division. He said the county's Highway Division is preparing its inclement weather plans.
Van Emburgh said on Friday that Easton was putting plows on the fronts of trucks and loading salt into the trucks that spread salt.
"And we have equipment that we're placing around town that we'll use to address alleys and some of the tighter spots that we plow," he said.
Windsor said it is important that residents make sure they take the usual winter preparedness precautions, such as making sure vehicles have gas in them. He said that residents who live in areas that are prone to power outages should make sure they have blankets and warm clothing in the event of an outage.
"And a supply of fresh water in case the power goes out and you're on well water and therefore you rely on the power for your water source," he said.
Van Emburgh said it's helpful if residents do not park their cars on main streets.
"When people park on the streets, we have to plow around the cars and sometimes that can — depending on how much snow we get — that can get tricky and then we plow the cars in," he said.
Van Emburgh also talked about the importance of not plowing snow from the sidewalks into the street.
"Because we then plow it back onto the sidewalk," he said, laughing. "It's just a battle. (Residents) plow it onto the street. We plow it back onto the sidewalk. And they get mad at us."
Van Emburgh said residents should plow snow off their sidewalks by starting in the center of the street and working toward a house or building so that the snow is plowed into a yard.
"Some properties don't have yards," he said. "But if you plow it out in the street, it's just going to get pushed back onto the sidewalk. So we ask that everything moves away from the center of the street."

title: Easton woman charged with placing swastikas on political signs
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton woman charged with placing swastikas on political signs

 May 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Friday, police charged an Easton woman for allegedly placing swastika stickers on political signs and town property ahead of Easton's recent election.Jennifer Cristaudo, 53, has been charged with 20 counts of using a hate symbol, three counts of malicious destruction of property and one count of defacing property in a race/religion crime. All counts are misdemeanors.
According to charging documents, Cristaudo allegedly placed six swastika stickers on political signs and 16 stickers with red lines through swastikas on town property, such as light poles and stop signs.
The six stickers placed on Gunsallus signs were all in "high-minority areas," according to charging documents prepared by Detective Cory Schuch.
"The placement of a hate symbol, such as a swastika on campaign signs in these areas is a clear indication that Cristaudo's motivation was to intimidate minority voters in the Town of Easton to not vote for Frank Gunsallus," charging documents stated.
Police say the placement of the stickers began in late March and continued through early May. The election was held May 6.
According to the Easton Police Department, on March 26, officers located three swastika stickers on Gunsallus signs. They reviewed surveillance video, which showed a woman driving a blue Subaru as the person placing the hate symbols.
On April 1, police discovered another defaced sign. April 28, officers found two more Gunsallus signs defaced near the Easton Amish Market.
Per charging documents, police later found 16 swastika stickers with red lines throughout town, with 10 reported on April 1 and 2, and six reported between April 30 and May 6.
According to court documents, a town official told police removing the stickers causes "permanent damage" to the signs, "rendering them unusable." The town's public works department estimated $21,000 in replacement costs.
In addition to video footage linking Cristaudo to the stickers, court documents state police found a "large roll of matching swastika stickers" in Cristaudo's residence.
Matching clothing and more stickers were found in her car, police said in charging documents.
During the campaign, Gunsallus and his then-opponent Don Abbatiello both spoke out against sign vandalism. Gunsallus told The Star Democrat in March that "these types of things shouldn't happen during a campaign."
"This act of hate has escalated the situation into a deeply troubling reality that demands our collective attention," Gunsallus wrote in a letter sent to The Star Democrat, local police and various local officials in March.
Rabbi Fred Scherlinder Dobb, interim rabbi for Temple B'Nai Israel and Satell Center for Jewish Life on the Eastern Shore, said he was "disappointed" but not "shocked" by the use of hate symbols.
"I would say Easton and Talbot County are mostly a wonderful refuge from some of that national division," he said. "But sadly, and maybe inevitably, pieces of that creep in."
Dobb said the placement of hate symbols is "utterly unacceptable" no matter the intent. "Full-on continental devastation and genocide — which is the ultimate Nazi legacy — needs to be reserved for issues far greater than Town Council," Dobb said.
Lt. Milton Orellana, special operations commander for the Easton Police Department, said Monday that the department had also received a report of a Ku Klux Klan hood being placed on a Gunsallus sign during the campaign. Police were not sure who was behind that incident.
Orellana said police are actively investigating both incidents. A preliminary hearing for Cristaudo is set for June 20.
Gunsallus declined to further comment on the situation, citing the ongoing investigation.
