title: Three graduate from Caroline County's Problem Solving Court
author: Tom McCall
content:
Three graduate from Caroline County's Problem Solving Court

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — In a celebratory event at the Circuit Court for Caroline County, Judge Heather Price presided over the May 10 graduation of three remarkable women.Through a yearlong Problem Solving Court program, they have taken a giant step forward to step out of the cycle of substance use disorder and incarceration.
"Being the problem solving court judge is sometimes a very difficult job, but it is also one of the most gratifying parts of the job. You will hear some success stories today," Price said.
The back row of the courtroom was packed with people supporting the graduates — Nichole Meredith, Samantha Mitchell and Carole Rawding. There were tearful testimonies to the power of this program. Love ones were showed the before and after pictures that marked the women's journey from the beginning of the program to the end.
Problem Solving Coordinator Michelle Bethke spoke to the journey these women have taken and she presented certificates and flowers.
Each graduate had a presenter. Meredith had lawyer Dana Boston, Mitchell had Whitely, and Rawding had Bethke.
There were lots of local dignitaries present, including Caroline County Commissioner Larry Porter, Sheriff Don Baker, Police Chief Geroge Bacorn and State's Attorney Sloan Franklin. Even Roger McKnight, MTU program administrator, was there.
From state to county to town, there was community supporting these women to break the cycle of addiction and incarceration.
"It is an achievement and we are sending our graduates back out into the world to do good things," Price said.
Price noted the rigor of the program. Collectively the three graduates had submitted 382 drug tests. They completed 313 treatments of either substance abuse disorder or mental health treatment. They had to complete 146.25 hours of community service.
Bethke went up to the podium and addressed the crowded court room.
"The Caroline County Problem Solving Court employs science-based best practices to provide a pathway to sobriety for participants with diagnosed substance use disorders utilizing a combination of therapy, counseling, mentoring, encouragement and discipline when necessary," Bethke said.
The program received a $200,000 grant from the Maryland Office of Problem Solving Courts through a sub grant of the Bureau of Justice Assistance, which helped provide the program's staffing.
A graduate from 2022's program, and keynote speaker at the May 10 graduation, is Whiteley.
"I am a recovering addict and alumni from the Problem Solving Court. The definition of recovery is the process of change for which individuals improve their health and wellness, live a self-directed life and strive," she said. "The mindset and thinking pattern I once had, I needed to give up in order to change. Today I am a strong worthy loving and lovable woman, mother and friend."
The next speaker was Meredith.
"My addiction had taken everything that I ever loved away from me. I lost custody of my kids. I lost the trust and respect of my family. When I looked into the mirror, I didn't even recognize the person staring back at me," Meredith said. "This program has saved my life. I have full custody of my kids now. My family and friends can depend on me."
The next to speak was Mitchell.
"Drug court has given me the resources I need when I need people," Mitchell said.
The final graduate, Rawding, was introduced by Bethke. Rawding was described as quiet and determined.
"I am just glad I accepted this program," Rawding said.

title: Talbot County Sheriff's Office to place cameras in patrol cars
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County Sheriff's Office to place cameras in patrol cars

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is planning to add cameras to its patrol vehicles, a move that Sheriff Joe Gamble said will increase transparency with the public.Earlier this month, Talbot County council members approved the purchase of 30 in-car cameras for $415,000, spread across a five-year period. Body-worn cameras have their limits, Gamble said, only showing the steering wheel during situations like police chases.
The sheriff said the in-car cameras have two main benefits.
"One, it's another level of transparency with the public," Gamble said. "And the other is evidence gathering."
But Gamble noted that a state investigation into a fatal police-involved chase last year factored into the decision.
"It definitely played a role in it," he said.
In July 2024, Talbot County deputies and an Easton police officer engaged in a pursuit of a vehicle on U.S. Route 50 in Easton after the driver failed to pull over for a traffic stop. Police reached speeds over 100 mph, and the chase ended with the vehicle crashing into a tree on Black Dog Alley. An 18-year-old passenger died.
The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Attorney General's Office reviewed the incident, as it does for all fatal police-involved chases statewide. Body-worn camera footage was eventually released in September. It wasn't until January when state investigators determined they wouldn't seek charges against any of the involved officers.
At the time, Gamble said it shouldn't have taken that long for the state to complete its investigation and clear his deputies. Now, the in-car cameras will better show the actions taken by vehicles being pursued by police, he argues.
"You couldn't see the egregious disregard for public safety by the driver in that car," Gamble said in an interview this week, referencing the limited view of the chase provided by body-worn cameras.
"It protects our deputies in the sense that, this is what they did," he added. "And if there's allegations they did something else, it's on footage."
Other sheriffs on the Eastern Shore concur with the effectiveness of the cameras.
Queen Anne's Sheriff Gary Hofmann said most patrol vehicles have had the in-car cameras for a few years. Complaints are down, and it's increased trust with the community, Hofmann says.
"It's been extremely beneficial for us to avoid any type of complaints or allegations," he said.
Dorchester Sheriff James Phillips said he would love for his agency to buy them, although cost is a problem — the in-car cameras are more expensive than body-worn ones.
In Caroline County, the vehicle cameras were purchased under a former sheriff, current Sheriff Donnie Baker noted. They are key in providing a better perspective for traffic stops and other incident, he said.
"I think that they make a good cop better," Baker said, "and they limit false reports."
Gamble said the Talbot County Sheriff's Office hopes to install all 30 in-car cameras by 2026. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 4 plead guilty to varying misdemeanors in 2024 Kohl's incident
author: Konner Metz
content:
4 plead guilty to varying misdemeanors in 2024 Kohl's incident

 July 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Four people have pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges in connection to an incident in the Easton Kohl's parking lot last year.Raven Todd, 24, of Laurel, Delaware, entered a guilty plea on June 26 to reckless endangerment and loaded handgun in vehicle charges. The state is not prosecuting previously levied charges against Todd for attempted murder and assault.
Todd was the last of four people to enter pleas for an incident that occurred in April 2024. Three others accused of assaulting Todd during the incident — 21-year-old Tucker Eason, 19-year-old Blake Dorman and 18-year-old Navelie White — have pleaded guilty to assault charges. They were each handed sentences that they are currently serving.
The incident occurred in the parking lot of the Kohl's on April 16, 2024. The Easton Police Department said Todd fired a gun after an assault took place, according to a press release from when Todd was arrested in October 2024. Police spoke with a person whose truck had been hit by a bullet, allegedly from Todd's handgun.
According to police, Todd told them that while in the parking lot that day, Eason hit him on the head with a beer bottle. Another person had a tire iron, Todd told authorities. Todd also told police he was punched several times.
Detectives interviewed a witness who identified Eason, Dorman and White as the people who attacked Todd.
At the time, Easton police said video showed the attack during which Todd fired his gun after the assault ended with people fleeing the area.
On June 26, Judge Philip Cronan sentenced Todd to one year for reckless endangerment with the full term suspended, and two years for the handgun charge with all but 212 days suspended. Todd was credited with 212 days served dating back to last November. Cronan ordered Todd to serve two years on probation and perform community service, among other conditions.
White, of Easton, entered an Alford plea for first-degree assault on March 21. He was sentenced to eight years with all but 18 months suspended, dating back to January.
Eason, of Easton, pleaded guilty in December 2024 to second-degree assault and was sentenced to a three-year term with all but 18 months suspended. The 18 months date back to October 2024.
Dorman, of St. Michaels, pleaded guilty on June 4 to second-degree assault and rioting. A three-year sentence for the rioting was fully suspended. For the assault count, Cronan delivered a three-year sentence with all but 18 months suspended, dating to June 3.

 EASTON - A Henderson man was arrested Tuesday on a grand jury indictment for manslaughter and narcotic distribution in connection to an overdose death last September.Detectives from the Easton Police Department announced the arrest of 35-year-old Justin A. Bodman, who is charged with manslaughter, distribution and possession with the intent to distribute narcotics, distribution and possession with intent to distribute fentanyl or heroin, possession of a controlled dangerous substance, reckless endangerment and conspiracy.Police also announced that Elina Lazarieva, 23, of Easton was arrested in Baltimore on Aug. 2 on similar charges.The charges stem from the duo's alleged involvement in an overdose death in Easton.Easton officers were dispatched to the 100 block of Prospect Avenue on Sept. 5, 2022, for an unresponsive man.Talbot County paramedics also responded and pronounced the man, identified as 28-year-old Cristian Gonzales, dead.Easton police's criminal investigation division initiated an investigation, learning that Lazarieva had met with Bodman for the purpose of obtaining controlled dangerous substances.Police said Lazarieva contacted Bodman and the two traveled to Delaware to obtain heroin.After obtaining the heroin, the two traveled back to Easton and delivered the drug to Gonzales, who later overdosed, police said.Both Bodman and Lazarieva were turned over to the Talbot County Detention Center following their arrests.Lazarieva was released on bond Sept. 12, according to online court records. Her case is scheduled for a jury trial in Talbot County Circuit Court in early January.

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
'End of Watch'

 February 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 786
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE— As evening fell, the American flag proudly waved high up between ladder trucks welcoming the community to come, honor, and remember their fallen heroes. A date remembered and honored by many in Queen Anne's County for the last 22 years the Fallen Heroes Memorial continues to be observed Feb. 13. Hosted by Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 108, the location has varied through the years but was held this year at the Centreville United Methodist Church.The event began with the Pledge of Allegiance and a moment of silence led by Sheriff Gary Hoffman. Senior Pastor Rev. Karen Handy of Centreville Methodist Church welcomed and addressed families, friends, and community members.
Chase Armington, past president of Lodge 108 and current Queen Anne's County deputy, began, "Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes. It is our duty to never forget them, for they have paved the path forward with their lives. The path leading us here tonight was born from tragedy. Incredible losses. Unbearable pain for our families, friends, and the community. These honored in front of you served our community with pride, dignity, and honor. Knowing their lives could, at any moment be taken, so that we may live. So that we may continue on the path they have now paved."
The event started from tragedy, continues years later as a way to honor and remember those who have unselfishly given their lives for others. Sue Nickerson, who lost her son, Centreville Police Officer Michael Nickerson, in 2001 explains, "The FOP from QAC started [this event] and they will always have it on February 13th, the night that Michael [Nickerson] and Jason [Schwenz, Queen Anne's County deputy] were killed. But, it's to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne's County."
Nickerson is the Maryland Concerns of Police Survivors (COPS) Director.
As a mother who lost her son, this event is near to her heart. Nickerson said, "It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters, and our EMTs have done. It is very much appreciated."
First responders marched in for the Presentation of Colors, holding flags to honor those lost in the line of duty. Queen Anne's County State's Attorney, Lance Richardson, spoke about stoicism and how it applies here. "The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us. We don't have any control over that. But what we do have control over is how we respond to it, how we react, how we pick up the pieces and go on. Stoicism also places an emphasis on appreciating the unity and precious gift of life."
Richardson went on to quote the Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius, "When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive — to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love." Applying this quote, Richardson said, "So, tonight, we honor those who gave the ultimate sacrifice, their lives, so we could go on living our lives in peace and safety." He ended by encouraging all to 'earn this.' "We must continue to honor these brothers and sisters, live a life that would be a testament to their memory, and continue to do God's will and God's work."
During this powerful remembrance, family members came, first responder representatives saluted, and all placed long-stemmed red roses by the framed photographs. The names of the fallen heroes were read along with the date of their End of Watch. Ten Queen Anne's County residents and fallen heroes' pictures filled the front table: Queen Anne's-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company's Daniel Lister, Sudlersville Volunteer Fire Company''s "Buck" Clough, Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department's "Dougie" Thomas, United Community Volunteer Fire Department''s David Brinkley, Centreville Police Department's Michael Nickerson, QA Sheriff's Deputy Jason Schwenz, DNR Warden Charles Rider, and Maryland State Police troopers Thomas Noyle, Philip Russ, and Wallace Mowbray.
Radio transmission echoed for all to hear to mark the ultimate sacrifice given on that fateful Feb. 13, 2001, "Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland. May their dedication and sacrifice never be forgotten and may they rest in eternal peace." Bagpipes played 'Amazing Grace' from the balcony overhead. Silence filled every space of the church.
Handy closed, "Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others. Lord, mend those hearts that are broken in the loss of these loved ones. Lord, we pray that this memorial tonight has brought a bit of peace. Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons. We thank you and pray for those that they have left behind." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Flooding was prevalent as the remnants of Hurricane Debby hit the Eastern Shore Friday morning, with communities bracing for unusually high tides later that day."We've gotten a report on email from Emergency Management. It's been minor flooding so far," said Rescue Fire Company Chief Adam Pritchett Friday afternoon. "I believe the high tides are expected to be tonight of concern for Cambridge. But as of right now, it's been minor flooding so far."
The Town of Oxford warned residents that higher-than-expected tides could cause further flooding in the area Friday evening.
"Please be aware that the NOAA prediction for this evening's high tide has changed significantly and is now anticipated to be 4.5 feet, which could produce major flooding," the town said in an email to residents Friday afternoon. "By comparison, this morning's high tide that resulted in flooding throughout the town registered as a 3.9-foot tide at the Cambridge marker. With a 4.5-foot tide, the Causeway area will be impassable for a period of time."
Debby was downgraded to a tropical depression late Thursday afternoon, and was a post-tropical cyclone on Friday, the National Hurricane Center said. It made landfall early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida as a category 1 hurricane. Then, Debby made a second landfall early Thursday in South Carolina as a tropical storm.
Pritchett said his department was ready to help with any impacts from Friday evening's tides.
"We pretty much stay at a ready pace for things like this because it's becoming more normal all the time now with each storm that passes on," he said. "So we're kind of always ready for events like this. Have our equipment ready, checked out and so forth."

title: Queen Anne-Hilsboro firefighters honored for service
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Queen Anne-Hilsboro firefighters honored for service

 February 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE — The Queen Anne-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company awards banquet filled the fire hall on Feb. 10 with formal firefighter attire and fancy dresses.There were simmering meatballs as appetizers and flowers at every table as Fire Company President Phil Starkey Jr. emceed the evening. Around 100 people attended the affair to celebrate their firefighters' volunteer efforts.
Johnny Mautz, Maryland state senator, handed out years of service awards.
"You work hard all year. You get to celebrate one day, so I want to give you something back. We have years of service awards for U.S. Senate, Congress and the governor's office, from your state Senate office and your House of Delegates office," Mautz said.
He spoke on the value of emergency services to the community.
"The general public has no idea of the value and the service that is provided by all of our emergency volunteers. There are some paid paramedics. I get it. But it is a package deal, and we are so deeply grateful for this volunteer network. For everything you sacrifice, everything you give, all the time and your family commitments. I say it from the heart. Thank you for all you do," Mautz said.
Starkey recognized the adjacent fire companies, like Oxford, Greensboro, St. Michaels, Cordova and Easton, that respond to help fight fires in Queen Anne.
Then it was time for a litany of awards. There were membership awards, active service awards, fire awards, EMS awards, administrative awards, the President's Award and the installation of officers.
Awards from the chief included Firefighter of the Year Eric Voorhees and Officer of the Year Donnie Clark. There were two winners the Chief Award — Chris Kintop and Grady Motter.
The EMS awards included Chris Kintop, Tina Kintop, Eric Voorhees and Brandon Stiles. The Administrative Person of the Year is Dawn Starkey. The President's Award went to Nancy Baker, Jack Carson, Kenny Hope, Stephanie McNeal, Barbie Utz and Stacy Voorhees.
There were six top responders who were recognized: Donnie Clark, Kenny Hope, Chad Chaires, Eric Voorhees, William Townsend and the No. 1 responder was David Chaires.
At the end of the ceremony, Talbot County Council members Pete Lesher and Lynn Mielke presented the Queen Anne Hillsboro firehouse with a check for $37,088. Mielke said this was a third of their annual allotment.
Lesher said, "You serve three counties here, which is a big lift. It takes money to provide this protection, and Talbot County remains committed to paying for our part of what you do."
Before the tables were moved and the DJ could be brought in, there was a video highlighting all the fires the department responded to and emergency services that they provided throughout the year. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: EMS team coordination astonishing
author: Staff Writer
content:
EMS team coordination astonishing

 January 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 184
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thank God I live in Easton.The Monday evening of the snowstorm, I called 911 because my wife was experiencing a medical emergency. The 911 operator listened, gave me directions, kept me calm and told me that the medical team was on its way. Within 15 minutes of the call, the crew arrived. I call it a crew because at least two trucks from the Easton fire department accompanied the ambulance.
The fire department members shoveled the snow off the entrance to my house within a matter of minutes to give a safer passageway for the EMS crew. The EMS crew handled my wife's situation quickly and efficiently, moved her to the ambulance for transport to the emergency room. They kept apologizing for bringing snow into the house — the least of my concerns.
The entire team put themselves at risk to help us. The quickness of their response, especially considering the weather, was amazing. The coordination among the team was astonishing.
Again, I thank God for those who dedicate themselves to the well-being of our Easton community. By the way, my wife is doing OK.
BILL MOCARSKY
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Federalsburg man arrested after fleeing police
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Federalsburg man arrested after fleeing police

 May 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 267
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Federalsburg man who was wanted by Cambridge Police for attempted murder and assault was arrested Wednesday after fleeing Talbot County Sheriff's deputies.Adrian Jerrod Jenkins, 29, was charged with possession of a controlled substance, intent to distribute heroin/fentanyl, fleeing and eluding, driving without a license and other traffic violations, according to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.
The release said Jenkins was driving east on Ocean Gateway in the Trappe area when deputies attempted to stop him for moving violations. Police said deputies also determined Jenkins' vehicle registration was suspended.
According to the news release, Jenkins accelerated in an attempt to elude deputies. He traveled into Dorchester County, where the Talbot deputies were joined in the pursuit by Dorchester County Sheriff's Office deputies.
In Cambridge, Jenkins lost control of his vehicle, hitting a retaining wall and disabling his vehicle on Academy Street near Cedar Street, police said.
Police said upon taking Jenkins into custody, they discovered through a records check that he was wanted for attempted murder and assault stemming from charges in September of 2023. At the time of those charges, Jenkins was on probation for a second degree assault conviction in 2022.
Jenkins was taken to the Talbot County Central Booking Center. Police said he was held pending further court action.
Jenkins is scheduled for a hearing in Talbot County for traffic violations and drug possession, and on a subsequent date for violation of probation. He is also scheduled for a June hearing in Dorchester County on the attempted murder charge.
The Cambridge Police Department, along with the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office assisted in the incident.

title: Dorchester County may need to add to detention center
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Dorchester County may need to add to detention center

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County detention center is struggling to keep up with increases in the number of juveniles incarcerated and may ask for money to build a new wing to house the young offenders.During a Tuesday County Council meeting, council members decided to prioritize the topic for the upcoming Maryland General Assembly legislative session.
During a final discussion on priorities for the legislative session, Councilmember Mike Detmer, talked about what he described as his "juvenile crime concern."
In his comments, Detmer said juvenile crime in Dorchester County has been on the rise and the crimes being committed are more than simply jaywalking.
"It's absolutely insane that we have so many people that have had direct and directly affected by this, multiple people in this room directly affected by juvenile crime," Detmer said. "And it's unbelievable that in 2024 that we can be in a place of all the resources and all the talent we have that are wearing badges, that we can be in a place where we're held hostage by ostensibly well intentioned laws."
Detmer pleaded with council to put emphasis on juvenile crime for the Maryland General Assembly legislative session. He reminded the council of stories he shared on juvenile crime during previous meetings including children as young as 10 with guns and speeding cars on U.S. Route 50 and state Route 16 by underage drivers.
"There are kids that are still kids on paper," Detmer said. "(But) they're not acting like children."
Council President George Pfeffer, said the topic is on the list and there's no priority on the list created. Pfeffer described the topics on the list as "equally important to us" and said they will emphasize the importance of those topics once there is a legislator in front of them.
The list will be discussed with the local contingent of state delegates and senators.
Later on in the meeting Councilmember Ricky Travers, added that he agreed with Detmer and said he had issue with the way the juvenile justice system functions and said the system is "setting up a whole group of young kids for failure."
During public comment, detention center Warden Don Satterfield shared that over the last two months the detention center has had seven juveniles waiting for adult status.
Satterfield said because the state of Maryland has passed laws stating that juveniles must be housed separately by "vision and audio," those regulations have created a difficult barrier with the increase of juveniles being sent to adult detention centers.
Satterfield shared that the current detention center is almost 34 years old and is not designed to accommodate increased numbers of juveniles.
"Unfortunately, I'm going to be coming before you to add a wing (to the center)," Satterfield said. "That's where we are with this. We are already in violation of the law because of the audio part, and every other facility in the states is pretty much the same way. But this is where we are with the juvenile situation, and I don't see it concluding. And they are, quite frankly, they're a holy terror."
After hearing comment from Satterfield, Pfeffers suggested in addition to the rise in juvenile crime, that they discuss the restrictions placed on detention centers could possibly force the county to build another wing to the detention facility.
The council unanimously agreed to add the topics to the county's legislative priorities.
Dorchester is not the only county facing questions of outdated detention centers. Earlier this week, Caroline County commissioners discussed plans to join with Queen Anne's and Kent counties to build a new center, in part to deal with the increase in juvenile inmates.
In a March article in The Star Democrat, Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd talked about the growing challenge of juvenile crime in Dorchester County's largest city.
"Through investigation and statistical analysis, we have determined that the overwhelming suspect profiles for these crimes are male juveniles under the age of 16," according to a Cambridge police report. "But we have detained suspects as young as 11 for stealing vehicles in Cambridge."
According to the report, there is one 12-year-old who has been arrested for vehicle theft 11 times in the past three years. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Adams brings experience, potential K-9 to Greensboro Police Department
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Adams brings experience, potential K-9 to Greensboro Police Department

 March 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 446
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Sgt. Jeff Adams chose the Greensboro Police Department as his next endeavor because of his great relationship with Police Chief Lenox Trams."I was looking at different agencies but I reached out the chief. Chief and I go back to 2005 or 2006," Adams said. "I didn't know if I wanted to come here or not. We just had a brief conversation, then I came and did an interview and instantly fell in love. Ever since talking to him and doing a ride along, I was pretty much sold."
Adams, originally from New Jersey, came to the Eastern Shore in 2004 after his career in the military. Adams served in the Navy and in the Army Reserve.
A friend talked to him about coming down to the Eastern Shore and pursing law enforcement as a career.
Adams started his career in law enforcement in dispatch at Easton Police Department for one year. Then Adams moved to the Federalsburg Police Department, where he served for the past 17 years.
While Adams and Trams' long relationship played a big part in his decision to pick Greensboro as his next stop, Adams' residence in Greensboro played a big part as well.
"I think the people here are very nice," Adams said. "They're genuine, and it just seem like a really good fit after we went for a ride along. Just the environment alone was was good enough."
Adams wants residents to know if they ever cross paths with him, he is a easy officer to work with.
"I'm easy going," Adams said. "So what you see is what you get. I think Chief can attest to that, but I'm just laid back, professional, polite and kind. Hopefully we'll be community-oriented. We're just trying to make our interactions are police-public friendly."
Adams brings a potential coworker with him to the department. His K-9 Mosley has been with him since 2017.
Mosley has experienced cancer, but Adams says she is still able to work as a K-9 dog.
"She's done everything," Adams said. "She's already certified in tracking and narcotics. Now we took off the tracking because she lost her leg to cancer in Halloween of 2023. She went through chemo, radiation, and she's she's still working. She's did awesome with the training last Wednesday, she nailed it."
While Mosley hasn't officially joined the force yet, Trams and Adams expect for her to be apart of the team very soon.
"We're really excited to be able to bring her on," Trams said. "We're going through our budget cycle, and we put the K-9 program in the budget so the Town Council has to approve it. Hopefully we'll get the thumps up and then she can start working because we need one."

title: Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After a threatening social media post on Friday was determined to not be a threat to Easton schools, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating another threat that has been circulating on social media.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, is not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. He said the threat is a photo of a "clearly" photoshopped Instagram message that includes the 410 area code.
"We're taking it very seriously, as we do every threat," Gamble said, adding that, through investigation, the Sheriff's Office doesn't think there is "any viable threat to the safety" of TCPS students.
According to a letter from the district addressed to TCPS families, the district is "closely monitoring the situation" and working with local authorities. The letter says that school operations will continue as normal.
Gamble said a criminal investigation by the Sheriff's Office is underway. He said all school resource officers in the district are aware of the threat, and extra deputies are patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
Gamble said the Sheriff's officer is aware of jurisdictions in other states that "have had 40 or 50 of these types of threats."
"It's happening all over our country where, for whatever reason, somebody is trying to disrupt school operations and put our kids in fear," he said.
Gamble said that a few years back, the district experienced something similar where about half a dozen non-specific threats were made during the course of the school year. He said he would expect to see more of these threats this year.
"This just seems like the thing to do these days for some reason," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton Man Gets 18 Years For Enticing Child For Sexual Activity
content:
Easton Man Gets 18 Years For Enticing Child For Sexual Activity

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: B2 | Section: News 
 
 553
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE - An Easton man was sentenced Wednesday to 18 years in federal prison for attempted coercion and enticement of a minor to engage in illicit sexual activity.U.S. District Judge George L. Russell III handed down the prison term to Samuel Charles Hardeman, 55. His prison term will be followed by lifetime supervised release.
Hardeman had a previous federal conviction in a 2002 case in the Northern District of Georgia for use of a computer to entice a child to engage in sexual activity, for which he was sentenced to 174 months in prison.
Upon his release from prison, Hardeman must continue to register as a sex offender in the places where he resides, where he is an employee and where he is a student, under the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act, per the judge's order.
The sentence was announced by United States Attorney for the District of Maryland Erek L. Barron, Acting Special Agent in Charge R. Joseph Rothrock of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Baltimore Field Office and Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble.
According to the guilty plea, from Dec. 11, 2022, through Dec. 26, 2022, Hardeman engaged in conversations with an undercover law enforcement officer who purported to have a 10-year-old daughter.
During the conversations, Hardeman expressed how he wanted to have sex with the 10-year-old, sent a video containing child pornography to the undercover officer and made plans to drive to New York, where the undercover officer purportedly lived, to have sex with the 10-year-old.
Hardeman communicated with the undercover officer by phone via video call, text and through the use of encrypted messaging platforms.
The Maryland U.S.
Attorney's Office said the conversations occurred while Hardeman was on the sex offender registration for a previous federal sex offense conviction.
During a call on Dec. 26, 2022, Hardeman expressed hesitation about traveling to New York to visit the undercover officer and her daughter. The officer did not hear from Hardeman after that time.
On March 14, 2023, a federal search warrant was executed at Hardeman's residence, where several electronic devices were seized.
A forensic examination of one of the phones revealed the encrypted messaging account which Hardeman used to communicate with the undercover officer, a text message thread between Hardeman and the officer, photos sent to Hardeman by the officer at Hardeman's request, the photos and videos that Hardeman sent to the officer and dozens of images and videos depicting minors engaged in sexually explicit conduct.
Forensic examinations of several other devices and Hardeman's cloud storage account recovered additional images of child sex abuse material, including bestiality.
This case was brought as part of Project Safe Childhood, a nationwide initiative launched in May 2006 by the Department of Justice to combat the growing epidemic of child sexual exploitation and abuse.
Led by the United States Attorney's Offices and the Criminal Division's Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section, Project Safe Childhood marshals federal, state, and local resources to locate, apprehend, and prosecute individuals who sexually exploit children and to identify and rescue victims.
For more information about Project Safe Childhood, visit justice.gov/psc. For more information about Internet safety education, visit justice. gov/psc and click on the "Resources" tab on the left of the page.
Barron commended the FBI and the Talbot County Sheriff 's Office for their work in the investigation.
Barron thanked Assistant U.S. Attorneys Spencer Todd and Paul E. Budlow, who prosecuted the federal case. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Stevensville man charged with sexual solicitation of minor
author: Staff Writer
content:
Stevensville man charged with sexual solicitation of minor

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 185
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Antonio Blaine Nicely, 20, of Stevensville, was arrested Tuesday, March 5, by the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office on charges of sexual solicitation of a minor and obscene telephone misuse.After an investigation involving numerous interviews, multiple search warrants and suspect identification, an arrest warrant was secured by the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff Criminal Investigation Unit, according to a report from the sheriff's office.
Deputy First Class Zane Doyle served the arrest warrant. Nicely was later released on his own recognizance on Wednesday.
"This arrest underscores our unwavering commitment to protecting our community's most vulnerable," Sheriff Gary Hofmann said in a statement. "We commend the diligent efforts of our criminal investigation unit for their unwavering commitment and tireless work."
Officials with the sheriff's office said the ongoing investigation does not allow the release of specifics surrounding the case at this time. However, parents are encouraged to be always be mindful of their young children's device use.
Anyone with information related to the case or wishes to report similar incidents involving the suspect should contact Detective Chase Armington at carmington@qac.org or call 410-758-0770, ext. 1938.

title: Easton Elks Veterans Affairs Committee hosts a USO dance
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Easton Elks Veterans Affairs Committee hosts a USO dance

 December 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Saturday evening, Bridget O'Brien, 2024 Miss Maryland, opened the dance floor at Easton Elks Lodge by singing the "Star Spangled Banner." Couples, of all ages, gathered on the dance floor under USO military-themed decorations for a benefit in honor of disabled veterans.In an effort to provide continued care for disabled veterans at Pleasant Day Adult Day Care in Cambridge, the Easton Elks 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee hosted a USO event in an effort to raise funds for disabled veterans. Over a hundred people attended the event that included dancing, food, a silent auction and a raffle.
Michael Feehley, chair of the 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee and a lead planner for the event, said the committee believes in doing what they can to provide for those veterans in need and this event was a way to raise funds for veterans that are often overlooked.
"We believe in taking care of veterans, the veterans that use services at Pleasant Day, whether it's just for two meals, whether it's for medications, whether it's to meet with medical people, whether it's transportation to their medical appointments, they're only funded for two days a week through (Veteran Affairs), we feel it's necessary to fund those guys for five days," Feehley said.
Throughout the event, veterans were honored by attendees and volunteers but also by potential new recruits. Feehley said Easton High School's Navy Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps members assisted in functions such as drawing tickets, helping people to their seats and any assistance needed including putting away chairs at the end of the evening.
Tom Carlson, Vietnam veteran and member of the Easton Elks 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee, said the event provided him the opportunity to be around more veterans and talk about their experiences between enjoying the music and dancing.
Carlson said he was surprised by the enjoyment of the guests when it came to the music being played. Guests of a variety of ages were in attendance that evening singing along to songs of Carlson's youth and flooding the dance floor.
"It wasn't just people in their 60s and 70s and 80s. There were a lot of people in their 20s and 30s, and they had a great time too," Carlson said. "It's amazing that some of these youngsters really knew the music. They know our songs that we grew up with."
Feehley said he was proud of the ability to organize an event to honor veterans in the area, and he advises anyone who comes across a veteran to take the time to honor them even in the smallest ways.
"When you see that Army hat or the Coast Guard bumper sticker on the back of a car, or anything that says, 'Hey, I was in the service,' say, 'Thank you for your service.'"
"Because that veteran, the person who wears that hat, or the person who drives that car, they gave an awful lot of themselves," Feehley said. "They took time away from their families, away from home, in some but not all cases, they put themselves in danger, so you and I can do what we do today, and who are we not to give back to those people."

title: Easton airport runway closed for construction work
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Easton airport runway closed for construction work

 March 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 184
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — One of the runways at Easton Airport has been temporarily closed. As you drive by, you can see a large glowing X that alerts pilots not to land there.This is due to the construction phase of the Airport Modernization Program.
"Those are an added safety feature anytime we have the runway closed," said Micah Risher, airport manager. "Runway 4/22 is closed. The Xs are out there as a reminder for pilots from the air. They can see them very clearly flashing, and they know not to land on the runway."
The airport has gone to further lengths for extra layers of safety.
"In addition, we have physically turned off the instrument landing system for Runway 4/22, so pilots cannot inadvertently receive the landing data," Risher said. "We have got some barricades out there. We have turned off other visual aids for that runway."
There is another runway in use while 4/22 is closed until April 9.
"We have a second runway, 15/33, that is still operational," he said.
4/22 will be closed for a month, then will reopen for a month before being closed again for construction. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Officials emphasize firework safety ahead of July 4
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Officials emphasize firework safety ahead of July 4

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 275
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Fourth of July is right around the corner, and many residents and towns will began setting off fireworks to celebrate.Fireworks come with risks from starting fires to injuries of an individual, safety officials say. Residents are advised to follow certain protocols to keep celebrations safe.
Master Deputy State Fire Marshal Oliver Alkire recommends residents to go to public fireworks shows. For those who are dead-set on setting fireworks off themselves, Alkire doesn't recommend going over state lines to purchase fireworks.
"If you are going to be using any fireworks, just to keep in mind that you should only be purchasing and using fireworks that you are buying within your county or your area," he said. "... Anything that you can purchase at a roadside stand, I can assure you, has been inspected, or anywhere in any retail stores."
The most important thing Alkire emphasizes is only adults should handle fireworks.
"If you're going to light fireworks, only allow the adults to light the fireworks, only light one firework at a time, and also keep all children and pets away from fireworks," he said.
For those handling fireworks at home, Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson recommends to have a water hose nearby and ready in case of a fire.
For fireworks that light and don't work, Alkire recommends putting the fireworks in a bucket of water for 24 hours, then disposing of them properly.
The state fire marshal's office recommend not putting fireworks anywhere on the body. In 2023, there were two deaths in Maryland resulting from people holding fireworks to their chest or head.
In the event of an emergency, people are advised to call 911 for assistance. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Woman killed, two others injured in Preston crash
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Woman killed, two others injured in Preston crash

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 181

 PRESTON — A 30-year-old woman was killed in a fatal crash that occurred in Preston on Tuesday, according to Maryland State Police.Police say just after 6:30 p.m. Tuesday, officers responded to a crash involving two vehicles at the intersection of Harmony Road and Grove Road. One vehicle, a Ford, was heading south on Harmony Road when the other vehicle, a Chevrolet, did not stop at the intersection and struck the Ford.
The driver of the first vehicle, identified as Courtney Dunn of Salisbury, was pronounced dead at the scene.
The driver of the second vehicle and a 16-year-old passenger were flown to TidalHealth Peninsula Regional in Salisbury and the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment.
According to police, Harmony Road was closed for around three hours for an investigation. The crash investigation is still ongoing and is being led by the Maryland State Police Crash Team.
Police said the investigation's findings will be sent to the Caroline County State's Attorney Office to determine if charges will be filed.
Anyone with information may contact the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack at 410-822-3101.

title: Community block party brings resources and fun together
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Community block party brings resources and fun together

 August 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 292
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER — Strengthening neighborhood spirit, a warm evening of collaboration brings a festival of resources and organizations for a community night out block party to the United Methodist Church in Chester Aug. 2.The annual community block party is a multi-organization collaborative event brought forth music, food vendors, resources and giveaways.
Blending everything in the county in one central hub: the warm evening of collaboration provided an opportunity for citizens, law enforcement, faith-based organizations, county agencies, civic organizations, neighborhood organizations, and businesses to come together and address prevention issues.
Sponsored by CSAFE, the Collaborative Supervision and Focused Enforcement Group, and in collaboration with the organizations including the Queen Anne's County Department of Health Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services, Citizens Against Smoking Tobacco Coalition, the Office of the Sheriff and the Wellness Coalition, the annual community-building campaign promotes police-community partnerships to make neighborhoods safer.
Thankful to be part of the diverse landscape that makes up Queen Anne's County, Dorine Fassett has been organizing community events to bring resources to surrounding neighbors for years.
"I love to see people come out and support each other," Fassett said.
Community festivals are excellent ways for neighbors to learn more about the resources and organizations surrounding them in a casual, fun environment, she said.
Alongside local vendors, raffles and activities for all ages, other participating organizations included the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Department, the County Health Department, and the Maryland Army National Guard.
National Night Out is a nationwide event that brings law enforcement and the community together and is traditionally held on the first Tuesday in August. Fassett and her organizers love to hold a community event on the first Friday prior to giving the community more events to attend and more opportunities to get out and meet their neighbors, she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Ridgely police force saga is far from over
author: Konner Metz
content:
Ridgely police force saga is far from over

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Headlines 
 
 178
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Though it hasn't been an active agency for nearly 18 months, the Ridgely Police Department is still making noise in Caroline County.Police officers and employees were suspended by town commissioners in March 2024 and later laid off, leaving the town with coverage through a contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office. But the matter is now being taken to federal court.
Former Police Chief Jeff Eckrich, six former officers and a former employee have filed a lawsuit, alleging that town officials and Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker formed a "coup" to disband RPD.
Among many claims, the lawsuit asserts that Baker and former Ridgely officer James Joles "devised a plan that would eliminate the RPD and allow the Sheriff's Office" to take over policing in the town."
Joles, who resigned in 2024 and provided documentation to town officials that led to a state investigation into Eckrich for alleged misconduct, spoke to The Star Democrat on Wednesday. He denied claims made in the lawsuit.
To learn more about Joles' comments and the lawsuit itself, read our story below.
Thanks for reading.
— Konner Metz

title: Trial Begins For Cambridge Man Charged In Fatal Shooting
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com
content:
Trial Begins For Cambridge Man Charged In Fatal Shooting

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 528
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Testimony began Tuesday in the jury trial for a Cambridge man charged in the shooting death of a 24-year-old man last December.Tramelle Williams, 23, is charged with firstand second-degree murder, armed robbery and firearms offenses in the fatal shooting of Taijay Brian Daniels on Pleasant Street just after 7 p.m.
Dec. 8, 2022.
Wearing a Space Jam jacket and walking down Race Street that night, Daniels was just a normal 24-year-old. He had no idea he was about to be killed "execution-style," said Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, who is prosecuting the case with Senior Assistant State's Attorney Ella Disharoon.
Williams, wearing a mask, approached Daniels with a gun, shooting him in the back. Then, he shot again, striking Daniels in the head twice before taking Daniels' belongings and leaving.
Although a Cambridge resident on his way home that night found Daniels' body lying facedown on Pleasant Street within minutes of the shooting, and police and emergency medical services personnel performed CPR, Daniels was pronounced deceased at the scene.
Daniels' death was ruled a homicide by multiple gunshot wounds, two of which were "rapidly fatal," a state medical examiner testified Tuesday afternoon.
"He didn't stand a chance," Leonard said during her opening statement.
However, Williams didn't count on surveillance cameras from local businesses capturing the shooting, she said.
Williams also didn't count on police arresting him while he was wearing the same backpack from the night of the shooting, or police finding Daniels' phone in his pocket, Leonard added.
Williams was arrested the next evening following a foot pursuit on Lincoln Terrace. After he attempted to flee, a Cambridge police officer fired, shooting Williams in the leg.
But to defense attorneys Michelle Moodispaw and Stephanie DeLang, evidence shown by prosecutors would not prove Williams guilty.
Video surveillance and forensics presented by prosecutors have limited value, Moodispaw said, urging the jury to consider evidence that wasn't being shown.
The only thing to be presented was "maybes and possibilities," she said.
By the end of the day Tuesday, seven witnesses had testified, including Daniels' mother, police officers, crime scene technicians and the medical examiner.
Additional law enforcement witnesses and forensic analysts are expected to testify Wednesday. A verdict is anticipated Friday.
This week's trial is not the only pending case against Williams.
Williams is also accused in a second fatal shooting in Cambridge, which occurred roughly three hours after Daniels was shot.
Around 10 p.m. Dec. 8, 2022, police responded to the 700 block of High Street for a second gunshot victim, who was identified as Lory Eugene Fields, 69, of Cambridge.
Fields was found lying in a yard with a gunshot wound to his head. He was declared deceased at the scene.
Williams is facing additional murder and robbery charges in connection to Fields' death.
Though the shootings happened within hours of each other and all charges appear to be grouped together in Maryland Judiciary court records, Williams is set to stand for a second trial related to Fields' death in mid-January. 
 
 Caption: FILE PHOTO

 Pleasant Street near the intersection with Race Street in Cambridge is the scene of the first fatal shooting that occurred Thursday evening, Dec. 8, 2022.

title: ‘Cutting edge’: Talbot County first responders create mental health peer program
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘Cutting edge’: Talbot County first responders create mental health peer program

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new peer support program is aiming to break stigmas around mental health and provide direct assistance to first responders across Talbot County.The collaborative program is called Talbot FiRST!, a joint effort between the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, 911 dispatch center, Talbot County Sheriff's Office, Talbot County Department of Corrections, Easton Police Department and Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
Tina Kintop, EMS division chief for the Department of Emergency Services, says the program is meant to provide mental health services for all first responders in the county.
The peer support team will be made up of a diverse selection of first responders who have been interviewed and trained through a partnership with For All Seasons. When a first responder is in need of help, they can contact a peer member.
Kintop says the program is designed so first responders don't have to "go through the ranks" for mental health assistance.
"The idea is that they can come from the bottom up, meaning that they will know who all the peer (team members) are," Kintop said. " … They will be able to contact who they want to contact."
Kintop and fellow members of Talbot FiRST!'s steering committee — made up of heads from all of the agencies — were applauded by the Talbot County Council on Oct. 22 for the initiative.
County Manager Clay Stamp, a former Talbot County emergency services director, commended the program for being the first of its kind in Maryland.
"The things that we expose our 18-year-old kids to — that become EMTs or dispatchers or police officers — are horrendous," Stamp said on Oct. 22. "We have got to come up with a better way to arm these individuals to deal with these things in a healthy manner and to give them a support system.
"And right here in Talbot County, out of the 23 counties and Baltimore City, they've stepped up, and they're making it happen first."
Former EMS Division Chief Matt Watkins said it's a step very few first responder communities around the country have taken, adding, "Talbot County should be extremely proud of the fact that we're on the cutting edge of this."
Kintop and Watkins have been involved in creating the program for more than a year. A training by former New York City Police Department detective and crisis negotiator Jeff Thompson ignited their enthusiasm for the project.
Kintop called the four-day training "rigorous," yet said all of the first responders who attended were committed to learning from Thompson's life experiences.
"By the time the day was over, you didn't even know you were there for eight hours. It was so engaging, and everybody felt the same way," Kintop said. " … It brought up all the things that maybe I didn't seek help for, that I just kind of sucked it up and handled it on my own."
Kintop says the peer program will be completing a second phase of training soon to expand the peer team, along with doing outreach to first responder agencies. Her hope is that Talbot FiRST! becomes a model up and down the Eastern Shore.
For All Seasons CEO Beth Anne Dorman said funding from the Rural Maryland Council made the nonprofit's clinical training with the Talbot County first responders possible. In fiscal year 2024, the Rural Maryland Council awarded a $30,000 grant to For All Seasons meant to aid the organization in training first responder agencies across the Mid-Shore.
Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan recalled the stigma around mental health in the first responder community when he first volunteered as a firefighter at 18 years old.
"You kind of feel like you're out there alone sometimes, and you need to talk to somebody," Callahan said at the Oct. 22 meeting. "Sometimes, the stuff that we do feels like it's forgotten.
"As long as we're up here, you guys are never ever going to get forgotten," Callahan said, "because you're our heroes in Talbot County, and we love you guys and you protect us." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: School bus crash sends 11 to hospital
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
School bus crash sends 11 to hospital

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 425
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Eleven patients were transported to the hospital following a crash between a SUV and a Caroline County school bus near the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Three Bridge Branch Road just before 8 a.m.Monday morning.According to a preliminary investigation by Maryland State Police, a Kia Sportage failed to stop at a stop sign at a four-way intersection and crashed into the side of the bus.The school bus rolled over.According to a statement from Caroline County Public Schools, the bus was transporting high school students involved in the Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps program to Easton High School. Nine students and the bus driver were transported to area hospitals. All parents of children on the bus were notified.The juvenile driver of the Kia Sportage, whose identity is being withheld by police at this time, was transported to an area hospital for treatment of injuries.In an email sent to parents Monday morning, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the driver was an Easton High School student.Police said the cause of the crash is under investigation. Charges may be filed pending the outcome of the investigation.Fog blanketed the area around the time of the crash. Neither Talbot County Public Schools nor Caroline County Public Schools issued a fog delay earlier in the morning.Troopers from the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack, Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division and crash team responded to the scene to assist.All lanes on Matthewstown Road at Three Bridge Branch Road were closed for several hours during the investigation.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Caroline County Sheriff's Office also responded to the scene to assist. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A school bus lays on its side in the roadway following a Monday morning crash involving this SUV.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A cadet field manual lies next to the overturned bus and some broken glass. The bus was delivering Caroline County NJROTC students to Easton High School. Eleven people were injured in the crash.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A member of Maryland State Police inspects the bottom of the bus that turned over at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road on Monday, Oct. 30. The rear and roof escape hatches are open.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT

title: Trappe Volunteer Fire Company seeks funding for firehouse
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Trappe Volunteer Fire Company seeks funding for firehouse

 July 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company is raising funds to build an up-to-date firehouse. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st) wants to secure federal funding to help.The Trappe Volunteer Firehouse was completed in 1951 and has not been updated since. "We probably have the oldest one in the county," Assistant Secretary Treasurer of the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company Cheryl Lewis said.
Lewis said a new firehouse is necessary because the current building is no longer suitable for the modern equipment.
Because Trappe has a volunteer fire company, like many towns on the Eastern Shore, projects like this rely heavily on government and local support, Lewis said.
"We've been in the process of trying to get assistance," Lewis said. "In the last budget year, the federal budget that was just approved, we had successfully worked with Andy Harris's office to be included in the budget. But with the cuts that were done early on this year, it was removed."
Harris said the appropriations bill to provide funding for the project failed due to negotiations in Congress leading to a continued delay, but she said the project has been reapplied for in the current year's legislation.
"We hope the appropriations process has a better outcome, but then that's not up to us because it involves the minority party as well," he said in an interview with the Star Democrat.
In order to qualify for federal grants, the company must match 25% of the projected project cost of $6 million. The company set a goal of $1,500,000 and set aside $450,000 to begin the efforts.
Fundraising efforts include The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company's upcoming annual fair, held on July 31 through Aug. 2 at the firehouse. The event begins at 6 p.m. and ends at 10 p.m. each day and will include fire truck rides, hay rides, food, games and prizes, and live entertainment, according to the fire company's Facebook page. Saturday's event will open with a parade.
Harris said the outcome of federal funding depends on the successful bipartisan negotiations in Congress to pass this version of the appropriations bill.
"In the end, this is going to depend on the minority party. And you know, if they're not willing to negotiate in good faith, that could end up being a problem," Harris said. "The people in Trappe have to know that their member of Congress was working hard to get that money to the fire company." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Multiple crashes at Easton intersection lead to resident concerns
author: Konner Metz
content:
Multiple crashes at Easton intersection lead to resident concerns

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 630
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A recent string of crashes at the intersection of Brookletts Avenue and South Aurora Street have ignited resident calls for traffic and safety improvements.Monday morning, residents Lydia Pinkney and Tony Ruffini stood on the sidewalk of Aurora Street, discussing their safety concerns for the residential area that is home to many families and children.
"You stand out here for about five, ten minutes, you'll see how fast people go," Ruffini said. "It's insane. They don't care, and they're always in a hurry."
According to the Easton Police Department, the intersection has seen three crashes this month, all due to driver error. There were only 13 in the last 11 years, police said.
Town engineers reviewed the traffic light, which was confirmed as operational. In a Facebook post, the police department encouraged drivers to be cautious and stated the intersection will be monitored.
"While this location is being monitored, officers have begun targeted traffic enforcement and will continue to do so at different hours of the day," the department wrote.
Pinkney said she's worried for the safety of her 9-year-old daughter and her dog when walking up and down Aurora Street near the intersection. She says a car has careened into her yard before, and many neighbors have had their parked cars damaged.
Pinkney believes part of the issue is drivers may be unaware it is a residential area.
"The speed limit's 25, and I know people are going more than 25," she said. "Our kids play out here. And what worries me about everything is if … someone's not paying attention or whatnot, them running the red light or just going way too fast and clipping me and my daughter."
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said the town is looking at what it can do with the intersection's traffic light in terms of safety and timing.
Easton's engineers recently adjusted the timing of the intersection's traffic light, hoping to lower the "chances of a collision if a driver attempts to beat a red light," the Easton Police Department announced Tuesday.
Discussion around safety on Brookletts Avenue has been recurring. This month, the town installed four-way stop signs at two other Brookletts intersections, South Harrison Street and Hanson Street. The intersections previously had two stop signs each.
Van Emburgh said thus far, feedback on the four-way stop signs has been positive. Resident Lisa Stone lives next to the intersections and said she's happy with the change.
"I have seen so many near accidents at the intersections, particularly Hanson and Brookletts," Stone said. " … I think that's a good improvement."
The town also added on-street parking lines to Brookletts Avenue, a measure that Van Emburgh said will improve safety on the wide, two-way street.
"The white lines give the drivers cues as to where they're supposed to be in the travel lanes," Van Emburgh said. "Because one of the things that we struggle with is when you have a road that can accommodate on-street parking, but no one's actually parking on it, it looks like a wide-open raceway."
For many neighbors, traffic and safety concerns only grow as developers revamp a nearby property formerly owned by Perdue AgriBusiness. Last week, Easton's Planning Commission approved the majority of a 123-unit proposal for the site along Brookletts Avenue.
Developers had Lenhart Traffic Consulting prepare a traffic impact study, which recommended project approval. Per Planning Commission documents, the study found redevelopment will have "minimal impact on the surrounding road network."
Ruffini said with the new development and an eventual increase in traffic, South Aurora Street "will be a main road before you know it."
Stone, meanwhile, is excited to see the redevelopment, given it includes commercial space and affordable housing. But she's keeping an eye on its impacts to driver and pedestrian safety.
"Hopefully it will just be an increase in traffic and not a decrease in safety," Stone said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Trial begins for Cambridge man accused of murder, kidnapping of woman
author: Konner Metz
content:
Trial begins for Cambridge man accused of murder, kidnapping of woman

 September 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 615
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Witness testimony began Tuesday in the jury trial for a Cambridge man charged with murdering and kidnapping a woman last year.Kenneth Bradley, 43, is charged with first- and second-degree murder and kidnapping, among other counts, in connection to the disappearance and presumed death of Tiyavauna Britt on Feb. 7, 2024, at the Gerry Boyle Park at Great Marsh in Cambridge.
On Tuesday, prosecutors made their first appeal to the jury, asking for first-degree murder and kidnapping convictions. The defense is vying for not-guilty verdicts on those counts, contending that second-degree murder or manslaughter are more appropriate charges.
Bradley and Britt, a 31-year-old mother of three, had been dating, according to multiple accounts provided during trial Tuesday and prior court documents. They were allegedly together in the parking lot of the park on Feb. 7, 2024, before Britt disappeared.
Easton police put out a missing persons report for Britt six days later. Family had found her car abandoned in an Easton parking lot.
Cambridge police, along with state homicide detectives, assumed the investigation from Easton authorities following the review of cell phone location data placing Britt at the park.
Bradley was initially arrested on kidnapping charges in February 2024. Review of camera footage at the park from Feb. 7 revealed "sounds of loud thuds ... consistent with forceful strikes," police wrote in charging documents. Later that night, footage showed a man "carrying and dragging" a woman's body to a vehicle, police wrote.
Bradley was indicted and arrested on murder charges in March 2024. Britt's body was not found.
Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, the lead prosecutor, and public defender Matt Connell, who is representing Bradley, provided opening statements Tuesday.
Leonard told the jury the case is full of "rage, control, domestic violence." Evidence shows Britt's relationship with Bradley was "toxic," she said.
Leonard said Bradley's former employer and a close friend will testify later this week. Bradley confided in them, she said, confessing to the murder and the disposing of Britt's body.
"She vanished," Leonard said. "She was never seen or heard from again. No phone calls or text messages."
Leonard said jurors will see video footage from the park. The audio is "chilling," she said, showing Bradley drag Britt and throw her in the trunk of a car.
Before jurors took their seats to listen to openings, Connell objected to some of the audio evidence, arguing that Bradley could have a "reasonable expectation" for privacy during some of the conversations.
"We are fine acknowledging that that was him in the video," Connell said. " ... 90% of the verbal communication occurred inside the vehicle."
Leonard disagreed with the 90% assessment. Connell said, "it's possible I'm mistaken."
While the full video and accompanying audio wasn't admitted as evidence Tuesday, Judge William Jones sided with the prosecution. It's "quite likely" the court will allow its admission during trial, the judge said, especially if the conversations included yelling.
In Connell's opening statement, he acknowledged Bradley's involvement in Britt's death. But he said prosecutors must show Bradley intended to kill Britt in order for the jury to deliver a guilty verdict on first-degree murder.
"He lost it. He hit her too hard, and she died," Connell said, adding that Bradley tried to resuscitate Britt. "He didn't mean to do it."
"Hold him responsible for what he's really guilty of, not above and beyond that," the defense attorney said.
Thirteen witnesses testified Tuesday, including close family of Britt and police detectives who worked the case.
Linda Harris, Britt's mother, recalled Feb. 12, 2024 during an emotional testimony. It was her other daughter's birthday, and Britt didn't show up.
"She wouldn't miss anything," Harris said of birthday parties and holidays. The mother said she last saw Britt a week before she disappeared.
Trial is scheduled to continue through Friday. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Ridgley commissioners vote to continue MOU with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Ridgley commissioners vote to continue MOU with Caroline County Sheriff's Office

 May 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 456
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — The Ridgely commissioners voted to continue the town's memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office at their monthly meeting Monday.Commissioner Brad Sears voted in favor of the MOU, but he said he plans to continue negotiation with the Sheriff's Office over details of the agreement.
"I think at this point we're to a point where we would entertain a motion to give the town authorization to meet with the county to negotiate any changes to the MOU and go from there," Sears said.
Ridgely has maintained a contract with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to have assigned officers covering the town since last year. In March of 2024, the town suspended the entirety of its police department amid a state investigation.
On July 25, 2024, an investigation report by the Office of the State Prosecutor found no "sufficient evidence of criminal activity warranting further investigation or prosecution." By that time, the Ridgely officers had already been laid off.
Monday's decision came after a discussion at last month's commissioners meeting about three potential options to continue policing for the town.
"I know last month we talked about three options, one completely going back to the sheriff's department regular patrol pattern," Sears said. "Second was to attempt to re-establish an original police force, and even that price was conservatively estimated at $852,000 for the first year if we could find the police officer."
The third option was to continue the MOU with the county.
The cost for the services of the Caroline County Sheriff's Office would be $493,415 on the fiscal year 2026 budget.
The Sheriff advocated for his office to continue its agreement with the town.
"The sheriff's office is providing what is going to be a high quality of law enforcement in the town," Caroline County Sheriff Donald Baker said in an interview. "The town going with the MOU with the sheriff's office, they get everything the sheriff's office has to provide as far as criminal investigations handled by a investigator or detective, as well as the sheriff's office is a member of the Caroline County Drug Task Force and we have two deputies assigned to that."
Multiple questions were brought up by town residents regarding where the $493,415 would go. Baker clarified to residents and commissioners how the funds would be broken down.
"There was some confusion that this money is dumped right into the Sheriff's Office budget. That's not true," Baker said. "The county is billing the town based upon the usage. So, if we don't use something or there's money left over, the county does not bill it and it goes back to the town or the town keeps it and it's never filled."
The vote to continue the MOU was unanimous. Commissioner John Hurley was absent from the meeting.
