title: Few show for police town hall meeting
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Few show for police town hall meeting

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 870
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Few residents showed up to a town hall meeting, hosted by the Cambridge Police Department Tuesday evening, to hear about the department's community policing efforts and its goals for the future.Toward the end of the meeting, which was held at the Empowerment Center in Cambridge, Police Chief Justin Todd asked the five residents in attendance to share information from the meeting with other residents."All I ask of you, is that you take this tonight and make sure that the information - whether it's good information or bad, if you agree or disagree - and you put it out there to the public that we, the police department, want to work with our community to better the situation out on the street," Todd said.While the department used to only have two or three officers in a community policing division, Capt.Shane Hinson explained that every officer in the department is now a community-oriented police officer."It's all of our jobs to go out and make meaningful connections with the community," Hinson said, adding that every officer has been through a training course on community-oriented policing.Todd said community-oriented policing is what the department "is and will be built off of." Along with Todd and Hinson, Capt. Antoine Patton and Lt. Greg McCray spoke at the town hall.Patton spoke about some of the things the department does to increase positive interactions with the community."If you look on the news, it would have you to believe sometimes that police officers are only there when bad things happen," he said. "But we want our community to know that we love them, and we're here to work together." Patton mentioned how the department takes children and senior citizens Christmas shopping every year. This year, he said he had the idea for "12 Days of Christmas" where the department will take children and senior citizens out shopping from Dec. 12 through Dec. 24.Patton talked about a Thanksgiving dinner the department hosted last year and plans to host again this year."In five to 10 years these children will be teenagers and these teenagers will remember the things that we did," he said.Todd shared some of the city's crime data at the meeting as well.Since 2019, the Cambridge Police Department has taken 114 illegal guns off the streets, he said.Compared the the record number of seven homicides in Cambridge last year, Todd said there have been two homicides so far in 2023."I don't call that success by any means," he said. "The day we have zero is the day we've been successful. [[---]] But it's progress. And that's what we have to keep banking on as we keep getting better as a community and a city." Todd said the number of juvenile crimes (committed by those under 18) is "continuously getting worse." "Out of the 300-and-some assaults that we've had this year, 127 have been committed by juveniles," he said.Todd brought up the juvenile justice reform bill, passed in 2022, which stops youth, under the age of 13, from facing criminal charges like assault and weapons violations.He said something needs to be done to fix this reform."And the juveniles know it," he said. "We have 12-year-old kids telling us, 'What are you going to do to me?'" With the juvenile curfew in Cambridge, which went into effect Oct. 1, Todd said the last thing he wants to do is fine a parent."But at the end of the day, if we can help one child or one family, one parent to better parent their child, and get them out of the streets, then we've done something right as a community and it's a start," he said about the curfew.In 2010, Todd said the department had 52 officers. When he entered the role of police chief, there were 29 total officers with two in the police academy."At that time, we had a department that was depleted," he said.The department is building itself back up. Todd said there are 39 total officers in the department right now, with four in the police academy."So we'll get those out of the police academy in December, and we'll keep building our Criminal Investigations Division," he said.Todd said he hopes to increase the diversity of the department. He said that 67.5% of both civilian employees and sworn officers in the department are white. Black employees make up 22.5%. Hispanic employees and Asian employees each make up 5%."We want to mirror our community," Todd said, acknowledging that this is no easy feat."But I just want the public to know we're working hard to get there," he added.After the meeting, Gary Gordy, one of the residents in attendance, said that he thinks more policing is needed in Cambridge and thinks it's good the department is hiring more officers. He said that when it comes to crime, Cambridge needs cameras.Gordy added that some of the problems the city is facing with crime could have been prevented if the city had acted earlier."We wait for years to get things done," he said. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Capt. Antoine Patton discusses community policing at the Cambridge Police Department town hall meeting Oct. 3 at the Cambridge Empowerment Center. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police investigating 'sabotage' of Greensboro's water system
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Police investigating 'sabotage' of Greensboro's water system

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 328
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — The Town of Greensboro said it has discovered "deliberate sabotage" of its water system after higher than normal chlorine levels this weekend."After examining the tower wells, it was discovered that one of the chlorine regulators had been tampered with," the town wrote in a release on Monday. The release stated the Caroline County Sheriff's Office is conducting a criminal investigation.
The discovery follows resident concerns about the smell and drinkability of the town's water. On Saturday, Greensboro's public works department contacted its water and wastewater contractor, Susquehanna Operational Services, to test chlorine levels.
Resident Jose Miranda said "the smell is still really strong." He said there's no discoloration of the water, but that the chlorine smell is obvious.
In the release, the town stated that the chlorine levels were as high as 2.2 milligrams per liter over the weekend. Typical readings are around 0.56 milligrams per liter.
That mark dropped to 1.0 milligrams per liter on Monday, the town said. The Environmental Protection Agency's standard is that anything above the 4.0 milligram per level mark is not healthy to drink and could pose long-term health effects such as eye irritation and stomach problems.
On Sunday, a Facebook post by the town told residents the water is safe to drink and within Maryland Department of the Environment regulations. Multiple residents, though, commented that the chlorine-like smell and taste were still noticeable.
On July 19, the town issued a boil water notice, advising residents to boil water before drinking due to high chlorine levels.
Resident Chris Mason said the water quality issue has been recurring in the last few weeks. He said poor drinking water will especially effect those without refrigerator filters and mothers who need it for baby formula.
Town Manager Tammy Kelledes said the town changed its locks to prevent further tampering with the regulators.
Residents who would like their water tested can call 410-482-6222 or email greensboro@greensboromd.com. Anyone with information regarding the criminal investigation can call the Caroline County Sheriff's Office at 410-479-2515. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge Police Department is investigating two shootings that happened over the weekend, the department stated in a press release.On Saturday just after 4:30 a.m., police responded to reports of shots fired on Pine Street. The Cambridge Police Department is requesting the community's help to provide information for both shootings. Anyone with information can anonymously call police at 410-228-3333.

title: Tuesday night storm was loud, but damage was minimal
author: Staff Writer
content:
Tuesday night storm was loud, but damage was minimal

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 225
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The sky darkened Tuesday evening and then a jagged bolt of lightning ripped across the sky followed by the loud rumble of thunder.Then more lightning, more thunder. And rain. Driving rain that swamped yards and some streets.
The storm went on for hours. When it ended there seemed to be only minor damage — some downed tree limbs ... except for the Faith Chapel United Methodist Church near Trappe. A bolt of lightning hit the church and started a fire.
Trappe firefighters quickly responded and doused the flames. The state fire marshal's office assessed the damage at $25,000, not as bad as it could have been but devastating for a small church.
The Rev. Gary Moore said the damage is "very, very significant" for the small church, which dates to the 1880s.
"I was there last night," Moore said in an interview with Star Democrat reporter Konner Metz Wednesday. "Assessing the building will be a difficult decision as we move into the future."
Read Konner's story below along with an incredible story about a juvenile kayaker who got lost over the weekend as darkness fell. He was found quickly by the Natural Resources Police who used a thermal imaging device to spot the kayak and lead firefighters to pull the young kayaker to safety.
That's a story that could have had a bad ending. Fortunately it did not.
— Jim Johnson

title: Motorists encouraged to watch for deer as breeding season approaches
author: Tom McCall
content:
Motorists encouraged to watch for deer as breeding season approaches

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As deer breeding season nears, motorists are encouraged to keep their eyes peeled for white tails on the road.Local auto repair businesses say they are busier fixing collisions this time of year. Hitting a deer can cause thousands of dollars worth of damage, bending front fenders, crumpling hoods and cracking front windshields.
"It is about 20% to 30% more this time of year," said TJ Jefferson of Grants Automotive in Easton. "I get more calls early in the morning, 'Can you come get my car? I just struck a deer or a deer just struck me.'"
With increased volume during deer season, he says they just get it done with the available manpower that they have.
According to data from State Farm, "U.S. drivers had an estimated 1.8 million animal collision insurance claims in the U.S. between July 2022 and June 2023."
About 1.5 million deer-car accidents happen every year. More than $1 billion in annual insured losses are due to damages caused by deer-car accidents. According to State Farm, Maryland drivers have a one-in-116-vehicle likelihood risk for animal collisions. The highest risk state for deer-car collisions is West Virginia at one in 37 vehicles.
Deer breeding season begins in October and runs through mid-December. During these months, bucks become more active, seeking out female deer. The females move around more to avoid the bucks. All this motion means more deer are on the roads.
Deer are most active between the hours of 5 and 8 a.m. and again from 5 to 8 p.m., which are also hours that many drivers are on the road commuting to or from work.
Trooper Ian Rola of the Easton Barracks of the Maryland State Police said, "The incidents that rise this time of year are car accidents. (Deer) are in rut and are running all over and crossing the roadway. It is usually up this time of year — in the November time frame."
Rola and fellow law enforcement officers work to help keep roadways clear of hazards during these peak months.
"It is between law enforcement and SHA. We try to keep the roads clear. We rely on the public. If you see a carcass, give us a call, and we will come out. If it is a mess, we call SHA (State Highway Administration) to help," Rola said.
Rola emphasized the importance of drivers slowing down and wearing seat belts, especially as deer breeding season approaches.
"You have got to imagine, you hit a dear, you slam on the brakes and you are going forward at the same time. The seat belt will stop that forward momentum. This saves a lot of injuries from deer accidents," he said.
Representatives from the State Highway Administration encouraged drivers to avoid making sudden turns or movements to avoid hitting deer.
"Making sudden, sharp turns is dangerous as it could place the driver in the path of oncoming traffic or cause your vehicle to strike a fixed object such as a tree or utility pole," wrote Charlie Gischlar of the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration in an email.

title: Game called, police investigating assault
author: Staff Writer
content:
Game called, police investigating assault

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News

 Words

 CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff is actively investigating an assault that took place this evening on a Queen Anne's County High School basketball player. The incident occurred during the state quarter final championship being played at Queen Anne's County High School between Carver Vocational-Technical High School and QACHS.A representative for the Sheriff's Office confirmed they had obtained and are currently reviewing video surveillance footage as part of ongoing efforts. The Sheriff's Office is encouraging anyone who may have witnessed the alleged assault or has any additional video footage to contact the investigating deputy.
No arrests have been made at this time. One player sustained minor injuries and refused treatment at the scene.
In an effort to ensure the accuracy and integrity of the ongoing investigation, the Sheriff's Office is requesting speculation and rumors regarding suspect information from the community be withheld. "We understand the concerns within the community and assure you that we are committed to conducting a comprehensive investigation and ensuring a safe place in our schools as we work with school officials to bring a conclusion to this investigation," Public Information Officer Kaitlyn Briselli said on behalf of the department.
"Our players, teams, community, and school staff deserve a safe environment, we have a zero tolerance for this type of behavior at our public events, and we can assure our community that this investigation will be thoroughly completed, and appropriate charges will be done at the conclusion," added Sheriff Gary Hofmann. The department is continuing to review evidence and fully investigate the incident.
Anyone with additional information or video footage regarding this assault, is urged to contact Deputy Rhyheem Johnson at rjohnson@qac.org or to call 410-758-0770 ext. 1945. You may also submit this information anonymously on the app using the link here:https://apps.apple.com/us/app/queen-annes-sheriff/id1438757929?ls=1 https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ocv.queenannescosheriff or by calling the anonymous tip line at 410-758-6666.

title: Oxford man with loaded gun charged with assault
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Oxford man with loaded gun charged with assault

 August 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: A14 | Section: News 
 
 303
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD - An Oxford man is facing assault, reckless endangerment and firearm charges after reportedly pointing a loaded shotgun at someone.Robert McWilliams, 63, is charged with first-and second-degree assault, using a firearm in a crime of violence, reckless endangerment and intoxicated endangerment in connection to a Sunday, Aug. 6, incident.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the 100 block of Third Street in Oxford just after 10 p.m. that day for a reported assault in progress.According to charging documents, the caller, a family member, said McWilliams had a shotgun and had threatened to shoot him. The threat followed an argument between the two men at a local restaurant earlier that evening.After leaving the restaurant with the rest of his family, the man said they walked to McWilliams' house and knocked on his door. The man told police McWilliams came to the door armed with a shotgun, pointed it at him and said that, if the man entered the home, he would shoot him.Police who spoke with McWilliams at the home said they could smell the odor of alcohol on his breath and on him. McWilliams told police that he left the restaurant after the argument and returned home. When he heard the man knock at the door, he armed himself with the shotgun and went downstairs to answer.McWilliams also told police he did not point the shotgun at the man and that he felt "threatened" by something the man said earlier in the evening.Police recovered the shotgun, identified as a Remington 870 20-gauge. The gun was found with one live shot shell in the chamber with the safety off, police wrote in charging documents.McWilliams appeared in the county district court Aug.7 for a bail review. He was ordered to remain held without bond.A preliminary hearing in the case is scheduled for Aug.28.

title: UPDATE: Fire marshal investigating arson attempt at Ridgely business
author: Konner Metz
content:
UPDATE: Fire marshal investigating arson attempt at Ridgely business

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Multiple trucks at a Ridgely business were targeted in an arson attempt, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.SunnySide Energy, located on West Belle Road, was the subject of an attempted arson to four of its trucks, according to fire officials and owner Bryan Saathoff.
Saathoff said in an interview Thursday that a truck driver called him Monday around 3 a.m. to inform him that a truck had gas running out of its door. When Saathoff arrived, he eventually found four trucks doused with gas — one of them significantly burnt.
"The seats were soaked, they had gas running out of the floor," Saathoff said. "Then the very last one, we could tell when we open it, it had burned."
Damages are estimated at $100,000, per the fire marshal. Saathoff said surveillance cameras show two actors — one driving a vehicle outside the fence and another person inside the business' fence where the trucks are parked, he said.
The fire marshal's office is actively investigating the arson attempt. Anyone with information is asked to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office at 410-819-3500.
SunnySide Energy — which delivers bulk loads of fuel, retail and pool water — is offering a $1,000 reward for information leading to an arrest, Saathoff said.
He added that the damage to the trucks is a big financial dent.
"The loads that were lined up for the trucks, we have to get them back and you have lost revenue," Saathoff said. "But we still got the same expenses."
This story has been updated to correct the name of the business fire officials say was targeted in an arson attempt. The company is SunnySide Energy, formerly Murphy Transport and America's Best Oil.

title: Video of presumed ICE arrest sparks confusion, fear in Cambridge
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Video of presumed ICE arrest sparks confusion, fear in Cambridge

 June 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Immigrant communities are living in fear after arrests of immigrants have taken a new shape under the Trump administration.A Facebook video of unmarked vehicles with federal agents in bulletproof vests and ski masks arresting four men on Maryland Avenue off Route 50 in Cambridge has been circulating throughout the community.
"You know, it's definitely something we knew was coming, but we didn't know it was gonna be handled this way," said Julie Martinez, who recorded and uploaded the video to Facebook.
Residents and commenters of the video believe these agents to be Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials. The Department of Homeland Security has not responded to The Star Democrat's request for details about the incident.
Since President Donald Trump's inauguration, ICE raids have looked different. Washington, D.C., immigration attorney of over 25 years Matthew Famiglietti said the legal gray area has grown significantly due to rapid policy changes such as getting rid of safe spaces like churches, courts, hospitals and schools.
"Talking about what's legal and what's not legal, that's changed quite a bit since Trump," Famiglietti said.
Trump campaigned on stepping up immigration enforcement, promising to deliver the largest mass deportation in American history. ICE arrests have increased by 25% since he took office, according to the most recent ICE detention data.
To make this possible Trump signed five immigration-based executive orders on his first day, instated enforcement and structural changes within federal agencies like Customs and Border Control and ICE, conducted mass arrests including in safe spaces, and enacted travel bans from 12 countries, according to the White House's website.
Famiglietti said ICE agents and the Department of Homeland Security are under no legal obligation to let local law enforcement agencies know of their actions.
Cambridge police Capt. Antoine Patton and Dorchester County Sheriff Jimmy Phillips both said they were not aware of the arrests made on June 4.
The Cambridge Maryland Police Department's official Facebook made a post regarding the arrests saying, "We have received several phone calls and inquiries regarding photos passed through social media showing subjects being detained/arrested within the city limits by law enforcement. The law enforcement in the pictures is not anyone associated with the Cambridge Police Department, and we have no knowledge of the incident(s) that took place."
Martinez said around 7:15 a.m. June 4, four unmarked cars surrounded a work truck and began making what she called "unclear" announcements through a speaker while arresting the four individuals on Maryland Avenue.
"As you can see in the video, they didn't even give them time at all to even explain or say why you're getting pulled over," Martinez said. "It was very quick, so when I saw it, my first thing was 'oh my gosh, there's no way this is happening.'"
Famiglietti said ICE agents do not have to show their faces or ride in marked cars, but they have to wear some sort of identifying detail. Martinez said the agents' bulletproof vests said "Police," but that was the only identifying mark.
Martinez said she immediately pulled out her phone and began recording. She said she's always recording because "you never know what could happen, especially right now."
The video quickly caught traction, with 554 shares, 176 reactions and 135 comments on Facebook. The post made its way to the family members of the detained individuals, who, according to Martinez, were not aware of the arrests before the video.
Out of the 135 comments on Martinez's post, multiple alluded to further ICE actions around Cambridge. However, those actions were not verified.
Famiglietti said concerned residents and those looking for family members who may be detained should call their senators and representatives for information.
"That's the No. 1 thing," he said.
On June 14, demonstrations will be held across the nation on what protesters are calling "No King Day" in response to the administration's immigration policies and the actions of ICE agents. Protests are planned in Easton and Cambridge on that day, according to posts made on social media.
Martinez said the immigrant community has to be especially careful right now.
"Drive at the speed limit. Do everything you're supposed to be doing," she said. "You know we contribute to this country a lot, and unfortunately, we can't stay home. We can't do much but to keep going forward, but definitely stay more on the low." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: CASA of the Mid-Shore is thankful for dedicated volunteers
author: Casa Of The Mid Shore
content:
CASA of the Mid-Shore is thankful for dedicated volunteers

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Casa Of The Mid Shore | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 391
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CASA of the Mid-Shore, a private, nonprofit organization, advocates for children under the protection of the Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's or Kent Circuit Courts because of abuse, neglect or abandonment to ensure the children's right to thrive in safe, permanent homes.A CASA volunteer's role is unique. As a caring and consistent adult, CASA volunteers attempt to identify the specific needs of each child, advocate in court and with agency partners for services to meet those needs and assist in seeking a permanent resolution for each child's life as quickly and safely as possible.Most importantly, the CASA gets to know their appointed children, often becoming one of the most consistent adults in children's lives.This is especially poignant during the holiday season, when all children need to know that someone cares and is looking out for them.For many children, the holidays are a time for building happy memories with family.However, holidays can be very difficult for children who have been removed from their homes and placed in foster care.Rather than enjoying the magic of the season, these children may be adjusting to new foster homes and transitioning to new schools. That can be a heavy burden, and CASA volunteers can help by being present for the children.CASA's involvement can lead to children's hope for a better tomorrow.Studies support the fact that children and youth with CASA volunteers have higher levels of hope than foster children who do not have CASA in their lives.Greater hope can lead to children being more likely to succeed in school, having greater self-control, increased optimism and a healthier sense of well-being."Speaking up for children is our proverbial North Star. It guides us in the certainty that a better future is a real possibility for each child we serve," said Robin Davenport, CASA's executive director. "As we enter the holiday season, we are filled with gratitude for our CASA volunteers. Their compassionate dedication to vulnerable children is a treasure in our service region." CASA volunteers come from all walks of life, varied experiences and professions, and are at least 21 years of age. After completing the application and screening process, individuals participate in pre-service training before being sworn in as an officer of the court.CASA welcomes volunteers from all cultures, ethnicities and backgrounds.To learn more about becoming a Court Appointed Special Advocate, visit casamidshore.org or email jc@casamidshore.org. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Vehicle break-in cases move to Talbot County Circuit Court
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Vehicle break-in cases move to Talbot County Circuit Court

 May 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Criminal cases for two Talbot County teens have moved to the Talbot County Circuit Court from the Talbot County District Court.Nihjay Greene, 18, of Trappe, and Aamad Turner, 19, of Easton, were charged at the end of 2024 for their alleged involvement in multiple vehicle break-ins and thefts that occurred at the end of December in the La Trappe Heights community in Trappe.
Greene was charged with six counts of fourth-degree burglary, six counts of rogue and vagabond, theft, malicious destruction of property, second-degree assault, resisting or interfering with arrest, and obstructing and hindering.
Turner was charged with six counts of fourth-degree burglary, six counts of rogue and vagabond, theft, malicious destruction of property and obstructing and hindering.
Monday, the state entered nolle prosequi for all of Greene and Turner's charges in the district court. This means the state will not prosecute for those charges.
In an interview Monday, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said the charges against Greene and Turner will be recharged in the Talbot County Circuit Court. Coale said this process is standard practice for more complex district court cases that move to the circuit court.
According to Maryland Court records, the charges against both Greene and Turner have been filed in the circuit court.
The charges stem from an incident on Dec. 30 where deputies responded to a report of an attempted vehicle break-in in the 3800 block of Seymour Drive in Trappe. According to a Jan. 3 news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, deputies determined after further investigation that three men wearing all black clothing and masks attempted to enter multiple vehicles, stealing various items.
Police said the same day, deputies were dispatched to Harrison Circle in Trappe, where a resident noticed three men dressed in black clothing and wearing masks looking into vehicles.
Police said the three men barricaded themselves in a residence in the 3900 block of Main Street and after a short time, deputies were able to make contact with them. Police identified the three men as Greene, Turner and a 16-year-old boy, who was not named by the sheriff's office.
In January, the Sheriff's Office said the 16-year-old was charged with the same offenses as Turner and referred to the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services, where he was released to a guardian.
The Sheriff's Office said Greene attempted to resist arrest and assaulted a deputy as he was being detained.
According to the news release, deputies found evidence during the investigation that also connected the three teens to vehicle break-ins that occurred in Easton earlier in 2024.
As of Monday afternoon, hearings or trials had yet to be set for Greene and Turner's circuit court cases.

title: Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home
author: Konner Metz
content:
Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home

 August 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Daniel Fuentes Espinal returned home Friday after nearly a month of being detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.Espinal's daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, flew to Louisiana last week to bring Espinal home, according to a Facebook post by family friend Len Foxwell on Friday.
"It was an emotional time for me — to see him after almost a month of not seeing him," Diaz told The Baltimore Banner.
Espinal, pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015, was arrested the morning of July 21. He was on his way to his construction job, his family said. He was taken to ICE's field office in Salisbury and then transferred to Baltimore, where he spent three nights in Baltimore before being transferred to a detention center in Louisiana.
Espinal was granted bond on Tuesday, family told The Baltimore Banner.
His arrest received regional and national attention. In Easton, it stopped services at his congregation and sparked weekly protests against ICE.
Earlier this month, Easton Town Council members called for Espinal to be returned to his family.
Espinal has been in the country since 2001 and has no criminal record, his family has said. Following his arrest, ICE stated that Espinal was arrested for overstaying his six-month visa.
"Daniel Omar Fuentes Espinal is an illegal alien from Honduras who was arrested by ICE on July 21, in Easton, Maryland," the statement said. "Fuentes entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years. It is a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa."
This story may be updated.
Reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this story.

title: Drivers need patience on roadways
author: Staff Writer
content:
Drivers need patience on roadways

 September 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a senior driver of 70 years driving experience I have finally reached my frustration point in what I (correctly or incorrectly) perceive as unwarranted impatience, if not absolute rudeness and discourtesy, on the part of drivers in Talbot County.I am a competent, not perfect, operator of a motor vehicle, and I do not understand the needs of many other drivers, younger ones in particular, to honk their horns, pass on the right side, ride your bumper or even pass on a double line when I take a needed extra second or two to double check when I am making a turn, entering an intersection, leaving a stop light, or driving at what I consider a safe 40 mph on the narrow, winding and crowned blacktop roads here, many of which have no shoulders only ditches.
You drivers who are speeding and tailgating in our county — and you, in my experience are many —will get where you are going without putting me or yourselves in danger. An absolutely unneeded honking horn is startling and rather than achieving its likely objective of hurrying me along and making me drive in the manner in which you think I should be driving actually slows me down when I look once more to reassess the situation around me before I move away from that light or stop sign or turn against traffic.
You will be senior drivers someday yourself, and you will understand certain facts — namely your reaction time slows a touch, your hearing and vision, though adequate for the task, are not what they used to be and your trust in your own cognition in discerning what is happening around you is quite naturally slightly diminished.
Talbot County and the town of Easton today present challenging driving conditions. The sheer volume of traffic, the narrow streets in town with double parking, and the plethora of large sized pickups and SUVs plying streets and roadways here that were not designed for these types of vehicles are factors, as well as the presence of some dangerous intersections lacking traffic controls — one of these is one I use daily, the intersection of the Parkway and Tristan Drive. I do not need an accident at my age, whether my fault or not. This is a major reason I (and many others of my age) need that extra moment of time to cope safely and competently with the driving situations already mentioned. And I can cope if I get just a minimum amount of cooperation from all of you others on the road.
JOEL S. STROBECK
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton police seek permits for future protests
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton police seek permits for future protests

 October 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — While police said Saturday's No Kings protest in Easton remained civil, they're asking the town to consider requiring public assembly permits for similar future protests.Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey raised the concern at a Town Council meeting Monday. He said Saturday's protest — during which hundreds lined sidewalks on Dover Road — was a challenge for police.
"As with any big event, my concern with police coverage is the unexpected, the person who does not appreciate that (protest)," Lowrey said. "We've seen it all across our country. It's a little frustrating when these events are not going through the public assembly event process, to allow us to plan."
Easton's No Kings rally was just one of thousands nationwide, where people gathered in opposition of the Trump administration. Lowrey said one counter-protester remained civil, though police did get a call from a business concerned about people crowding parking lots.
Talbot County Democratic Central Committee Chair Phil Jackson said in an interview that the committee and the Talbot County Democratic Forum were in "regular contact" with the mayor and police in advance of Saturday's rally to ensure safety.
Also on Saturday in Easton, police and emergency officials held a mass casualty simulation, designed to train first responders in an active shooter scenario. The training ran from 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. at the Temple B'nai Israel and surrounding areas.
Lowrey said the Easton Police Department had a "great deal of resources committed" to that simulation. Combined with the large protest, the agency's patrol division was "essentially wiped out."
"We were able to respond to a call here or there, but if something happened, at that point, it comes at the expense of all the other citizens in the town because we have no officers available to respond to other emergencies," he said.
Saturday's No Kings protest didn't obtain a public assembly permit, nor did the first No Kings gathering in June. Lowrey said the town should look at rewording its public assembly permit rules to explicitly require such protests obtain a permit beforehand.
The police chief said the permits allow the department to adequately staff both the event and day-of calls or emergencies.
According to town code, permits must be obtained for "any open air public meeting, rally, conference, assembly or similar gathering upon any public property." The word "protest" is not included in the code.
Permit applications cost $100, though some events require additional costs depending on the equipment and police officers needed. Permits are first reviewed by police and then either approved or denied by the Town Council. Rarely does the council reject a permit request after a positive police recommendation, though some requests in the past have garnered debate and slim majorities, such as the Delmarva Pride Festival.
Jackson noted that the No Kings Day protests are nationally coordinated and then organized at a local level in the days and weeks leading up. Local organizers, he said, are open to following any new or adjusted permit requirements brought by the town.
"We are very interested in ensuring that these events comply with local policy," Jackson said. "Should the Town of Easton move forward with changes to their public gathering permits, we will look to comply with those and follow the process."
Lowrey added that Easton police typically provide as much coverage as possible for public assemblies at no cost by using on-duty officers. Feedback from Saturday, he said, was that officers were helpful. But he hopes the department can better prepare for future protests.
"But when you have 800 to 1,200 people lining streets and stuff, things can go wrong very quickly," he said. "And that's always my biggest fear. It takes a car driving through 30 people, and we have a mass casualty, actually, incident, and not an exercise." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Farmers, residents raise safety concerns regarding potential Route 662 closure
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Farmers, residents raise safety concerns regarding potential Route 662 closure

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 758
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As site preparation is underway for a new regional medical center in Easton, many residents are concerned about the looming closure of Route 662, or Longwoods Road.The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new hospital is expected to begin construction in the spring of 2025. Since designs have a corner of the hospital sitting in the middle of existing Route 662, a section of the road is expected to be temporarily closed from Oct. 1 to May 1.
Greg Gannon, a co-operator of family-owned grain farming operation C.H. Gannon & Sons on Longwoods Road, is not necessarily opposed to the closure. But Gannon said that the closure will "represent an inconvenience at some level" to not just the agricultural community, but everyone who uses the road.
"Moving large farm equipment and construction equipment these days is dangerous," Gannon said.
Instead of using Route 662, many farmers may have to travel on nearby county-owned roads. Gannon noted the visibility is worse on those county roads compared to Route 662.
Shore Regional Health representatives have stated that delaying construction of the hospital until a new route is complete would present significant financial and time barriers to the project. Hospital construction is estimated to complete in the summer of 2028.
"The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health is committed to advancing the health of Mid-Shore residents and the new Regional Medical Center project is one of the most significant developments in the history of Talbot and its surrounding counties," Shore Regional said in a statement enailed to the Star Democrat. "We recognize that building a state-of-the-art hospital to replace an aging and outdated facility may cause inconveniences and have worked tirelessly with state, county and city officials to ensure interruptions to daily activities are minimized. The necessary decision for a temporary closure of Route 662 was made in conjunction with the State Highway Administration, Talbot County officials and the Talbot County Sherriff's Office."
Nearly 70 residents wrote to the Talbot County Council in opposition of a bill that acts as a land transfer agreement between the county and Shore Regional, amending old legislation that required Shore Regional to build a new route before closing the current one.
A request signed by 67 residents asked that the county stick with the original plan that dated back to 2013. Council members voted 4-1 to approve the bill at their most recent meeting, with Council Member Lynn Mielke the sole no vote.
The letter presented four main concerns: increased traffic on local county roads, potential backups if there's an emergency situation on U.S. Route 50, effects on farmers who use Route 662 for equipment and access to the Talbot County Community Center.
Wittman resident Mark Marshall, who signed the letter, uses the road to travel to and from work. He believes it'll be a detriment to safety for farmers and residents alike.
"It's going to put a hardship on a lot of people who basically depend on that road," Marshall said, "especially on weekends with the traffic and everything going to and from Easton."
As part of the bill passed Tuesday, the transfer of the land from the county to Shore Regional Health is contingent upon the fulfillment of a road inspection and contribution agreement. That agreement requires Shore Regional Health to contribute to surrounding road work.
Surrounding county roads — Hailem School Road, Hiners Lane, Airport Road and Goldsborough Neck Road — will all receive paving work this September, County Manager Clay Stamp said. Though that paving is unrelated to the potential Route 662 closure, Stamp said Shore Regional Health will be contributing financially to the effort.
Since Route 662 is a state road, the Maryland State Highway Administration is responsible for approving its temporary closure and providing an official detour, which is expected to be U.S Route 50.
"SHA continues to work with all involved parties and will review the proposed detour plan to ensure it meets standards and provides for a safe alternate route," SHA wrote in a statement to The Star Democrat.
While the bill approved by the county facilitates the transfer of the road from the county to Shore Regional Health, the Maryland Board of Public Works first must approve the transfer of the land from the state to the county.
Upon successful transfers and State Highway Administration approval, the road may be partially closed for drivers come Oct. 1. Marshall, who drives Route 662 nearly every day and sees large farm equipment, is worried for the safety of the operators when that time arrives.
"If you have to go down (Route) 50, you're taking your life in your own hands," Marshall said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While local government actions and agricultural impacts are discussed, the primary focus is the public safety implications of the closure.

title: New patrolman to join EPD
content:
New patrolman to join EPD

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 2 | Section: News

 On Monday, Dec. 18, 2023, Easton Police Department welcomed Patrolman Christopher Mueller to the force following his graduation from Wor-Wic Community College's Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy.The graduation ceremony was held at the Roland E. Powell Convention Center in Ocean City.
The academy has a six-month curriculum that trains officers on many aspects of police operations and has testing requirements for physical fitness, academics and marksmanship with a pistol.
During the ceremony, Mueller received additional awards for excellence in pistol marksmanship and academics.
Prior to starting with the Easton Police Department, Mueller served as a service technician II for ADT Commercial. Following his graduation, Mueller must successfully complete a threemonth field training program with Easton Police Department to satisfy the requirements for full certification as a Maryland law enforcement officer.
After the graduation ceremony, Deputy Chief Gregory Wright congratulated Mueller on a job well done. Deputy Chief Wright said, "We're excited to have Patrolman Mueller join our team. He's going to have a positive impact on our community."

title: Tractor-trailer driver charged with assault in alleged hit-and-run
author: Konner Metz
content:
Tractor-trailer driver charged with assault in alleged hit-and-run

 August 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 228
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Police arrested a tractor-trailer driver on an assault charge last week after he allegedly hit a car three times at a red light in Easton.David Dziergowski, 33, of Glen Burnie, was charged Thursday with first-degree assault, reckless endangerment and five traffic citations.
According to court documents, just after 7:30 a.m. that morning, police met with a woman who said her car was hit three times by a tractor-trailer going eastbound on Route 50 at the Dover Road intersection. She said she was stopped at the intersection's red light.
The woman told police that the tractor-trailer hit her rear bumper once, reversed and hit her car again and then struck her car for a third time, according to court records.
The court documents do not provide details of the events leading up to the incident.
The tractor-trailer driver, later identified as Dziergowski, continued driving when the light turned green and did not attempt to stop, the woman told police.
Easton police wrote in charging documents that "dispatch (had) received several calls in reference to the same tractor trailer driving all over the roadway."
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Cambridge Police Department stopped the tractor-trailer stopped on Route 50 in Cambridge. Easton police arrived on scene and arrested Dziergowski around 8:30 a.m.
Dziergowski was released on his own recognizance Thursday. A preliminary hearing in Talbot County District Court is set for Sept. 16.

title: Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department marks 100 years with parade Saturday
author: Konner Metz
content:
Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department marks 100 years with parade Saturday

 July 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 619
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TILGHMAN ISLAND — It began in 1925 as a wagon with tanks, and now, the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department is celebrating its centennial.Serving residents in the waterfront village, the fire department has persisted through many ups and downs, president Jesse Gottleib said.
"So many small companies don't see 100 years because of not only funding, but more so because of lack of participation, lack of volunteers for the department," he said.
Such challenges are true in Tilghman Island — there are around 30 volunteers, 12 of them firefighters, the president noted. And while money is always a challenge, Gottleib said the department is extremely active in hosting community fundraisers.
The key cog in the fire department's survival and success has been community support, said Gottleib and his mother Linda, the department's secretary.
"We would've never thought it," he said of reaching the 100-year mark. "And I think the reason is because people in this side of St. Michaels down, they realize that we're gonna be there when they need it."
To celebrate the milestone, Tilghman Island firefighters are hosting a parade on Saturday. It begins at 10 a.m. with a fair atmosphere, including food, live music and games. At 11:30 a.m., kids will hop in fire gear to compete in a junior firefighters competition, spraying hoses at targets.
"It might help them to say, 'I wanna join,'" Linda Gottleib said.
The parade begins near the Knapps Narrows Bridge at 1 p.m. A friendly firefighters' competition will follow, and later that evening, the department plans to host a private ceremony to honor some key life members.
On Wednesday at the fire house, the Gottleibs pointed out some of the unsung heroes of the fire department. Dewayne Stewart, a line officer for 36 years, and Billy Lednum, a line officer for 31 years, have been integral to the company's success.
"You'll see a hurt in the fire department when those two are gone," Jesse Gottleib said.
The Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department doesn't go on a ton of calls — sometimes two to 10 per month, Gottleib said. But the department often provides mutual aid or helps with water rescues. Most recently, the Tilghman fire boat assisted state searchers with a rescue in Broad Creek on July 4.
In addition to the fire boat, the fire station houses multiple fire trucks and a Talbot County ambulance. Last year, the station donated a fire engine to a Tennessee fire department dealing with damages from Hurricane Helene.
Jesse Gottleib, 43, is the youngest sitting president and has been a member since he turned 16 in 1997. His mother joined in 1999 and has served a number of roles, including secretary, president and board member.
In recent days, they've been scouring through old newspaper clips and photos to create collages for Saturday's festivities. Some photos show the fire station in its three different buildings, the current one built in 2005.
It's a family affair for Jesse Gottleib, as it is for many of the volunteers. He recalled once ditching a baseball game — while actively manning left field — just to watch the fire trucks pull out of the station when he was about 9 years old.
"First game that we had down here at Tilghman school, the fire siren went off," he said. "And (my mom) and my dad were standing there and were like, 'Is he leaving?' And I ran across the field to go to the fence."
Saturday will be a chance to reflect on some of those fun memories, interact with the community and honor longtime volunteer firefighters and administrators. Gottleib said the dedication of volunteers has been remarkable.
"Their time is appreciated here," Gottleib said. "I feel like they play a key role into getting us to where we are now at 100 years." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Eastern Shore fire companies aid areas affected by Hurricane Helene
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Eastern Shore fire companies aid areas affected by Hurricane Helene

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Fire companies throughout the Eastern Shore have stepped up to assist with disaster areas affected by Hurricane Helene. Together they have donated fire and EMS equipment to first responders in need.When Hurricane Helene occurred, some of the members of the Oxford and Tilghman Fire Company felt the need to assist in any way possible. After watching several YouTube and Facebook videos circulating online showing the conditions in the affected areas, members of the fire company came up with the idea to assist first responders in Tennessee by donating some of their equipment.
Graham Norbury, chief of the Oxford Fire Company, said regardless of location, fire departments seek to help each other and anyone else in need.
"We do a lot of mutual aid to other departments in the area and elsewhere," Norbury said. "The Brotherhood of the Fire Services is pretty tight. When we see someone in need, then we want to be able to help any way we can."
According to Norbury, most volunteer fire companies replace equipment on a reasonably regular basis. The Oxford Fire Department had several pieces of equipment delivered to them in a short amount of time including a new ambulance and a new fire truck.
Norbury said they put word out through the Maryland State Firefighters Association that they wanted to help by donating equipment. News traveled fast, and Bill Killan, member from a fire department in Tennessee, contacted Norbury and helped coordinate a drop off with a fire department in Butler, Tennessee.
Tim Kearns, president of Oxford Fire Company, was one of the volunteers to deliver essential equipment to support disaster relief efforts. The drive to Tennessee was over 500 miles and was shared among four different drivers.
"It was important because the volunteer system works on mutual aid, so when someone is overwhelmed, we come to help," Kearns said. "And that's what we did, only they're just a little farther away than most."
Kearns said they made two stops to deliver equipment. The first was at an agricultural supply in Bristol, Virginia, which is on the border of Tennessee.
There they offloaded a skid brush unit, which is a pre-assembled piece of equipment that can fit into the back of a pickup truck and turn that pickup truck into a brush truck for fighting land fires and small house fires.
According to Kearns, the brush skid unit was the most valuable piece of equipment they gave because the roads in the area were so badly destroyed that any vehicle would have a difficult time navigating through.
With the brush skid unit the local fire department could use a heavy four-wheel drive pickup truck to help fight fires that occur.
The second stop was a campground called Faith Camp. Kearns said the camp was owned by Darren Clark, a member of the Elk Mills Poga Volunteer Fire Company, who had come from Florida to create the beautiful natural area.
Currently, Clark has been assisting people who have been displaced by the hurricane. Clark has designated his campground as a satellite fire station.
According to Kearns, everyone is trying to do their part, regardless of location. Contributing Maryland fire companies include Oxford, Tilghman, Cordova, Easton, Queen Anne Hillsboro, Suddlersville and Hollywood.
"It took a lot of folks to coordinate and manhandle the transfer of this equipment, from the paperwork, insurances, transfer of titles and tags, to all of the logistics here, there and in between," Kearns said. "Our Chief Engineer Stacy Dulin and Assistant Chief Engineers Mike Greenwak and Tom Bixler assured the equipment was capable of the 500-mile trip. Oxford Ferry loaned the heavy trailer." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot County places burn ban
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County places burn ban

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 244
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council has enacted a burn ban as a dry spell has rendered the county without rain for weeks.Council members held a special meeting Friday morning to pass the burn ban, which prohibits all "open-air burning." Effective Friday, it will last for 30 days, unless it is extended or terminated.
A county press release defined open-air burning as "burning any material in the open or in a receptacle other than a furnace, … including use of fireworks, sparklers, or sparkling devices."
Brian LeCates, county director of emergency services, said in a memorandum to the county that the request for a burn ban came from volunteer fire chiefs. The county's burn ban committee requested the council enact the 30-day ban.
"Their concern is that we have had abnormally dry conditions with no appreciable precipitation in the weather forecast," LeCates wrote.
LeCates noted that the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is "currently classifying Talbot County as having abnormally dry conditions."
"Looking at our weather forecast, we do not show any significant precipitation in the near future," he wrote. "The Maryland Department of Natural Resources Forest Service has listed our area as highly susceptible to fire due to these conditions."
Last week, Dorchester and Wicomico counties each enacted burn bans due to drought-like conditions. On Oct. 22, Wicomico County voted to extend its burn ban.
Talbot County most recently enacted a burn ban on July 21, which was placed due to similar dry conditions and a significant heat wave.

title: Easton officials weigh in on Complete Streets study, pedestrian safety
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton officials weigh in on Complete Streets study, pedestrian safety

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 640
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Town officials on Monday discussed ongoing efforts to shore up pedestrian and bike safety, including a comprehensive study on the town's roads and streets.In a workshop, Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh updated the Town Council on an ongoing study into street safety conducted by the engineering firm Wallace Montgomery.
The study, known as Complete Streets, aims to create a manual for Easton outlining which types of roads and streets prioritize certain modes of transportation, such as walking, biking and driving. The study itself will not make road safety improvements, though officials see it as a guide to initiating those upgrades.
Those leading the study are in the process of meeting with local businesses and safety stakeholders to gather feedback on how best to define and classify different streets. Larry Marcus, an associate for Wallace Montgomery, said some classifications include residential, collector, commercial urban and commercial industrial streets.
Roads are further defined by land use: downtown, residential, commercial and industrial, Marcus said. The categories roads fall into will determine the study's recommendation on which sidewalk, bike lane or vehicular improvements should be taken.
Van Emburgh added that the manual will make it easier for the town to require certain road safety steps be taken when residential or commercial developers apply for site plan approval. Moving forward, the town will be less likely to give developers breaks or reliefs from ensuring private roads are up to town standards, he said.
"It's a very practical document that I can think of a lot of different ways it will be used," Van Emburgh said of the Complete Streets study. Guidelines will be drafted and applied to a map of town roads in November.
During the nearly hourlong workshop, many specific pressure points in town were raised, including Port Street and North Washington Street.
Council President Don Abbatiello said telephone poles in the middle of sidewalks on Port Street make it difficult for people to walk safely. Council members Maureen Curry and the Rev. Elmer Davis echoed the concern about the street.
"It's gonna (be) awfully difficult to make Port Street pedestrian friendly unless we make some serious improvements," Curry said.
On North Washington Street, sidewalks are expected to be added. Van Emburgh said the town has funds in its budget already for survey and design work for North Washington Street from Easton Hardware (near the Creamery Lane intersection) to Gay's Seafood (close to the stoplight at the Easton Parkway, or Route 322).
The Complete Streets guidance will help determine the specific bike, pedestrian and vehicular safety measures taken for the North Washington Street project.
Pedestrian and bike safety has been an ongoing discussion among town leaders, residents and local advocates. Earlier this month, worries about safety on Route 50 — a state-operated highway — were raised after a man on a bike was struck and killed.
Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery shared concerns that the town would sacrifice the efficient flow of vehicular traffic in order to prioritize walking and biking. He said many of the older residents in his ward — including the west side of Easton Parkway — aren't "interested in bicycling to downtown."
"Automobile transportation is pretty much what everybody uses in order to get into the center of town," Montgomery said. "So I'm very concerned about our sacrificing the flow of single-occupancy vehicles, sacrificing it to other things, that for my ward, don't do any good at all by way of mobility."
Heather Grant, executive director of Talbot Thrive, a local nonprofit that advocates for pedestrian and bike safety, refuted Montgomery's stance. In a statement, she said residents who "don't want to drive everywhere" deserve "equal access to safe infrastructure."
"Some council members who mention the difficulties in traveling by car during school drop off and pick up should consider that if we make our streets safer for kids to walk and bike to school, we can reduce vehicle congestion," Grant wrote. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Federalsburg Police Department welcomes new officer
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Federalsburg Police Department welcomes new officer

 June 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 337
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERARLSBURG – The Federalsburg Police Department welcomed Officer Chandler Dyott after he graduated from the Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy on June 11.Dyott has been with the department since December, participating in ride-alongs while he learned the responsibilities of what he needed to became a full time police officer, the department said.
Dyott, from Easton, worked two years as a correctional officer in Talbot County before heading to the academy, but he said he always wanted to be a police officer.
"Ever since I was little, I wanted to be a cop," Dyott said. "But when I got out of high school, you can't be a cop until you're 21. So, when I got out of high school, I thought, 'I'll join Talbot County Corrections.'
"That way in corrections, it teaches you how to talk to people, interact with the people. Just because they got locked up and you see them in the jail, you realize they're not a bad person. They're just people like us."
Dyott, now 21, is looking forward to being an officer in Federalsburg. So far during his required 240 hours of field training, Dyott has enjoyed introducing himself to the community.
Dyott wants the community to know he will treat them with respect.
"I'm going to be fair, 100%," Dyott said. "I believe in respect goes a long way. You respect me, I'm going to respect you anytime… No matter what, I'm going to be fair, and I'm going to try to step up on community policing."
Lt. Michelle Schuerholz said the police department is happy to have such a young officer on staff.
"We're proud to welcome Officer Dyott to our department," Schuerholz said. "Being so young, he brings a strong commitment to community and public safety, and we're confident he will be a great asset to both our department and the residents we serve. We look forward to seeing the positive impact Officer Dyott will make in our community. He comes from correctional, and he had a good reputation there, and I think he'll do well here."

title: Reporting when rumors spread faster than facts
author: Staff Writer
content:
Reporting when rumors spread faster than facts

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 168
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A recent uptick in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement arrests has posed a challenge for our newsroom.Reports of ICE activity spread quickly on social media, but with little publicly accessible information from official sources, it became difficult to determine the extent of what was happening in Mid-Shore communities. Rumors circulated faster than verifiable facts, and many details remained inaccessible.
As a result, the newsroom pulled out some old-fashioned, on-the-ground reporting techniques.
This week, reporter Konner Metz knocked on doors in a small town on the Maryland-Delaware border with a large immigrant population. He spoke with residents to learn first-hand how the community was grappling immigration enforcement activity.
Konner's story, which you can read below, captures what that community is experiencing, but it is just one part of a larger, still unfolding story of ICE activity on the Eastern Shore.
Also in today's newsletter: the Greensboro Historical Society has found a new home, Doverbrook Apartments push back move-in dates to comply with HUD needs and more.
Thanks, as always, for reading.
— Wendy Weitzel 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chester woman sentenced in 2024 multi-vehicle crash on Bay Bridge
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Chester woman sentenced in 2024 multi-vehicle crash on Bay Bridge

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 558
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The woman responsible for a 20-plus vehicle crash on the Bay Bridge has been sentenced in Queen Anne's County Circuit Court.On July 8, Gwendolyn Persina, 49, of Chester, was sentenced to three years of jail time with all but 315 days suspended, which is the time Persina has served in jail from the time of her arrest.
According to the Office of the State's Attorney, Persina was sentenced for causing a life-threatening injury to another while operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. This was the most serious charge that Persina was charged with and the maximum penalty for the offense is three years in jail and a $5,000 fine.
Persina was also sentenced to five years of supervised probation, ordered to have a mental health evaluation and complete any recommended treatment, to abstain from alcohol and drugs, to get an alcohol evaluation and complete any recommended treatment.
Persina pleaded guilty by way of an Alford guilty plea, by not admitting guilt but by acknowledging that the state had sufficient evidence that she could be found guilty of the charge.
The case was prosecuted by Lance G. Richardson, state's attorney for Queen Anne's County, assisted by Carolynn Grammas, assistant state's attorney from Anne Arundel County, appointed as a special prosecutor for the case.
The state said the sentence fell within the recommended sentence range as calculated by the Maryland Sentencing Guidelines, which recommended a sentence ranging from six months to three years of active incarceration.
Persina's conviction was based on a Jan. 27, 2024, incident when at approximately 7:46 a.m. she was operating a Honda Civic passenger vehicle at a high rate of speed in heavy fog traveling westbound on the Bay Bridge on the Queen Anne's County portion of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge. Persina rear-ended another vehicle, which disabled her vehicle in the travel portion of the bridge, resulting in a 23-vehicle chain reaction collision.
The collision resulted in a victim having his arm severed from his body. The man's arm was unable to be reattached. Persina suffered serious injuries in the collision and was transported to the hospital.
Through the course of their investigation, police determined at the time of the collision, Persina's blood alcohol content was between 0.24 and 0.27 — three times greater than the legal limit.
Although the accident occurred on Jan. 27, 2024, Persina wasn't criminally charged until August 2024. The state reported the delay in formally charging Persina was due to the incredible amount of vehicle data that had to be reviewed for the more than 20 vehicles involved.
According to State's Attorney Lance Richardson's chief of staff, Rob Penny, medical records had to be obtained and then the large volume of records had to be reviewed.
Additionally, a large volume of other evidence, and information from witnesses, had to be reviewed and analyzed. All of this investigative information took months to be collected and examined, Penny said.
Once Persina was formally charged, she was arrested and held without bail. Her attorneys ultimately filed a notice of incompetency to stand trial due to her inability to assist in her defense or an inability to understand the nature of the proceedings.
Experts from both the state and the defense examined Persina. After many delays, the state doctor from the Maryland Department of Health deemed Persina competent to stand trial on July 2.
The Office of the Public Defender represented Persina.

title: Pilot dies in plane crash near Easton
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Pilot dies in plane crash near Easton

 July 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Officials with the Maryland State Police confirmed the pilot of a small aircraft that crashed into the Tred Avon River near Easton Tuesday morning was killed in the incident.Robert Eugene Merlini, 56, of Annapolis was identified as the victim of the crash by MSP Tuesday evening.
The Merlini called in an engine failure before crashing into the river at around 9:30 a.m., the Federal Aviation Administration said in a statement to The Star Democrat. The pilot was the only person on board.
Merlini was doing work with the Maryland Advanced Development Laboratory's University Research Foundation, according to officials at the scene.
"It's a sad day for not only the aviation community, but for the scientific community," said David Abrams, the communication director for the Maryland Department of the Environment.
The FAA said the aircraft is a twin-engine Cessna 402. The plane was 30 years old, according to MSP.
According to David Heidhausen, president at the University Research Foundation, the plane was used for advanced research and development. Heidhausen said the projects included enhanced flight vision systems, cameras in the nose and helmet-mounted displays.
Heidhausen said Merlini was not developing research but relocating the plane in a "ferry flight" when he crashed.
According to a preliminary investigation, the aircraft took off shortly before 9 a.m. from Tipton Airport at Fort Meade before crashing into the Tred Avon River, MSP said. Police believe the pilot was headed toward the Easton Airport when the crash occurred.
The Easton air traffic control tower reported the incident to the emergency dispatch center, as did witnesses who observed the crash.
The FAA said it will work with the National Transportation Safety Board to conduct an investigation.
Merlini's identity was released following the notification of his next of kin. Merlini was recovered from the water and transported to the shore, where EMS personnel declared him deceased at the scene. He will be transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner for autopsy.
Liz Underhill, who lives along the Tred Avon, received a call from a neighbor who had seen the plane in the water. Underhill got in her boat and attempted to assess the situation. She saw the plane in the water, but no one was out of the plane.
There were numerous other people in boats trying to help.
Among the agencies on the scene were the Coast Guard, Talbot County Sheriff, Maryland State Police, Maryland Natural Resources Police, Easton Volunteer Fire Department, St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department, Anne Arundel County Fire Department and Talbot County Emergency Services.
Konner Metz contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 39 indicted, accused of drug-trafficking ring
author: Staff Writer
content:
39 indicted, accused of drug-trafficking ring

 December 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thirty-nine people accused of a drug-trafficking ring on the Eastern Shore were indicted following a five-month combined law enforcement investigation.Wicomico Narcotics, a collaborative effort between the Maryland Department of State Police, the Fruitland Police Department, the Office of the State's Attorney for Wicomico County, and the Drug Enforcement Administration, began a covert investigation in spring 2024 that culminated in the indictment of 39 people involved in a large-scale drug trafficking operation in Wicomico County.
Maryland State Police joined more than two dozen local, state and federal law enforcement agencies in dismantling the sale and distribution of illegal drugs, including cocaine and fentanyl, throughout Wicomico, Dorchester and Baltimore counties.
In August 2024, Wicomico Narcotics and the Drug Enforcement Administration Salisbury Regional Office served multiple search and seizure warrants in Wicomico, Dorchester, and Baltimore counties.
These warrants yielded more than 2,500 grams of suspected cocaine and nearly 30 grams of fentanyl as well as other felony narcotics, 14 firearms, and four vehicles that allegedly were used to transport the drugs.
Wicomico Narcotics received funding for this investigation from the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy and the Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Forces. Wicomico Narcotics is a designated Washington/Baltimore HIDTA-funded initiative.
Assisting agencies include the Drug Enforcement Administration, Maryland State Police, Somerset County Sheriff's Office, Worcester Sheriff's Office, Wicomico Sheriff's Office, Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, Talbot County Sheriff's Office, Kent County Sheriff's Office, Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Strike Force 7, Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office, Eastern Shore Information Center, Homeland Security Investigations, Salisbury Police Department, Ocean City Police Department, and the Maryland Department of Transportation Authority Police.
This operation was supported in part by the Maryland Criminal Intelligence Network. The Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy supplies grant funding and strategic assistance to MCIN member sites. These resources enable the identification, disruption and dismantling of criminal organizations through enhanced inter-agency collaboration and data sharing.
