title: Mid-Shore organization pioneers a 'hub' of resources for victims of domestic violence
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Mid-Shore organization pioneers a 'hub' of resources for victims of domestic violence

 December 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For more than four decades, the Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence has been at the forefront of advocating for victims on the Mid-Shore. With a new program, the organization is now planning to assist far beyond.The nonprofit for victims of domestic violence has taken steps to advance resource access for clients using the Geographic Information System program, a mapping dashboard providing a free one-stop shop for essential resources for victims.
Jeanne Yeager, executive director for Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence, said rural clients face various barriers to receiving care. During the pandemic the barriers to care were more apparent and Mid-Shore Council sought to find alternative solutions to helping their clients.
This initiative, she said, revolutionizes the way domestic violence victims access vital resources.
"I was really mindful of coming out of COVID, because everything we did at Mid-Shore was very one-on-one, personalized — our case management, our meetings, our support groups, everything — and we would say, 'Oh, well, we'll do an online group sometime.' Well, 'that sometime' became tomorrow," Yeager said. "So it normalized using technology, and I think there's no turning back."
The barriers faced by victims in rural communities include limited employment opportunities, spotty cell service, transportation, lack of affordable housing, and social and geographic isolation.
The GIS program operates with a holistic Chesapeake Crisis-to-Self-Sufficiency model, providing comprehensive services and case management from crisis through transition to self-sufficiency.
According to Yeager, the program initially focused on mapping out housing resources in five counties in Maryland. The data team began working with case managers and staff to compile a list of resources that clients frequently inquire about, such as childcare and pet care.
From there it continued to expand.
Kazeem Anifowoshe, GIS senior data analyst, said the project went from the initial five counties to nine counties, and the team decided to create a website as a "hub" for the project. Now, this hub is used by 25 agencies and has expanded resources to include nearby pro bono and legal services across Maryland through a partnership with the Access to Justice organization.
"When people kind of think of victim services, there's kind of like a formula that a lot of people have been doing for 20 to 40 plus years at their organization that works for them," Anifowoshe said. "But again, we're just trying to make things easier the best way we know how, by mapping things."
According to Yeager, the GIS program has been earning notable recognition, such as the prestigious Domestic Shelters Purple Ribbon Award.
The organization's GIS Hub integrates data from various sources, including popular rental property platforms/affordable housing, childcare resources, medical facilities, grocery stores, law enforcement agencies, court houses and local social service organizations.
Pamela Caudill Jordan, program evaluator for the GIS Hub, said she hopes to encourage other organizations to adopt a comprehensive model where the focus is not just on crisis intervention but on helping survivors achieve long-term stability and self-sufficiency. For Caudill Jordan, having access to tools such as the GIS Hub can make the work of advocates for victims easier and more efficient.
According to Yeager and Anifowoshe, the goal is to get the GIS Hub more widely adopted and used by other organizations, going beyond Maryland and, hopefully, one day nationwide.
"We know what victims need," Yeager said. "We ought to work with victims, and we're making this available. Let's see where we're going with it." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: St. Michaels VFD places new engine into service
author: Mike Detmer; mdetmer@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels VFD places new engine into service

 August 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Detmer; mdetmer@chespub.com | Page: A3 | Section: News 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - A brand new piece of fire equipment is in service for the residents of St. Michaels and Talbot County.St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department's Engine 45, an engine tanker, was put into service on July 27 and has already run calls, including pumping water for the response to an attic fire in town last week.Engine 45 is a 2023 E-One Cyclone, featuring a 1,035-gallon water tank, Cummins L9 engine, Hale QMAX pump, Harrison Hydraulic Generator, Whelen and Firetech lighting, and an Arkon Electric Monitor.St. Michaels VFD President Chris Thomas said the new engine has a larger water tank, a necessity in the rural environs of St. Michaels and elsewhere the engine will serve in the area, often not near hydrants.The new engine carries 1,000 feet of 5-inch supply hose, 500 feet of 3-inch hose, five attack lines, a Blitzfire Monitor, a battery powered fan and work lights, and a full complement of firefighting tools.Engine 45 replaced Engine 49, a 2009 engine, in the top of SMVFD's rotation as the "first due" engine. Engine 45 was purchased to replace Engine 48, a 1990 engine that served the department for 33 years, and was placed in reserve in the department's fleet.Thomas said the older engine had exceeded the expected 30-year service window, and that while it is still serviceable, parts for repairs are getting harder to find and the apparatus lacks updated safety features.Typically, the department would sell the engine, Thomas said, but it is being retained as a precaution due to the lengthy lead time to fill orders that has become the norm in the fire apparatus manufacturing industry.Engine 45 was designed by the SMFD Engine committee and purchased through Patriot Fire in Grasonville. The engine cost $718,850 and carries well over $200,000 of tools, hose, radios and breathing apparatus.The RFP for the new engine was put out in 2021, and the committee moved swiftly to finalize the purchase, and the efficient of the process led to the relatively rapid acquisition and placement into service, Thomas said.The funding for the fire apparatus came from a variety of sources. "It's a combination of fundraising efforts and money that we get from the county, town and state," Thomas said."The department thanks the generous residents and businesses who helped make this purchase happen through their donations and support over the past few years," the fire department said in a statement about the new engine.Thomas, who is in his third year as the department's president, said the department's board does a good job of strategic budgeting for future equipment replacements and maintenance of the fire station.Fundraising efforts include barbecue chicken dinners, a fund drive and a rotation of other types of campaigns, but he said the department's pit beef and pit turkey offerings were particularly tasty. "I think that it is off the charts it's phenomenal," he said.SMVFD has around 70 members, and of those about half are fire and EMS personnel.Just like fire companies across the country, paid and volunteer alike, SMVFD faces a manpower crunch.Thomas said the nature of the demographics of the St. Michaels area poses a challenge for the department, as many residents are retirees, although the talent pool of retirees helps ensure the administrative part of the community organization is well staffed.As far as fire and EMS personnel, Thomas said, "We're hurting just like everyone else." Still, the department forges on as the status quo of consistent calls for emergency response continues, and the department continues to plan and save for future acquisitions.Thomas said the brush truck and tanker truck are both in the latter stages of their service, and the department continues its work on that front too, continuing to raise and secure funds and being prepared for what is now a three-to five-year wait time on new equipment.The newest member of the SMVFD fleet isn't the first with the title of "Engine 45" - the previous 45 was an engine with an open cab and tailboards that volunteers ride on, braving the heat and cold depending on the season, before carrying out their emergency response.The equipment has changed, but the fundamental aspects of the job have not. Engine 45 sits in the right hand of the middle bay of the firehouse, waiting to carry to the volunteers to the next call. 
 
 Caption: MIKE DETMER/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department President Chris Thomas gives a thumbs up as he pulls Engine 45 out of the engine bay. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge woman pleads guilty to altering evidence in Sidetracked Saloon shooting
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge woman pleads guilty to altering evidence in Sidetracked Saloon shooting

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Cambridge woman was handed a three-year sentence after pleading guilty to altering physical evidence in the shooting death of 23-year-old Antonio Smith.Judge Broughton Earnest handed down the sentence following a plea hearing on May 22. Chadnee Harris, 33, will serve 236 days followed by one year of probation, with the remainder of the sentence suspended.
Harris originally faced charges of of acting as an accessory after the fact of first- and second-degree murder and acting as an accessory after a felony for the same incident. The charges were amended to one count of altering physical evidence.
The charge stems from a shooting in the parking lot of Sidetracked Saloon in Easton on Sept. 30. Officers who responded to the incident just before 2 a.m. found Smith in the parking lot suffering from a gunshot wound to the head. Smith was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, where he was pronounced dead.
On May 20, Kevron Chase, 35, of Cambridge, pled guilty to first-degree murder for Smith's death. A sentencing hearing for Chase is set for July 19.
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, in charging documents, police said the bar's security camera footage showed Chase and Harris standing between two cars near the entrance of the bar and Smith approaching the two.
According to the documents, Chase pulled a handgun from his waistband area and pointed it at Smith. Chase put the handgun back toward his waistband area and then appeared to hand the gun to Harris, police said.
After a fight broke out, Harris reportedly walked toward the men. A crowd that had gathered quickly dispersed. According to the charging documents, Smith appeared to duck behind a car and Chase walked toward Smith, pointing a handgun at him. The officer who reviewed the footage wrote in charging documents that they saw a muzzle flash from the gun and Smith collapse in between two cars.
At Chase's plea hearing on May 20, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said Chase then left the scene and drove to Cambridge, where he disposed of the handgun in the Choptank River.
Chase and Harris were later found during a traffic stop on Race Street in Cambridge. They were both detained by police. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: American Legion Post 77 donates $40,000 to local organizations and in scholarships
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
American Legion Post 77 donates $40,000 to local organizations and in scholarships

 July 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 299
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Approximately $40,000 was donated in scholarships and to local organizations — including local volunteer fire companies, children's organizations and churches — on Saturday morning by American Legion Post 77.Post 77 Judge Advocate Walter Black said Post 77 feels proud to be able to donate this money.
"It's consistent with our mission of assisting veterans and their families, and children and youth, and the community at large," he said. "We feel very good about that."
Black said making these donations addresses the needs of the community, living up to the Post 77's responsibilities as an American Legion organization. He said a lot of the money for these donations, which Post 77 makes annually, is raised through the slot machines located at the post.
Donations were made to volunteer fire departments in Talbot County, nearly 20 churches and a variety of other organizations, such as the Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers, the Talbot Senior Center, the Frederick Douglass Honor Society and the Neighborhood Service Center.
Representatives from these organizations came out Saturday morning to the American Legion to accept the donations.
Black said the event was wonderful and all the recipients were "very pleased."
According to a statement from one recipient organization, Channel Marker, which offers mental health and wellness support, this donation will help improve the wellbeing of its clients' lives.
Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers Executive Director Cristy Morrell said the event Saturday was "lovely."
"They support such amazing organizations in our community," she said. "And they're not always organizations that I think people are aware of. And so, that they include us in with those organizations is very humbling and we're very honored."
Morrell said the "generous" donation will be used for enrichment programming and tuition assistance at the Children's Center's Trappe and Easton locations.
"I'm just honored that they consider us a worthwhile cause," she said.

title: Rider trial postponed; bench warrant issued
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Rider trial postponed; bench warrant issued

 March 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 476
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Although the trial was set to begin Monday morning, Fred "Trey" Rider III will not be tried for arson, malicious destruction of property, reckless endangerment and other charges this week.Rider is accused of setting his house afire in November 2022.
At a status hearing Monday morning, Judge Thomas G. Ross stated that Rider had been voluntarily admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital and issued a bench warrant for Rider's failure to appear in court that morning.
A tentative trial date has been scheduled for Aug. 19 at 9 a.m., according to the Maryland Electronic Courts website.
According to court documents, the bench warrant can be executed once Rider has been released from Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The $20,000 unsecured bond that Rider had been released on in February 2023 also was revoked Monday.
Rider's attorney Stephanie Shipley filed a motion Friday to postpone the trial, according to court documents. In the motion, it states that Rider had been admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital "on an emergency basis for acute medical issues, with further transfer planned to an inpatient facility in the State of Maryland."
On the same day, the State's Attorney's Office issued its position on the defendant's motion to postpone the trial. According to court documents, the state's consent to the postponement was contingent upon "further appropriate medical documentation."
Shipley presented an updated letter from Johns Hopkins Hospital at the status hearing Monday morning.
The 15 charges Rider faces stem from a Nov. 24, 2022, incident where firefighters responded to a fire at Rider's home at 27930 Peach Orchard Road in Easton.
Deputy State Fire Marshal Shayne McKinney, who investigated the fire and authored the incident narrative, wrote in charging documents that a Talbot County deputy responding to the scene informed him Rider had possibly attempted suicide that evening based on evidence found within the home. Rider had attempted suicide in the past as well, according to the deputy.
According to court documents, a person connected to Rider told officials he had called Rider several times that evening, adding that Rider had clearly indicated to him that he was attempting suicide and wanted to be left alone. Charging documents indicated that Rider told the person that he lit the house on fire during their conversation.
Rider was located a short distance away from the home and transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton for emergency care.
Through investigation, officials identified the fire as an act of human intervention with an open flame, classifying the cause of fire as incendiary.
According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put emergency services personnel, specifically more than 45 firefighters who responded, in danger as they suppressed the fire.
Rider was arrested in February 2023 and released on a $20,000 unsecured bond.
In April 2023, Rider entered a plea of not criminally responsible by reason of insanity, according to documents filed in court. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Body sits in Greensboro yard for hours due to traffic delay
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Body sits in Greensboro yard for hours due to traffic delay

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 232
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — On June 22 at about 1:57 p.m., the Greensboro Police Department were dispatched to 110 Maple Ave. in Greensboro in reference to an unattended death.According to a statement from the Town of Greensboro, a male was found lying face up on the stairs of his apartment.
When EMS arrived, they moved the man, who was not identified, from the residence and stairs down to the front yard area near the driveway so they could conduct a full analysis. He was pronounced dead at about 2:06 p.m., the town said.
Greensboro Police Department requested dispatch to notify a forensic investigator and have them respond to the location.
EMS then placed two sheets over the man, preventing him from being viewed by the public. The forensic investigator arrived on the scene at about 4:30 p.m., then they consulted the medical examiner's office in Baltimore that an autopsy would be needed.
The forensic investigator contacted Springbok to transport the body to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore. The estimated time of arrival was initially an hour and a half, but due to a 16-mile Bay Bridge back-up, the transport was delayed and didn't arrive until 7 p.m.
EMS, the forensic investigator and the Greensboro Police Department offered to moved the man out of the environment, back inside the residence or place him in a body bag. The family declined all options, the town said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police fatally shoot Cambridge man Thursday evening
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Police fatally shoot Cambridge man Thursday evening

 September 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Caroline 
 
 406
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Thursday evening, a Cambridge police officer fatally shot a man who the police department said was armed with a knife and threatening advances toward officers.According to a release from the Cambridge Police Department, a Cambridge Police officer assigned to the Patrol Division shot the man multiple times after the man "advanced on officers" with the knife. The man was transported by Maryland State Police Aviation to Tidal Health Peninsula Regional Medical Center in Salisbury, where he later died.
The man, described in the release as a "30-year-old Caucasian male from Cambridge," has not been publicly identified. The police officer who shot the man has also not been publicly identified.
According to the release, shortly after 5 p.m. Thursday, officers responded to the Deep Harbor development around Seaway Lane and Riverview Wharf in reference to a report of a male subject chasing a female subject with a knife.
When officers arrived, they encountered a male subject who was armed with a knife, police said. Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said three officers were on the scene.
"Officers on scene attempted to deescalate the situation and have the subject drop the knife," the release said. "The subject refused and advanced on officers. Officers gave warnings for the subject to stop as they were attempting to retreat."
Police said the subject continued to engage and approach the officers, leading to one officer shooting the man.
"Officers immediately rendered life saving measures to the subject awaiting EMS arrival," the release said. "After EMS arrived, the subject was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge prior to being flown by Maryland State Police Aviation to Tidal Health Peninsula Regional Medical Center in Salisbury."
According to Todd, this is Cambridge's first fatal police shooting in approximately 15 years.
The incident is being investigated by the Maryland attorney general's office's Independent Investigations Division, which investigates all officer-involved fatalities in the state. Todd said the officer who discharged their weapon has been placed on paid administrative leave until the investigation is complete.
Todd said press releases and body-worn camera footage will be released to the public as part of the transparency process.
"I think the main thing I want to say is my condolences to the family of the subject that succumbed to his injuries. Unfortunately, it's a sad situation," Todd said. "And speaking with some of the family, I just feel there needs to be thoughts and prayers kept for them as well."
This report may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Stranded boater rescued by MSP aviation crew
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Stranded boater rescued by MSP aviation crew

 October 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TAYLORS ISLAND - A Maryland State Police aviation crew helped rescue a 22-yearold man early Thursday morning after the boat he was operating ran aground, stranding him on a small island in Dorchester County.MSP's Trooper 7, which is based at St. Mary's Airport, was dispatched to the area of Taylors Island around 12:40 a.m. Thursday for a report of a missing boater.The request came from the Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department after they had exhausted efforts searching for the subject by boat.Shortly after Trooper 7 arrived in the area, they located the victim in his boat that had run aground in a marshy area. Trooper 7 guided ground rescue crews to the victim location, but conditions proved to be inaccessible by foot or boat.MSP's Trooper 2, which is based at Joint Base Andrews, was dispatched at about 1:20 a.m. to assist with a hoist extraction and take over rescue operations.Once overhead, the pilots on Trooper 2 hovered the Leonardo AW-139 helicopter approximately 50 feet above the marshy terrain while a trooper/paramedic was lowered below to assess the victim.The victim was extracted utilizing the air-lift rescue vest. The trooper/paramedic and victim were hoisted back into the aircraft.Trooper 2 then landed at a landing zone established by the Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department, where the victim was transferred to ground paramedics for a secondary evaluation.The victim ultimately did not require treatment or transport.The Maryland State Police Aviation Command has served Maryland citizens since 1970 and operates a fleet of 10 AW-139 helicopters from seven bases throughout the State. Each aircraft provides coverage 24/7/365 to Maryland residents and visitors.The MSPAC missions include medevac, law enforcement, search and rescue, homeland security and disaster assessment.The success of the missions relies heavily on the cooperative efforts of local fire, rescue, EMS, law enforcement agencies and partners at the U.S. Coast Guard and the U.S. Park Police.

title: Glen Burnie man sentenced for role in Eastern Shore Hospital Center escape
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Glen Burnie man sentenced for role in Eastern Shore Hospital Center escape

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 633
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Glen Burnie man will serve 12 years for helping a patient escape the Eastern Shore Hospital Center in August 2023.Israel Labastida Jr., 20, was sentenced Friday to 25 years, with all but eight years suspended, for first-degree assault, followed by 10 years, with all but five years suspended, for use of a firearm during a felony or violent crime. Labastida was also sentenced to five years for first-degree conspiracy to escape, with all of those years suspended.
Labastida will get credit for one year of time served.
He will serve five years of supervised probation following his release from prison. Conditions of probation include that he must receive a mental health evaluation and seek treatment, receive a substance abuse and alcohol evaluation and seek related treatment, abstain from alcohol and illegal drugs, stay away from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center, and not contact Darrin Jeter, 20, who was also involved in the incident.
Before Dean handed down the sentence, Leonard recommended Labastida be sentenced to five years without parole followed by five years of probation. Dean said she was "taken aback" by the state's "lenient" sentencing recommendation.
She said that although she feels for Labastida's family and the pain they have been going through, she also feels for the people that were at the psychiatric facility on the day of the escape.
In June, Labastida pleaded guilty to the three charges. The charges stem from Jeter's escape from the psychiatric facility located on Woods Road in Cambridge last year. At that time, Jeter, who has schizophrenia, had been committed to the hospital center.
At the June plea hearings for both Labastida and Jeter, Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard said Labastida approached the facility on Aug. 1, 2023 and shot into a window several times. She said Labastida and Jeter kicked out the broken window so Jeter could exit the building. The two fled the area in a black vehicle.
Jeter was located by the Montgomery County Sheriff's Office the following day. Leonard said Labastida was identified as a suspect through investigation. Evidence of an escape plan between the two was discovered through investigation, Leonard said at Jeter's hearing.
Jeter was sentenced to 10 years in prison for first-degree escape with eight of those years suspended.
During Labastida's sentencing hearing Friday, defense attorney Marvin Ochoa said Labastida is sorry for his actions and is ashamed and embarrassed. He said when Labastida was in middle school, he withdrew from his family and started hanging out with the "wrong" crew, making bad decisions.
Ochoa said that when Labastida helped with the escape, his brain wasn't fully developed and didn't realize the consequences of his actions, including the "pain and suffering" it would cause his family.
Before showing the certificates Labastida was awarded for classes he took in jail, Ochoa said Labastida has "a lot to give to this world" and he just needs guidance and support.
Labastida told Judge Karen Dean that there was no reason for him to do what he did on Aug. 1 2023, but there is also no reason for his life to be "stunted." He said he believes he can be a productive member of society.
Labastida's family also spoke at the hearing Friday, sharing the toll this incident has taken on their family. His mother Patricia Sanchez said her son "has learned a lesson." She said that she never imagined she would see one of her children standing in front of a judge like this.
"We should (have been) getting ready to go to a graduation or something else," Sanchez said, "not to this."
Labastida's older brother, Nicholas Sanchez, said that Labastida is a hard worker and that with the right guidance, he can become a productive member of society.
The victim of Labastida's assault charge was not present at the hearing and did not wish to make an impact statement. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Some political signs vandalized in Talbot County
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Some political signs vandalized in Talbot County

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 358
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A number of political signs in Easton and around Talbot County have been vandalized, according to police and residents.Easton Police Department Captain Greg Wright said in the last month, there have been reports of at least four signs damaged or stolen in the town. There have been multiple reports since last Friday.
"This is a trend that usually occurs every election cycle," Wright said. "We've had two reported to us. One (sign) at the beginning of September and two (signs) over last weekend."
Easton police have not yet identified any of those involved in the recent vandalism, Wright said.
Talbot County Republican Central Committee Chair Robert Osborne said signs have been vandalized on Dover Street recently. Some have been spray painted, while others have been stolen.
Signs stolen or vandalized include not just those for Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, but also candidates for the Talbot Board of Education. Osborne said, "it's very frustrating that people don't want a different view."
"It's a shame that people have hate in their heart," Osborne said. " … Everybody's in our prayers, we just want the election to be fair."
Patrick Firth, chair of the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee, said there has been sign vandalism against Democratic candidates in Oxford, Trappe and Cordova. Firth said the Talbot County Democratic Party condemns all vandalism.
"These acts of vandalism are not just about signs; they are about the erosion of the democratic process and the suppression of free speech," Firth said in a statement. "We must hold ourselves to a higher standard, respecting the political views of all citizens, regardless of party affiliation."
Wright encourages residents to not place signs too close to their houses in case someone tries to damage or steal them.
He said while "there's no doubt" some acts of political sign vandalism go unreported, it's best to report them to police for documentation.
"Be vigilant. Report it if it happens to them. If for any reason, it gives us an idea if we need to concentrate on a certain area, or just so we know what's going on," Wright said. "Because people are entering your property to commit a crime, and that should be concerning." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: No small feat
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
No small feat

 December 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 784
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Being a court appointed special advocate isn't your average volunteer gig."This is not something you just sign up for Saturday and show up if you can," CASA of the Mid-Shore Volunteer Coordinator Jane Crawford said.
As Mid-Shore court appointed special advocates, or CASAs, volunteers in Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties are assigned to be advocates for children who are considered to be at significant risk in their current homes and have been placed under court protection. According to the nonprofit, reasons a child might be under court protection include abuse, neglect and abandonment.
Those advocates are tasked with identifying a child's needs and advocating for the necessary services so their needs can be met. CASAs share their recommendations with the judge assigned to that child's case.
CASA of the Mid-Shore Executive Director Robin Davenport said the work that the organization's volunteers do is "heroic."
"In a nutshell, we're saying, 'Be a sponge,'" she said about a CASA's role. "Just go around and soak up every bit of information you can about the child. Wring the sponge out. Figure out what is important for us to be paying attention to and bringing to the court's attention."
Though it can be considered rewarding, the volunteer gig — open to residents who are at least 21 years old — is a commitment.
Following a lengthy application process and in-depth interview, those interested in volunteering with CASA of the Mid-Shore must complete eight training sessions. Once those trainings are complete and the volunteers have been sworn into the courthouses as officers of the court, they are assigned to a case.
Generally, CASAs are assigned to one case at a time. The length of a case can vary. And although the children are from one of the four counties served by CASA of the Mid-Shore, a lot of the time they are living in placements outside the four counties, Davenport said.
Crawford said the decision to become a CASA volunteer isn't always an easy one to make.
"Once people learn about the program and what's required, sometimes they need to think about it too because of that commitment," she said.
Janet Healy, a Talbot County resident, has been a CASA volunteer since 2008. After a career as an educator, Healy wanted to find a volunteer opportunity where she could work with kids in a less "intensive" way, she said.
"And it just seemed like the right fit," she said about volunteering with CASA of the Mid-Shore.
For Healy, one of the most rewarding aspects of the job is building relationships.
"(Building relationships) with kids, with foster parents, with social workers," she said, later adding, "It's hard when things don't work out the way you think they should, but it's also, on the other hand, very rewarding."
Healy said one adoptive mother still sends her photos of the sibling group that she was a CASA for about four years ago.
"That's very rewarding to get some of that feedback," she said. "To see how well some of these kids are doing."
But there are challenging aspects of the job, too. Davenport said it's important for CASAs to take things slow and be consistent when building relationships with the children. She said they tell volunteers not to take things personally.
A child might be dealing with trauma, she said, "and so there are a lot of things that we have to just keep track of and measure things in very small victories."
Healy said making recommendations to judges is a big responsibility. She said taking on the role of a CASA means becoming invested and emotionally involved.
"Because you do get very invested in these kids, but you know it really is temporary," she said. "You have to keep that in the back of your mind all the time."
BECOMING TOUCHSTONESCASA of the Mid-Shore is celebrating 35 years of service in 2025. Davenport has been there since the beginning. She has seen the organization grow not only in staff, but in the number of counties it serves.
"It was a very tiny, tiny organization," she said about the nonprofit's start. "We, at that point, were only Talbot County."
On May 17, the nonprofit will host a special fundraiser called "Voices of Hope." The celebration is, in part, to celebrate CASA of the Mid-Shore's successful 35 years and kick off its next 35.
Davenport said that over the years, she's seen CASAs become "incredible touchstones" for the children they advocate for.
"The CASA volunteers end up kind of being the one consistent adult in these children's lives," she said. "Foster care is not a short turnaround usually. So it's been really exciting for us to see that the CASAs themselves are not only helping the judge, but they're actually really giving messages to the children that stick with them for years." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023

 January 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — There were less than half as many homicides in Cambridge in 2023 compared to the year before.In 2022, Cambridge saw seven homicides. In 2023, it saw three.
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd, who was sworn in as chief in January of 2023, called the difference progress. He credits the decrease in homicides to a few different things — namely, how the department polices and its partnerships with other agencies.
One of the police department's top priorities last year was community-oriented policing. For Todd, that meant being a part of the community that the department services.
He said getting out into neighborhoods and creating programs like neighborhood watches can help build relationships and trust in communities and, hopefully, reduce crime.
Along with prioritizing community policing, Todd said that the department has tried to be proactive in addressing gun violence and aggressive assaults. He said CPD is now taking an average of one gun off the street each week, "well more than double" the average in 2022.
Todd also stressed the importance of working with other agencies and working with the community. He said that being a part of the Dorchester County Task Force, getting support from Cambridge City Council and focusing on community-oriented policing has all made a difference.
"I think a lot of people have come to the table in the last year," he said.
Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout said this decrease in the number of homicides in Cambridge is a significant one.
"Every shooting that we can stop is a step in the right direction," he said.
Rideout said he thinks CPD's community policing efforts are part of the reason for that success.
"It's just started, but I think they're building a trust within the community that just did not exist before now," he said.
Lieutenant Kyle Clark with Maryland State Police's Homicide Unit said that although he can't say for certain why the number of homicides has gone down in Cambridge, he can say that there has been a focus on collaboration between agencies.
"We do concentrate on a lot of collaborative efforts with other units within the State Police and also allied agencies," he said, specifying the use of task forces, gang units and gun units. "And those are all tools that we use to combat the crime in any city."
Clark said that he would estimate about 50% of the homicides in the last two years in Cambridge have been gang-related. He said that in addressing gang violence, MSP, along with other agencies at all levels, do "everything and anything" to combat the gang violence.
Todd said CPD is working to identify gang members and groups that are "constantly harassing" residents in different Cambridge neighborhoods. He said they have worked with the different agencies within the Dorchester County Task Force as well as federal agencies to identify who is bringing in handguns and where they are coming from.
"The partnership's been great with the Task Force and Maryland State Police," he said. "The Homicide Unit with Maryland State Police — they handle all of our homicides. So we work hand in hand together. And that's what it's going to take."
Todd said he has noticed gun violence and homicide rates begin to fall throughout the country.
Specific data on other crime rates in Cambridge should be released to the public in the next couple of weeks, Todd said.
Rideout said early intervention is important when it comes to crime prevention. Rideout was recently at a meeting about a flag football initiative by CPD and the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services.
"It was really an exciting possibility of where we can really start focusing, not only on the crime itself, but on the prevention and early intervention," he said.
Rideout added that engaging children in education and outside activities, such as programming at the YMCA or Boys and Girls Club, can have a positive effect.
Going into 2024, CPD's goals include continuing to build its manpower, focusing on data-driven technology and "patrolling with a purpose."
Todd said "patrolling with a purpose" means putting officers in the areas where crimes are occurring on the specific days and at the specific times they have been occurring.
He said that residents can also expect to see more data from CPD in the new year, including heat maps of where crimes are occurring.
Regarding homicides, Rideout said the downward trend is good, but added that the work doesn't stop here.
"What we have to do is continue working on it and engage the community in working on it to hopefully keep these numbers down," he said.

title: QA, Kent approve regional jail agreement, Caroline not yet on board
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QA, Kent approve regional jail agreement, Caroline not yet on board

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A proposed new regional detention center to be located at the former Eastern Pre-Release Unit site at 700 Flat Iron Square Road near Church Hill would house detainees from Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent counties. But all counties have yet to reach an agreement. The Queen Anne's commissioners gave their approval to the Mid-Shore Regional Detention Center Cooperative Service Agreement final draft Jan. 28, as did Kent. Caroline remains uncommitted.The new jail facility aims to address the growing need for modern and efficient detention facilities in the region, where counties are struggling to finance renovations or replacements of their aging detention facilities.
The corrections facility is proposed to be owned by Queen Anne's County with employment also falling under Queen Anne's County; the goal being to assimilate the current Kent and Caroline correctional officers.
The agreement has been a collaboration between the three counties for several months, Queen Anne's County Administrator Todd Mohn said.
With Kent County also approving the final draft, the agreement is still waiting on a public hearing from Caroline County. If Caroline doesn't sign, Kent Commissioners said they would renegotiate with Queen Anne's alone.
Kent Commissioner John Price made the motion to a unanimous vote. The facility will be built regardless, he said, noting the number of beds would be the primary change if Caroline dropped out.
In a recent meeting of the Caroline County commissioners, they said they still have not received exact numbers for how much everything will cost and how much the county will save by joining the agreement with the other counties.
Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter suggested that the county should do an independent evaluation of the operating cost.
"This decision is going to depend on the operational cost and I'm talking long range operational cost," Porter said. "Would it make sense for us to engage someone to do an independent evaluation of these operating cost?"
Each county is currently operating their own jails and have either exceeded inmate capacity or need extensive renovation.
With the State of Maryland willing to fund up to 50% of the costs of the design and construction, a regional detention center is anticipated to be of less cost to the citizens.
Queen Anne's County Commissioner Phil Dumenil noted the regional and state effort, "is a savings for all three counties."
At about 100 years old, Caroline's facility in particularly is in need of improvement, according to Queen Anne's commissioners.

title: American Legion Post 77 looking to jumpstart Hometown Heroes banner project
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
American Legion Post 77 looking to jumpstart Hometown Heroes banner project

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An effort to honor past and present veterans, firefighters and police officers gained momentum at the Easton Town Council on Monday evening.Joan Harris-Brooks, speaking on behalf of Blake-Blackston American Legion Post 77, asked the council to partner with the group in creating a banner program so that families of Talbot County veterans, firefighters and officers can honor their loved ones.
Harris-Brooks said the banners would be placed on Ward 4 roads such as Glenwood Avenue, Port Street and West Street. Her father, John Harris Jr., and her uncle were members of Post 77, which operates on Glenwood Avenue.
With members of Post 77 in attendance, council members expressed nothing but support for the project.
"I think that this is a great endeavor," Ward 4 Council Member the Rev. Elmer Davis said. "(It's important) that we don't lose the memory of those persons who fought for our country. I believe it's our responsibility to help out with this project. Secondly, it doesn't cost the town a dime."
The Hometown Heroes Banner program began in 2006 in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. Today, Mid-Shore towns including Federalsburg, Hurlock and Preston showcase banners honoring past and present veterans.
Harris-Brooks said the banners would cost $200 each. There will be no ask of the council to provide any money for the project.
She asked that the town office hold blank applications for interested families, in addition to applications being advertised on social media and at Post 77.
"It will instill a sense of pride and unity in Easton and for our country," Harris-Brooks told the council. "It is our goal that you grant us approval. And we believe that if you grant us an approval, this will make a landmark for you as our councilmen."
Council members unanimously approved the request. Prior to voting, the council expressed hopes that the banner project could extend to the entire town.
Harris-Brooks said that Post 77 will accept donations from the community that can help families who cannot afford the cost of a banner. She added that Post 77 will work with American Legion Talbot Post 70, Easton Utilities and the town as the project comes to life.
"I think our children need to be aware," Harris-Brooks said. "We still have young people still enlisted in the service. I will just very passionately say my uncle was a member of Post 77 … He gave his ultimate self serving."
Commander Victor Middleton thanked the council for their support following the approval.
"When people say thank you for your service, it really lifted me up just now to a higher level," Middleton said. "And I thank you all."

title: Second fatal crash in three days prompts re-closure of Price Station Road crossover on U.S. 301
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Second fatal crash in three days prompts re-closure of Price Station Road crossover on U.S. 301

 July 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 565
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHURCH HILL — Following two fatal crashes in three days, state transportation officials have ordered the closure of the MD 405 (Price Station Road) median crossover at U.S. Route 301 in Queen Anne's County.The Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration announced Friday, July 25, that the crossover will be closed beginning Saturday, July 26. Emergency vehicle access will be maintained, and alternate crossovers are available at MD 19 (Roberts Station Road), two miles north, and Hayden Clark Road, 1.7 miles south.
"This is a safety-focused decision," said State Highway Administrator Will Pines. "This closure is necessary to save lives and make the corridor safer for the tens of thousands of travelers and residents who use it every day."
The announcement follows two deadly collisions at the intersection this week, resulting in three fatalities.
On Thursday, July 24, a two-vehicle crash occurred around noon, leaving two people dead at the scene.
Just two days earlier, another woman was killed when her vehicle was struck by a southbound car as she attempted to cross Route 301. The impact caused her car to overturn. The other vehicle's two occupants — a 22-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman — were flown to R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore in critical condition.
The State Highway Administration had previously closed the crossover in July 2024 due to a high number of crashes. Between January 2019 and December 2023, there were 76 reported crashes at the site — 62 of them in the southbound lanes, most attributed to driver inattention or failure to yield. Despite safety upgrades such as restriping, rumble strips, additional signage, and channelizing devices, collisions have continued at an alarming rate.
Troopers from the Centreville Barrack of the Maryland State Police, Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann, and first responders from the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company have all voiced strong support for the closure.
The Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company confirmed Friday that it had been notified of the closure and has coordinated with SHA to ensure continued emergency access to communities east of Route 301, including Price and Bridgetown Estates.
"As we did in July of 2024, the department leadership reached out to SHA to ensure emergency access would be available to Fire, EMS, and Police units responding to emergency calls on the east side of Route 301," the fire company said in a statement. "We have been assured by SHA leadership that they intend to use the same process as before and that emergency access will be available.
"While this will create a slight delay in response times, we appreciate the willingness of SHA to work with us to keep those delays as short as possible while long-term solutions for the crossover are worked. The leadership of the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company is committed to providing the most timely and efficient emergency response possible and will continue to monitor the situation and be a partner with SHA for a permanent solution."
Sen. Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) also voiced support for the re-closure, stating, "Given the dangerous track record at this intersection — and now two fatal accidents in just three days — it is clear that further action is urgently needed. While I understand the temporary inconvenience to motorists, public safety must come first."
The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading both crash investigations. Findings will be submitted to the Queen Anne's County State's Attorney's Office for review. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Ridgely man indicted on rape, sex offense charges
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Ridgely man indicted on rape, sex offense charges

 February 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime

 DENTON — A 26-year-old Ridgely man was indicted Jan. 18 in Caroline County in connection to an alleged sexual assault in 2012.Rhett Ritter is facing second-degree rape; second-, third- and fourth-degree sex offenses and second-degree assault charges related to the incident.
According to the indictment, the charges stem from a situation involving another minor, which is alleged to have occurred in January 2012 in Ridgely.
Ritter was arrested Monday. He was initially ordered held without bond.
At a bail review Tuesday afternoon, Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin said he wasn't opposed to supervised release, saying he didn't think Ritter was a danger to himself or the alleged victim.
Ritter's defense attorney Chris Jennings advocated for release without supervision, pointing out Ritter's lack of criminal history and unlikelihood of being a flight risk or danger to the community.
Ritter is a founding member and the CEO of Purple Peake CBD in Denton.
Ritter also would have been 14 years old at the time of the incident, Jennings added.
Mentioning Ritter's strong ties to the community and employment status, Caroline County Circuit Judge Heather Price ruled to release him on a $10,000 unsecured bond.
Ritter is set to appear for a scheduling conference in Caroline County Circuit Court on Feb. 21.

title: Bradford House resident wants to feel safe at home after multiple assaults
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Bradford House resident wants to feel safe at home after multiple assaults

 May 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Tena Cheaton looked forward to moving into the Bradford House Apartments about five years ago.At that time, Cheaton, now 59, was homeless.
She was receiving temporary disability assistance and waiting to be approved for supplemental security income, which is financial assistance for people who have little or no income and resources and have a disability, blindness or are 65 years of age or older.
"So I wanted to come," she said about Bradford House. "I didn't realize it was this bad."
Since moving in, Cheaton — who has PTSD, ADHD, bipolar disorder, fibromyalgia and back problems that include degenerative disc disease and spinal stenosis — said she has been assaulted, threatened and had her belongings stolen on the property.
Cheaton said that about two years ago, she was raped by a man who was staying with another tenant at Bradford House.
Cheaton said it happened in her apartment. She knew the man. He drugged her before raping her, she said.
After a few weeks of "throwing up constantly" and "crying uncontrollably," Cheaton went to rehab to get treatment.
She said it was her therapist that told her she didn't have to face her assaulter in the Bradford House halls everyday, and there were resources that could keep him out of the building.
Although Cheaton said she didn't call the police after she was raped, she did get restraining order against her rapist later on.
But despite the restraining order, Cheaton said she would still see her rapist in the halls at Bradford House.
Under the Violence Against Women Act, a housing provider may evict or terminate the assistance of a perpetrator of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault or stalking, according to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Notice of Occupancy Rights under the Violence Against Women Act.
According to the notice, those who have experienced domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault or stalking must have the option to stay in their subsidized housing and can request an emergency transfer from the housing provider for safety reasons.
In a statement to the Star Democrat, Millennia Housing Management — which manages Bradford House — said the Bradford House property management team sends violations to anyone residing at the property that is the cause of an assault or theft.
Cheaton said she is not the only tenant that has been raped in the building. And this is not the only time Cheaton said she has been put in danger at Bradford House. She said she has also been held at knifepoint, threatened and assaulted on the property.
In one instance, Cheaton remembers taking her dog outside a few hours after midnight.
"I had just shut that door," she said. "And somebody standing way down there at the end of the building was hollering at me."
Cheaton, who said she doesn't leave the door to the building open for anyone, said the person was telling her to leave the door open.
She said the man got in her face and threatened to shoot her. By the time police arrived, he was gone, Cheaton said.
According to a Cambridge Police Department calls for service report requested by the Star Democrat, of the 1,099 calls for service to Bradford House made between Aug. 1, 2021, and Feb. 21, 2024, 18 were for reports of threats.
After being threatened outside the building, Cheaton — who has had experiences with substance abuse — said she moved out of Bradford House for about a month to live with her daughter.
"To stay sober in a building like this is very, very difficult," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 EASTON — An Easton man has received a year-and-a-half sentence on child pornography charges.Darian Braun, 23, was arrested in September, 2024. He pleaded guilty in February to six counts of promoting and distributing child pornography. During the plea hearing, Braun said he pleaded guilty because he was guilty and it was in his best interest.
On June 26, Judge Philip Cronan handed down a five-year sentence with all but one year, five months and 29 days suspended. That nearly 18-month term began June 26.
Braun was previously charged on 34 total counts — 17 for promoting and distributing child pornography, and the other 17 for possessing child pornography. As part of the six-count plea agreement, the state did not prosecute the remaining 28 charges.
At the February plea hearing, prosecutors said the Easton Police Department received a tip last year from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children about a person possessing child sexual abuse material. Investigators identified that person as Braun, prosecutors said.
Braun will be registered as a tier II sex offender. He is under five years supervised probation among a number of other conditions.

title: Two arrested in separate child-abuse cases
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstien@chespub.com
content:
Two arrested in separate child-abuse cases

 October 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstien@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 312
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE'S COUNTY — The Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office announced two arrests in separate child-abuse investigations, including a Stevensville man wanted in Kentucky and an Essex man charged with child pornography.On Sept. 18, the sheriff's office was contacted by the Fulton County Sheriff's Office in Hickman, Kentucky, regarding a full-extradition warrant for Robert Wolfe, 59, of Stevensville, on three counts of first-degree sexual abuse of a child younger than 12, according to the sheriff's office.
Fulton County authorities advised that Wolfe had been entered into the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) database, the sheriff's office said. After confirming the active warrant, deputies arrested Wolfe at his Stevensville residence. He was charged as a fugitive from justice and held pending extradition to Kentucky to face the charges.
"This case highlights the value of interagency cooperation," public information officer Kaitlyn Briselli said in a statement. "By working closely with our partners in other jurisdictions, we were able to locate and apprehend a fugitive whose actions threatened the safety of our community and, most importantly, our children."
In an unrelated case, the sheriff's office said Jamie Lee Overton Jr., 23, of Essex, was arrested on Sept. 24 in Baltimore and held without bond following an investigation into a report received Aug. 30. A county resident alleged an unknown adult male contacted their child, younger than 12, for sexual purposes, according to the sheriff's office.
After reviewing evidence, investigators obtained a warrant Sept. 19 charging Overton with sexual solicitation of a minor, two counts of child pornography and two counts of obscene telephone misuse, the sheriff's office said.
Because the investigation is ongoing, the sheriff's office said it could not release specifics on how the child was contacted. Detectives are reviewing evidence to determine whether additional victims may be involved.
Anyone with information is asked to contact Detective Cpl. Parker at gparker@qac.org or call the anonymous tip line at 410-758-6666.

title: Police investigating serious rollover crash outside Trappe
author: Konner Metz
content:
Police investigating serious rollover crash outside Trappe

 June 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 133
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — Police are investigating a serious crash that occurred just outside Trappe on Tuesday.At around 4:30 a.m. Tuesday, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to an accident in the area of Chloras Point Road and Claylands Road, according to a press release.
The vehicle involved was 150 yards from the road and rolled over multiple times, police said. Authorities say a passenger was ejected from the vehicle and sustained life-threatening injuries.
Police said the passenger was then taken to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton and later transferred to a shock trauma center in Baltimore.
The 18-year-old driver, Ellis Newcomb, refused treatment at the scene, according to the press release.
The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is actively investigating the crash. Anyone with information is asked to contact the Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020.

title: Police arrest Dorchester County man on rape, sexual assault charges
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Police arrest Dorchester County man on rape, sexual assault charges

 September 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Police arrested a man from Toddville on rape, sexual offense and assault charges on Monday morning, according to a press release.Jason Groff, 41, was arrested just after 11 a.m. Monday by the Cambridge Police Department. A release stated city police received assistance from the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office in locating Groff, who was actively being sought by authorities.
Police obtained information that Groff was heading to Cambridge from Toddville, which is just over 20 miles south of Cambridge. Police located him northwest of Toddville around the Lakesville area, the release stated.
Groff is being held without bond in the Dorchester County Department of Corrections. He's charged with two counts each of first-degree rape, second-degree rape, sex offense of the third degree and sex offense of the fourth degree. He is also charged with a count of second-degree assault and a count of false imprisonment.
The charges stem from an investigation by the Cambridge Police Department into an Aug. 13 incident.
According to the release, investigators began an investigation on Aug. 16, contacting a female victim in the hospital. She reported that after pulling into a gas station to inflate a tire, a man engaged in conversation with her.
The release stated the man and the female went to a Cambridge residence, where "the male subject was reported to making lewd comments and advancements on the female victim."
"The female repeatedly told the male subject 'No' and to 'Stop,'" the release states. "The male subject ended up reportedly overpowering the female victim and she ended up being raped."
Investigators gathered descriptions of the subject, and on Aug. 27, an officer matched the descriptions to a man identified as Groff. Detectives met with Groff for an interview on Aug. 28.
On Aug. 29, an arrest warrant was issued for Groff. The investigation revealed Groff was on probation with restrictions and is a registered sex offender.
The investigation is ongoing. Anyone with information regarding the incident is asked to contact the Cambridge Police Department's Criminal Investigations Division at 410-901-8457. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Political vandalism reported in Easton ahead of Election Day
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Political vandalism reported in Easton ahead of Election Day

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 219
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton residents reported incidents of sign vandalism in the days leading up to the 2024 general election.Sandra Chappell said on Monday her two yard signs supporting Vice President Kamala Harris and Angela Alsobrooks were taken from her yard and disposed of away from her property.
Chappell said the incident left her surprised and concerned over political vandalism.
"It's just not right," Chappell said. "You can have different opinions, but you should also respect the fact that others do too, and it doesn't mean that the other side from wherever a person is bad, it just means that they differ with you and their opinions, because that should be a part of life."
The following day Chappell said she saw close to 20 political signs vandalized and thrown in a pile. The vast majority were supporting Kamala Harris' presidential race and Candace Henry, a candidate for the Talbot County Board of Education.
Chappell reported both incidents to Easton Police.
Easton Police Department Captain Greg Wright said in September, there had been reports of at least four signs damaged or stolen in the town. More reports have been made in the months following.
John Bollinger, captain for the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, said there has been a noticeable decrease in reported vandalism of political signs and other forms of vandalism compared to previous years. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton police officer found guilty of misconduct
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton police officer found guilty of misconduct

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 662
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton police officer was found guilty on Tuesday of misconduct in office. Sgt. Jason Dyott, 38, was convicted of two separate instances of engaging in physical sexual conduct with two different teenage girls while on duty.Judge C. Carey Deeley Jr. found Easton Police Department Dyott guilty on two counts of misconduct in office. Dyott — who had served as an Easton police officer since approximately June 2008 — was found guilty under three theories of misconduct: malfeasance, misfeasance and nonfeasance.
The charges stem from allegations that Dyott used his departmental cell phone to communicate in a sexual manner with several teenagers and students at local high schools and met up with them while on duty. Two teenage girls are mentioned in a charging document from the Office of the State Prosecutor.
During opening statements of the trial, Senior Assistant State Prosecutor Mary Setzer said that in the fall of 2022, Dyott engaged in physical acts with two teenage girls in separate instances. She said that on Nov. 11, Dyott picked up an 18-year-old from her friend's house in his police vehicle and had sex with her in the vehicle while on duty.
Setzer said that two days later, Dyott met with a 17-year-old in the Target parking lot while he was on duty and made out with her. According to the charging document, Dyott leveraged his position as a police officer to engage in this sexual relationship and sent her multiple photographs of him in his police uniform with sexually provocative language attached.
Dyott's defense attorney Shaun Owens said during opening statements that Dyott is not denying the relationships with the teenagers. Owens said the conduct was not criminal, however, and that he does not believe there is evidence to support that Dyott's actions constituted misconduct.
Owens said the state would need to prove that Dyott engaged in the acts because he was a police officer or because he had been afforded that privilege as a police officer. Owens said that in any profession, Dyott could have engaged in the exact same behavior.
During the trial, both of the then-teenagers mentioned in the charging document testified. The then-17-year-old said that when the investigation into Dyott began, Dyott told her to deny what happened, and he said they didn't do anything wrong because she was old enough to consent.
The then-18-year-old recounted the night she met up with Dyott. She said that while in the police vehicle, the police radio was on, and after she heard a badge number spoken over the radio, Dyott turned the radio down. She said that she and Dyott didn't have any conversations about Dyott's job during their interaction, and Dyott didn't respond to work during that time.
During closing arguments, Owens brought up that the radio call, which the then-18-year-old talked about during testimony. He said that it was not clear what the call was about, if it was for Dyott specifically or if it required Dyott's response.
Deputy State Prosecutor Sarah David said that in the two incidents, Dyott acted in his official capacity. Not only was he on duty, she said, but he was presenting himself to the public and to the teenage girls as an officer.
A sentencing hearing is set for Nov. 1.
According to a news release from the Office of the State Prosecutor, State Prosecutor Charlton T. Howard III said, "Law enforcement officers who abuse the power of their position, and betray the trust of the community, must be held accountable."
In an interview with the Star Democrat Wednesday, Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said Dyott is suspended with pay. He has been suspended with pay since the beginning stages of the investigation in 2023.
In 2014, Dyott was named the Easton's department's officer of the year.
According to a Wednesday press release, "upon this conviction, the Easton Police Department will now seek to impose the appropriate administrative penalties upon Mr. Dyott."
Lowery said he could not say at this time when those administrative penalties will be imposed.
This article may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Police Accountability Board gears up for first annual report
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Police Accountability Board gears up for first annual report

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - As the year draws to a close, the Talbot County Police Accountability Board is preparing to compose its first annual report.The Board, which receives complaints of police misconduct, meets with law enforcement officials and reviews outcomes of disciplinary matters, will be required to submit the annual report to the Talbot County Council by Dec. 31.The report is intended to identify trends in police disciplinary processes and recommend policy changes that would improve police accountability in Talbot County.It will also include the number of complaints submitted by members of the public.The Administrative Charging Committee which reviews findings of a law enforcement agency's investigation of a complaint, determines if an officer should be administratively charged and recommends appropriate discipline, has received 14 complaints between January and August, according to the Talbot County Office of Law.While the Board will meet on Tuesday, Dec. 19, to discuss the draft annual report, top law enforcement officials weighed in on some items they want to see included in the document at the Board's Nov.14 meeting.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble asked the Board to include details on the amount of time local law enforcement agencies are spending on handling complaints, adding that it's an added workload for his office.Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said he appreciated how the Administrative Charging Committee's opinions were reasoned out, though he believed some things were mischaracterized.Lowrey also said the "year and a day" issue needed to be addressed.State law requires that a determination on whether or not an officer should be administratively charged be made within a year and a day of a complaint being made. Talbot County law enforcement officials raised concerns about the rule in the context of parallel criminal investigations, according to minutes from the Board's August meeting.Police Accountability Board Chair Mitch Ettinger agreed to address the issue in the report.Further discussion will take place at the December meeting. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Members of the Talbot County Police Accountability Board, seated to the right, listen to the county's top law enforcement officials during a Nov. 14 meeting. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Attorney takes on ICE on Eastern Shore
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Attorney takes on ICE on Eastern Shore

 September 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Criminal defense attorney Ivette Furneisen has made it her mission to stand between federal agents and some of her clients.From courtrooms to detention centers, she is fighting U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement on behalf of families across the Eastern Shore.
Having gone through the immigration process herself, she understands what it entails. Lately, she said, the road has gotten more difficult under the Trump administration.
"In general, I see that people are being picked up and detained for minor traffic offenses," she said.
This was not so during past administrations, she said. Under other administrations, felonies and misdemeanors such as assault, theft, neglect of a minor and sex crimes would lead to deportation since they are crimes of moral turpitude.
"Under Trump however," she said, "people are being picked up for minor offenses and then targeted by ICE."
That's the distinction.
In a recent case, her client was charged with driving under the influence by local police for having open alcohol containers in the back seat. He was acquitted, she said, but it put a target on her client for ICE.
Furneisen recalled that her client was leaving the hospital between Kent and Talbot counties after his wife's medical checkup when he was stopped by ICE. She said agents busted out the windows while his pregnant wife was in the car and detained him. Furneisen and his loved ones did not know where he was for three days.
She said that level of apprehension is heightened by more ICE presence, including in courtrooms.
In her first case of this happening recently, two undercover ICE agents approached her client in court, asked their name, then hauled them into a van.
"I am seeing a lot of failure to appear in court, especially for minor traffic violations, and that makes things worse for those facing charges," she said. "I tell them they need to show up for court with a lawyer."
It could mean the difference between paying a fine and being detained by ICE.
"That's why I fight so hard for them," she said. "If I can get them out of jail at the bail review, they will have a better chance to stay with their families. If they go to jail, their life in the U.S. is over."
She said these are not isolated incidents.
"I am swamped with work of this nature," she said, noting cases from Kent to Talbot and Queen Anne's counties.
The attorney has built her practice around these kinds of challenges.
Furneisen has worked hard all of her life, immigrating from Spain, establishing herself as a prominent immigration attorney on the Eastern Shore. She is half of the law firm of Campbell and Furneisen, located on Cross Street in Chestertown.
The firm's expertise earned Furneisen the 2024 Women to Watch recognition, an honor sponsored by the Kent County News' parent company, Adams MultiMedia. She is one of the only Spanish-speaking attorneys on the Eastern Shore, dealing with criminal, traffic and immigration cases.
Furneisen received her law degree from the University of Barcelona Law School. After becoming a United States citizen, she received her master's degree in U.S. law from George Mason Law School. She is admitted to practice in both state and federal courts in Maryland, the District of Columbia Court of Appeals and the Executive Office for Immigration Review.
That background and the multiple courts where she is admitted have come in handy in the past year as a criminal attorney that handles some immigration cases.
In the past, anyone could request a bond hearing. Now, she said, the federal government wants to limit or eliminate bond eligibility for many immigrants detained by ICE, particularly those who entered the U.S. illegally.
"The problem is that this will lead to indefinite detention because there is a backlog in immigration court," she said. "These people could be detained for years before they have their immigration hearing."
Furneisen described one client who was told not to plead guilty to theft and he would receive probation before judgment ©, which is not considered a conviction under immigration law. Her client pleaded not guilty and paid full restitution.
The judge ordered the detention center to release her client, but the center did not comply. She filed a writ of habeas corpus to release him, but ICE picked him up and gave him an option: get deported or sign a voluntary departure.
He chose the latter and went back to an area where his brothers and cousins were tortured before being beheaded by a gang.
"That's why I fight so hard to keep them here, but sometimes everything goes against you and you lose those battles," she said.
She said some of her clients, the ones who are undocumented, pay taxes through special IRS rules.
"They work in the county, they pay taxes and they are contributing, but they are still getting deported," she said.
Her view aligns with Maryland Attorney General Anthony G. Brown, who has said that immigration violations are a federal civil matter, not a state-level criminal offense.
Kent County Sheriff Dennis Hickman said his office's stance on ICE has not changed since March.
"In the past ICE has placed a detainer on illegal immigrants who were being held on local charges," Hickman wrote, "but when the sentence was over they were required to come get them. That practice has not changed."
Furneisen sees positive changes happening within the justice system as cases like Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Maryland man who was deported to El Salvador earlier this year before being brought back, gain national attention.
"Just because you're being charged with a crime doesn't mean you did it," she said. "I love my job in helping those who don't have a voice and being an advocate for them." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
